results.webTitle: How the US student loan debt crisis started â€” and how it could end

fields.headline: How the US student loan debt crisis started â€” and how it could end
fields.trailText: What to do about the debt has become a hot political issues as midterm elections approach
fields.body:
Americaâ€™s students have a debt problem. A big one. More than 45 million Americans â€“ more than the population of California â€“ now owe a collective $1.7tn in student debt.

What to do about that debt has become a hot political issues as midterm elections approach.

The vast majority of the money is owed to the federal government, which has been backing or directly offering student loans for higher education since 1958. While student loans are not new in the United States, the amount of student debt has doubled over the last 16 years.

The Biden administration has recently hinted that some form of student debt forgiveness could be announced soon â€“ specifically, canceling at least $10,000 in student debt for Americans earning less than $125,000 a year. With that threshold, most student loan borrowers will qualify for some debt forgiveness.

If the executive action is undertaken, it will be the first large debt cancellation by the federal government to address the student debt crisis. Understanding the impact of such a dramatic policy requires unpacking the student debt crisis, beginning with its origins.

How the student debt crisis started

In 1957 the Soviet Union successfully launching the first earth-orbiting satellite, Sputnik. With the cold war raging the federal government feared the US education system was failing to produce enough scientists and engineers to compete with the Soviets and, in 1958, started handing out student loans through the National Defense Education Act.

Nearly a decade later, the Higher Education Act of 1965 allowed more people to take out loans as the federal government promised to pay back banks for any loans that were not repaid.

â€œIt all started from this choice, which I think was a terrible choice, to decide that as a policy matter we should support higher education â€¦ by giving [students] an opportunity to get a loan,â€ said DaliÃ© Jimenez, professor of law and director of the Student Loan Law Initiative at the University of California at Irvine. â€œIt was just a terrible mistake.â€

Starting in 2010, the federal government started directly lending money to student borrowers. In the wake of the Great Recession, the amount of student debt began to increase rapidly. Colleges were seeing increased enrollment as people left the workforce to go back to school. States slashed their higher education budgets, leading to higher tuition. More students were turning to for-profit colleges, which tend to be more expensive than public colleges.

Over the last few years, the amount of grant aid, which does not need to be paid back, has risen. Yet despite this appearance of more financial support for students to attend college, the cost of attendance has remained the same.

The cost of attending public college has actually increased at a higher rate than the cost to attend a private college. The net cost of attendance for four-year public colleges, which takes into account any grants students receive, went from $17,500 in 2006 to $20,210 in 2016, according to data from College Board.

â€œThat era 10 years ago was a really formative moment for producing a lot of debt thatâ€™s still out there,â€ said Kevin Miller, associate director for higher education at the Bipartisan Policy Centerâ€™s Economic Policy Project. â€œThe cost of college attendance has gone up a lot while household incomes in the United States havenâ€™t â€¦ thereâ€™s a real sense that if grant, state or institutional aid isnâ€™t filling the gap, that just leaves debt as the only option.â€

What student debt looks like today

For the 2021-2022 school year, the average cost of tuition and fees for a four-year public college is $10,740. The cost is nearly quadrupled for private institutions, at an average of $38,070. Even with grant aid, the cost of attendance is an average of $19,230 for public institutions and $32,720 at private schools.

Estimates put the average debt of those in the class of 2019 who took out student loans at $28,950. The number is close to the maximum $31,000 that students who are dependents of parents or guardians can borrow from the federal government to fund undergraduate education.

Continuing racial wealth disparities are reflected in who has to take out loans to fund college. About half of Black college students take out student loans, compared with 40% of white students. Black Americans owe an average of $25,000 more in debt than their white counterparts and are more likely to be behind on their payments.

Despite the amount of debt many students need to take on to attend college, nearly 20 million Americans still enroll in college every year. While earnings can depend on a personâ€™s industry, those with a bachelorâ€™s degrees earn 75% more in their lifetime than those with just a high school diploma.

â€œThe message is you have to get a college degree. Itâ€™s not just a rhetorical message, itâ€™s an actual truth that if you donâ€™t have a college degree, particularly if you are Black or brown â€¦ you will not be able to get a job that is better than your parents,â€ Jimenez said.

Those with graduate and professional degrees earn even more, but the price for an advanced degree is even higher. A good chunk of student debt â€“ about 40% â€“ is held by those who took out loans to pay for graduate school.

What the government has done to address student debt

The most substantial policy addressing student debt was first implemented by the Trump administration, which paused student loan payments and interest accrual at the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic. Both Trump and Biden extended the pause over the last two years, and it is now set to expire on 31 August.

Since the beginning of this year, Biden has announced a slate of additional policies alongside the pause extension. Those who have defaulted or are delinquent on their federal student loans will be returned to good standing. Biden forgave $415m in student debt for borrowers who attended predatory for-profit schools.

His administration also announced changes to the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program, which forgives the student loans of borrowers who are non-profit and government employees after 10 years of debt or after 120 payments are made. Over 113,000 borrowers with a cumulative $6.8bn in debt are now eligible for forgiveness. Over the years, the program has been under much criticism, as relief through the program was rare and borrowers were often deemed not qualified for logistical reasons.

The debate over debt forgiveness

Even as it seems Biden is prepared to cancel some debt, the idea has gotten some criticism over the last few months.

Republicans have been using student debt as a talking point against Biden as the midterm elections start rolling.

Senator Mitt Romney suggested that Democrats canceling student loans is a way of bribing voters. â€œOther bribe suggestions: Forgive auto loans? Forgive credit card debt? Forgive mortgages?â€ he wrote on Twitter. JD Vance (who went to Yale Law School) told the Washington Post that â€œBiden essentially wants blue-collar workers like truck drivers â€“ who didnâ€™t have the luxury of going to college to get drunk for four years â€“ to bail out a bunch of upper-middle-class kids.â€

The reality is that the student loans of those in the highest income quartile â€“ people making more than $97,000 â€“ do make up a third of all outstanding student debt. But many low-income Americans also have student debt, though the amount of debt they have is smaller. Those making below $27,000 a year make up 17% of all borrowers, but their loans comprise 12% of all the outstanding debt.

An income threshold could be a way for the government to target forgiveness to those who need it most. But some have pointed out that an income ceiling does not take into consideration a personâ€™s wealth.

â€œYouâ€™re looking at a snapshot of what your income was this year or last year, that tells you very little,â€ Jimenez said. â€œIf your family has no wealth, youâ€™re very differently situated from someone who has family wealth or personal wealth from previous careers.â€

Those who have been advocating for student debt cancellation say that $10,000 in forgiveness will not be enough to address the breadth of the crisis. Democratic lawmakers, including Senate majority leader Chuck Schumer, Senator Elizabeth Warren and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, have called on Biden to cancel up to $50,000.

â€œI donâ€™t believe in a cutoff, especially for so many of the frontline workers who are drowning in debt and would likely be excluded from relief,â€ Ocasio-Cortez told the Washington Post. â€œCanceling $50,000 in debt is where you really make a dent in inequality and the racial gap. $10,000 isnâ€™t.â€

Ending the student debt crisis for good

Even if Biden forgives some student debt, future college students will continue to take out loans â€“ and at higher interest rates. Tackling the price tag of college will come with its own complications, but advocates say it will be necessary to ensure student debt does not get worse.

While Bidenâ€™s plan for free community college was killed along with the rest of the social and climate spending bill that was making its way through Congress, some efforts for better college funding are happening at the local level.

In March, the governor of New Mexico signed a bill that would use $75m in state funds to cover tuition and fees for undergraduate students at two- and four-year colleges. Drives for similar government support have been seen in Pennsylvania, California and Maine.

â€œThe cost of college is too high for a lot of students to manage without debt. Making it so that students can go without debt or take less debt in the first place is the thing that we really need to be focusing on,â€ Miller said. â€œWhat about the next generation or the one after that?â€

results.webTitle: Bitter Orange Tree by Jokha Alharthi review â€“ a life far from home

fields.headline: Bitter Orange Tree by Jokha Alharthi review â€“ a life far from home
fields.trailText: In the followup to the International Booker winner Celestial Bodies, a student reflects on her roots in Oman
fields.body:
Celestial Bodies, Jokha Alharthiâ€™s second novel, used four generations of a family in the Gulf state of Oman to gauge breakneck social transformations after the discovery of oil in the 1960s. Published in Arabic in 2010 (a chapter first appeared in English in Banipal magazine the following year), Celestial Bodies won the Omani writer and her translator Marilyn Booth the 2019 International Booker prize. Through the vexed marriages of three sisters related to a slave trader, it explored liberty, patriarchy, and social control over both women and men. It included intriguing glimmers of Omani history, from Bedouin freedoms and anti-colonial insurgence to Indian Ocean trade and modern enslavement â€“ outlawed only in 1970.

Bitter Orange Tree, Alharthiâ€™s third novel, is her second to appear in English and is also translated by Booth. Aided by Boothâ€™s deft touch, some parts affirm the authorâ€™s talent for lyrical shifts between past and present, memory and folklore, oneiric surrealism and grimy realism. Yet structural flaws and an overambitious global reach make for a patchy read.

Alharthi makes lyrical shifts between past and present, memory and folklore, oneiric surrealism and grimy realism

The narrator, Zuhour, is an Omani student in a snowy British city (Alharthi studied at Edinburgh), who is pitched into gloom by guilt-laden grief over an adoptive grandmother, who died soon after she left, and an unhappy elder sister she has left behind. Isolated in an alien tongue, or as she awkwardly expresses it, â€œbound to a wheelchair that was languageâ€™s incapacity to fully express meâ€, she fears turning into her mother, whose postnatal depression was never dispelled.

Zuhour retraces the bonds to her homeland, reimagining the life of Bint Aamir, a distant poor relation who cared for Zuhourâ€™s father, and later his children. In the most engaging passages, this grandmotherâ€™s spirit, with her scent of â€œcivet musk, precious aloeswood oil, and ancient soilâ€, emerges in vivid anecdotes. Rebuffing a predatory shopkeeperâ€™s advances, she is a girl with one unsighted eye who toils with the charcoal-makers. She saves up for a fruitless trip on a Bedford truck to consult a missionary doctor, at a time when villagers needed the colonial governorâ€™s permission to venture to Muscat.

Through Bint Aamirâ€™s expulsion from her fatherâ€™s home, and her thwarted dreams of owning an orchard, the novel evokes a history of hunger and sickness after the world wars, when wells dried up and villages emptied. The devastating toll of emigration â€“ a theme shared with Cities of Salt (1984-89), the trenchantly satirical cycle of novels on the rise of an oil-rich desert kingdom by the late Saudi-Jordanian writer Abdelrahman Munif â€“ is here exemplified by Shaykha, a neighbour with dementia who trudges half-naked through the narrow lanes searching for a son who departed 40 years earlier.

Zuhourâ€™s spooling memories of Oman are interspersed with new student friendships, with the vegan American Christine and two Pakistani sisters. Suroor, with â€œjet-black hair rippling down her back and a dazzling smileâ€, was â€œborn in her fatherâ€™s luxurious villa in Karachi, speaking nothing but English all of her carefree lifeâ€. Failing to rise above cliche, her privilege and snobbery are deployed as a crude foil to Bint Aamirâ€™s deprivation. Suroorâ€™s sister Kuhl and Kuhlâ€™s lover Imran, a Pakistani peasant turned scholarship boy whom her family would deem unsuitable, furnish the central plot. When the couple contract a secret mutaa marriage â€“ a temporary liaison deployed more subversively in Hanan al-Shaykhâ€™s 2018 novel The Occasional Virgin â€“ Zuhourâ€™s interest grows, signposting an incipient love triangle.

The narratorâ€™s claim to know Imran better than his lover by virtue of her own vicarious acquaintance with poverty â€“ â€œmy grandmother would have given anything to be a peasant farmerâ€ â€“ is never challenged or qualified. Rather, Zuhour, who â€œmade the imaginary my lifeâ€, assumes an authorial omniscience. When she comments on the loversâ€™ disparate backgrounds that â€œthe weave of his trousers was not spun along with the weave of her skirt, and so it all unravelledâ€, the distance between author and narrator dissolves, and with it, the tension in the plot.

At times, the narratorâ€™s projected emotions risk obscuring their object. The tale of Bint Aamirâ€™s lost suitor is eloquent enough. But a chapter entitled â€œThe Virginâ€ risks sentimentalising the putative tragic spinster, who â€œleft the world as she lived it â€¦ without a beloved to hold her close â€¦ and never having had children who came out of her own bodyâ€. Kuhlâ€™s mother, a Londoner with frustrated ambitions in the theatre, reluctantly accepted the â€œsanctified status of motherâ€ to gain authority in her husbandâ€™s family. Yet overwrought prose reinforces conventional attitudes to womanhood questioned elsewhere.

The global allusions are as unconvincing. Imran is said, vaguely, to return to his â€œvillage without a name in his Pakistani hinterlandâ€. Zuhour imagines the â€œchild he had been. Barefoot and hungry, coming out of his mud-brick home at dawn.â€ When an Omani moves to â€œthe Congoâ€, his â€œtiger-hunting expeditionsâ€ in the Congolese rainforest might be construed as myth in their misapprehension of African fauna.

Zuhourâ€™s â€œagony of regret and remorseâ€ over Bint Aamir is compounded by sorrow at the fate of her own sister, Sumayya, a â€œdynamoâ€ stilled by a brutal husband. Yet, like several other episodes in this uneven novel, Sumayyaâ€™s numb revenge at an Omani beauty spot appears to be a fine short story poorly integrated into the whole.

â€¢ Bitter Orange Tree by Jokha Alharthi, translated by Marilyn Booth, is published by Scribner (Â£14.99). To support the Guardian and Observer, order your copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply.

results.webTitle: â€˜Perfect for a caipirinha and sunsetâ€™: readersâ€™ favourite beaches of Portugal

fields.headline: â€˜Perfect for a caipirinha and sunsetâ€™: readersâ€™ favourite beaches of Portugal
fields.trailText: Our tipsters take to the sands, seas and restaurants of exquisite beaches from north of Porto to the island of Madeira
fields.body:
Winning tip: Lazy river, roaring waves, western Algarve

Every time I emerge from the dunes and see the endless expanse of sand along the winding river my heart sings. Praia da Amoreira sits on the Algarveâ€™s wilder, western coastline, near the town of Aljezur but, unlike the regionâ€™s many glorious beaches, this is a beach with a split personality. Set up camp along the broad sandy banks of the Ribeira de Aljezur as it makes its sweeping escape into the Atlantic. An idyllic stroll westward takes you from tranquil cliffside curves out into the roaring force of the Atlantic â€“ a surferâ€™s dream. But the greatest pleasure is the river itself â€“ hop in and let the water gently carry you on a lazy river like no other.
Robin Dear

White sand alcove, south of Lisbon

My favourite beach in the world is Portinho da ArrÃ¡bida near SetÃºbal. This is a small alcove-like beach, south of Lisbon in ArrÃ¡bida national park. Its relative inaccessibility has protected it so far from overcrowding. To reach it you pass through some truly beautiful hilly green scenery. The beach is of fine white sand and thereâ€™s a desert island about 200 metres offshore to swim to. Itâ€™s best in May and June, out of the holiday season.
Pedro Santos

Dramatic cliffs, near Sintra

We love Praia da Adraga on the Atlantic coast, 19km north of Cascais, and easily accessible (by car) from historic Sintra. Itâ€™s a wonderful place to escape the summer crowds. Somewhat more sheltered than nearby Guincho, yet still great for surfers, it combines dramatic cliff scenery and golden sands studded with black volcanic rock formations reminiscent of semi-submerged dragons. Though it feels off the beaten tourist track, thereâ€™s a spacious car park, toilets and showers, a little shop and a delightful restaurant (dine in and takeaway).
RJA

Books and octopus, south of Lisbon

Praia do Carvalhal, near Comporta, is just over an hourâ€™s drive from Lisbon. A family I was staying with drove me there to show me the benefits of not heading for beaches too near the capital. Itâ€™s not usually crowded and has a lovely stretch of white sand curving round a sheltered turquoise sea where you can swim easily. There is even a small library on a rustic terrace where visitors of all nationalities can leave or take beach books, often novels that have been read while sunbathing. Try the seafood at the casual restaurant Dinis: itâ€™s run by a fisherman and barefoot waiters will serve you octopus salad and crisp white wines on the beach.
Greta

Take the train to the beach, west of Lisbon

Linha de Cascais is the train line running along the coast from Lisbon to Cascais. Any beach along here is worth visiting but my favourite is Praia das Avencas near Parede station. Named for the medicinal avenca plant (an evergreen fern) that grows there, the beach is tucked away under the cliffs, which providie welcome respite from the afternoon winds. Designated an area of biodiversity, the small beach is a favourite among snorkelers but often goes unnoticed by tourists. For food or drinks, head to Bar das Avencas overlooking the beach â€“ perfect for a caipirinha and sunset.
U Watson

Cable car and a marine reserve, Madeira

In Madeira, an autonomous region of Portugal, there are a vast number of amazing beaches. One that I find is overlooked by most tourists is Praia de Garajau, on the south coast and backed by huge cliffs. The only way you can access the beach is either by cable car or a long walk down a winding road. Once down there, Garajau offers tranquil views with breathtaking blue waters contrasted against the grey stone beach. Itâ€™s also a natural marine reserve with a vast number of fish species.
Jonathan Bernardino

Surfing for doughnuts, western Algarve

Praia do Amado is a stunning beach in the western Algarve, a 40-minute drive from the popular city of Lagos. This beach can be hard to find however, as the signposts guiding to it have been smothered in stickers by surfers who wish to There is a surf school on the beach for newbies to try their hand, or for more experienced surfers to brush up on their techniques. The clear waters are surrounded by beautiful cliffs that protect the more relaxed beach-goers from the north wind. To top it all off, beach vendors are never far off, serving delicious hot doughnuts!
Erin Brown

Ah, Armona, eastern Algarve

Related: The real Algarve: â€˜A white-washed village adrift in the kissing seaâ€™

The most wonderful beach Iâ€™ve been to is on Armona Island to the east of OlhÃ£o and part of the Ria Formosa natural park. I visited with some Italian friends while doing an EU Erasmus-funded placement in Seville. OlhÃ£o is easy to reach being near Faro, but you can only get to the island via a few ferry crossings a day, and with no cars on the island, you feel totally cut off from the world. A boardwalk leads to beaches that are wide, windy and deserted. We pottered around on the sand and collected clams, which my friends later cooked with garlic and pasta. You can stay in pastel-coloured beach huts facing the Atlantic, and eat incredible stews with vinho verde at the handful of restaurants. Total holiday bliss.
Sarah Collings

Aquatic pantheon, southern Algarve

The beach at Praia de Benagil is hidden away in a lovely silent cove reached only by rock-hewn steps â€“ get there early and you may have it all to yourself. A short swim away is the Benagil sea cave, a mystical aquatic pantheon with golden sunlight streaming in and bouncing off the red-hued sandstone walls on to a secluded sandy beach. Try the seafood at the family-run Sul Mar restaurant just half a mile away off the M1273 road, well away from the overcrowded eateries closer to the coast.
Nick

What a pleasant fort, north of Porto

Our favourite beach in the north of Portugal is Praia Forte do PaÃ§Ã´, nestled beneath the ruins of an 18th-century fort. This lovely white-sand beach is a short walk through dunes from the car park and sheltered by cliffs and granite boulders. Our children enjoyed the warm natural paddling pools and we braved the Atlantic for a cooler swim. Thereâ€™s a kiosk and a lifeguard from June to mid-September, but this beach is not overcrowded even in midsummer. We took a picnic and played â€œstorming the castleâ€ in the ruins of the fort.
Susanna Callaghan

results.webTitle: â€˜It looks beautifulâ€™: UK gardeners on leaving lawns uncut for No Mow May

fields.headline: â€˜It looks beautifulâ€™: UK gardeners on leaving lawns uncut for No Mow May
fields.trailText: People taking part in Plantlifeâ€™s conservation project say they have seen plants and wildlife thrive
fields.body:
The conservation charity Plantlife again urged people not to mow their gardens in May to help wild plants and pollinators thrive.

As the month draws to a close, we asked some of this yearâ€™s No Mow May participants what new plants and wildlife they have seen in their gardens.

â€˜Itâ€™s nice to know we cater for the butterfliesâ€™ whole life cycleâ€™

I thought I had better practise what I preach as a conservation charity worker. My three-year-old daughter loves the flowers in the garden, even more so when they are visited by butterflies, such as this orange-tip (pictured above). Our lawn is currently a sea of cowslips, but hidden under them, waiting to come into flower are meadow vetchling, yellow rattle, common knapweed, and even common spotted orchids.

We have a second no-mow lawn next to our little allotment. The wetter ground here supports cuckooflower, which is the food plant of orange-tip butterfly caterpillars. We spend many a happy hour searching for the eggs in May and the caterpillars in late June. Itâ€™s nice to know we cater for their whole life cycle, rather than just feeding the adult butterflies.
Adam Linnet, 35, conservation charity worker, Ipstones, Staffordshire

â€˜People stop to speak to me about my front gardenâ€™

Two years ago, inspired by the No Mow movement, I decided to resow the lawn of my back garden with both grass and clover to increase biodiversity. We also have a front garden that was once a very sad and bare patch of dirt and stones. I threw some wild flower mixes on to the ground, added a few self-seeded plants from the back garden and plants that had outgrown their pots. Even the bin store has a living roof.

Now, the front garden is left to its own devices and is a bountiful haven for birds, small mammals and insects. And I donâ€™t need to mow it! A number of people have stopped to talk to me about the front garden. Most are positive â€“ although one lady seemed to think I had too many weeds.
Sean South, 52, primary school teacher, London

â€˜I use a sickle at dusk, when the bees have gone to bedâ€™

Early in the year, this scene is covered with lesser celandines, primroses, grape hyacinth and dog violets. In early May, this gives way to daisies, bugle and forget-me-nots. All these flowers are useful to early spring bees, of which quite a few species nest in the garden: furrow bees, flower bees, mason bees and mining bees.

Some parts I keep short, using a sickle at dusk when the bees have gone to bed. Some species of mining bee and furrow bee like to nest in shorter grass areas. Despite this being a small garden (10 x 30 metres), the diversity of plant species and vegetation allows insects to thrive: along with the bees, many species of hover fly and wasp, as well as beautiful green rose chafer beetles and scarlet tiger moths.
Martin Dohrn, 65, wildlife film-maker, Bristol

â€˜I am not interested in absurd putting-green perfectionâ€™

I donâ€™t often mow my lawn as I cannot bear to turn the sea of hawkweed, daisies, dandelions and other wild flowers to pulp and convert it into a desert for all the bees and butterflies that thrive there. Then there are creatures like slow worms. It is heartbreaking to come across their remains after being mangled by a strimmer. I recently saw one only a few yards from my lawn, which no doubt froze in terror as the awful noise bore down upon it.

People can call it a â€˜lawnâ€™ in inverted commas if they like; I am not interested in having some absurd putting-green perfection in its place! I have a lovely Austrian scythe which is so peaceful and it is quite enough to keep some paths open.
Peter Finlay, retired church minister, High Corrie, Isle of Arran, Scotland

â€˜The insects and birds bring life to the once dull lawnâ€™

We stopped mowing most of our front lawn about six years ago. That year, we scattered fresh yellow rattle seed sent by my brother from the Yorkshire Dales, which weakened the grass to such an extent that many species of plants and insects have become established. Flowering starts in January with snowdrops, followed by crocus, anemone blanda, primrose, snakeâ€™s head fritillary, cowslip, dead-nettles, cow parsley, red campion, buttercups and daisies, oxeye daisies, yellow rattle, ragwort and many different grasses.

Our most exciting arrivals have been pyramidal orchids and white helleborine, which appeared with no help from us. Bees, flies, butterflies and moths busy themselves among the flowers; the striped caterpillars of cinnabar moths strip the ragwort leaves; and every summer, two colonies of ants extend their anthills. The insects attract many birds too, bringing even more life to what was once a dull piece of lawn.
Ros Page, retired civil servant, Oxfordshire

â€˜The cats liked playing jungleâ€™

After I stopped mowing, there was a parade of flowers, buttercups, creeping charlie, dandelions and clover. It got to over half a metre high in some places, so I cut the middle of the lawn but left the edges wild all summer. In the end it was nearly a metre high, with amazing wild grasses and flocks of butterflies everywhere.

The cats liked wandering along the little paths I made and playing jungle. Luckily they donâ€™t hunt. Towards the end of the summer, I attacked everything with the lawnmower, but I only have a small mower and it choked up in a couple of minutes. So I had to get some garden clippers to cut it all by hand. The clippers were blunt so in the end I resorted to scissors. I am not sure cutting a long lawn with a pair of scissors is the right look for an experienced gardener, but was a lot of fun.
Jo Burgess, 64, entertainment agent, Exminster, Devon

â€˜We were blessed with this beautiful carpet of daisiesâ€™

We have left our front lawn to its own devices over the past few weeks and were blessed with this beautiful carpet of daisies. We hope it will help support our local bumblebees. Itâ€™s been good to see the number of little insects that fly up from the daisies when I walk across the lawn. Hopefully theyâ€™re helping the small wild birds that are breeding at the moment.

There has been a marked drop in the number of flying insects in Britain over the last decade, even here in beautiful Wiltshire. I hope this will help a little bit. We also now make sure we leave the boundaries pretty wild, knowing that nettles support butterflies. We also leave some rough-and-ready parts of the garden to encourage hedgehogs. I love the idea of No Mow May, and will definitely leave this section of the garden more wild from now on. I think it looks beautiful.
Jemima Harrison, TV producer, Wootton Rivers, Wiltshire

â€˜Weâ€™ve spotted at least four types of waspâ€™

We donâ€™t often mow our lawn, and feel guilty about it. But not this year. Weâ€™ve seen lots of different bumblebees and solitary bees, as well as bees from our neighbourâ€™s hives â€“ we always get a jar of honey or two from them. Weâ€™ve spotted at least four types of wasp and a couple of other types of bees, butterflies â€“ including red admirals, peacocks, cabbage whites, yellow ones with a black spot, Polyommatus icarus, and others I couldnâ€™t identify. Iâ€™ve also seen brown and orange moths, which were possibly Agrotis puta, Ochropleura plecta and others not known.
Tony, north Norfolk

results.webTitle: More Tory MPs call for Boris Johnson to quit over Partygate revelations

fields.headline: More Tory MPs call for Boris Johnson to quit over Partygate revelations
fields.trailText: John Baron and David Simmonds say they have lost confidence in prime minister after Sue Gray report
fields.body:
Boris Johnson has faced two more calls to quit from Tory MPs, as his attempt to move on from the Partygate scandal after Sue Grayâ€™s damning report unravelled.

Backbenchers John Baron and David Simmonds, who is the prime ministerâ€™s constituency neighbour in west London, said they had lost confidence in him after an investigation that confirmed a string of lockdown-busting parties took place in Downing Street.

No 10â€™s chief of staff, Steve Barclay, insisted on Thursday it was only a â€œsmall minorityâ€ of people working in the building who had broken the rules, and added Johnson was not aware of many of the more debauched details that emerged on Wednesday, including wine being spilled up walls, vomiting and a fight.

He said there was a distinction between the alcohol-fuelled leaving dos Johnson attended in No 10 and some of the more raucous events that took place, including the night before Prince Philipâ€™s funeral, that went on until 4am.

â€œThere is a difference between the work exemption that applied that enabled people to work very long hours in Downing Street â€“ and weâ€™re talking about the behaviour of a small minority of people, often when the prime minister wasnâ€™t in the building or late at night,â€ Barclay told BBC Radio 4â€™s Today programme.

Related: Boris Johnson maintains â€˜work eventsâ€™ defence after damning Gray report

He said Johnson thought the leaving dos were permissible because staff were working â€œclosely together for long hoursâ€ and that the prime minister was â€œgoing to events for a short period of time during the working dayâ€.

Barclay defended Johnsonâ€™s decision not to quit in light of the report or being fined by police, saying the prime minister had already â€œtaken actionâ€ by making â€œsignificant changesâ€ to the structure of No 10, including bringing him in as chief of staff.

Asked on LBC why Johnson didnâ€™t investigate the parties after it was discovered some attenders broke his childâ€™s swing in the Downing Street garden, Barclay said it was a â€œgood questionâ€.

But John Baron, the Conservative MP for Basildon and Billericay in Essex since 2001 and a former shadow minister, said he did not believe Johnson was unaware of the â€œshameful pattern of misbehaviour during the pandemic as the rest of us kept to the Covid regulationsâ€.

â€œA bedrock principle of our constitution is that we can trust the responses we receive in parliament to be truthful and accurate,â€ Baron said in a statement.

â€œParliament is the beating heart of our nation. To knowingly mislead it cannot be tolerated, no matter the issue. Whether or not the prime minister is an asset to the party or the country is of less importance.â€

The MP added that the prime minister â€œno longer enjoys my supportâ€ but did not say if he had submitted a no-confidence letter, 54 of which are needed to trigger a vote on Johnsonâ€™s leadership.

Simmonds, the MP for Ruislip, Northwood and Pinner, said it had become clear that â€œwhile the government and our policies enjoy the confidence of the public, the prime minister does notâ€.

He added: â€œIt is time for him to step down so that new leadership can take forward the important work of the government in ensuring that our people and country prosper.â€

Their intervention follows the call of another Tory backbencher, Julian Sturdy, which brings the number of those publicly calling for Johnson to quit since Grayâ€™s report was published to three.


Labour argued the Partygate scandal demonstrated more fundamental issues of trust.

Lisa Nandy, the shadow levelling-up secretary, told BBC Breakfast: â€œThe reason why Partygate matters, the reason why the prime ministerâ€™s behaviour matters, is because if you cannot trust him on this, if you cannot trust a word that he says â€“ and that is abundantly clear from yesterday â€“ how can you trust him when he says that heâ€™s going to step in and help people with what is now a crisis for most businesses and families?

â€œHow can you trust him when he says that heâ€™s going to stand up to Russian aggression in Ukraine?

â€œTrust is the glue that holds up the political system together, and when that trust is gone the whole system collapses, and that is why what is happening at the moment with Partygate is so devastating for most people in this country.â€

Johnson still faces an investigation by the Commons privileges committee into whether he misled parliament by denying on multiple occasions that any rules were broken in No 10.

Chris Bryant, a Labour MP who recused himself from leading the investigation, said the committee would be able to gather evidence, including from cleaners and security staff who were mentioned in the Gray report as having cleaned up wine stains or stumbled across late-night gatherings.

results.webTitle: Bob Dylan rerecords Blowinâ€™ in the Wind for Christieâ€™s auction

fields.headline: Bob Dylan rerecords Blowinâ€™ in the Wind for Christieâ€™s auction
fields.trailText: The sale of a single copy of the recording on a new analogue format developed with collaborator T Bone Burnett is expected to sell for up to Â£1m
fields.body:
Bob Dylan has rerecorded his classic protest song Blowinâ€™ in the Wind for the first time since it was tracked in July 1962. The new version is the debut release for Ionic Original, a new analogue format developed by Dylanâ€™s long-term collaborator T Bone Burnett.

It is also highly exclusive: Ionic will produce one-of-a-kind aluminium discs painted with lacquer that features â€œa spiral etched into it by musicâ€. Only one copy of the Dylan recording will be released, and is set to be auctioned by Christieâ€™s in London on 7 July. It is expected to sell for between Â£600,000 and Â£1m.

Dylan recorded the new version of Blowinâ€™ in the Wind last year, produced by Burnett. â€œSixty years after Bob first wrote and recorded Blowinâ€™ in the Wind, he is giving us a new recording of his song,â€ Burnett said in a press release. â€œOne that is both deeply relevant for our times and resonant with decades of the artistâ€™s life and experience.â€

Blowinâ€™ in the Wind was released on Dylanâ€™s second studio album, The Freewheelinâ€™ Bob Dylan, in May 1963. He had begun playing it a year earlier in Greenwich Village venues and first published the lyrics in Pete Seegerâ€™s Broadside magazine, which was dedicated to folk and topical songs.

In June 1962, the lyrics were published again in Sing Out! magazine accompanied by comments from Dylan reiterating the points made in the song:

There ainâ€™t too much I can say about this song except that the answer is blowing in the wind. It ainâ€™t in no book or movie or TV show or discussion group ... But the only trouble is that no one picks up the answer when it comes down so not too many people get to see and know ... and then it flies away.

It became an anthem of the civil rights movement, admired by artists including Mavis Staples and Sam Cooke, and a modern hymn of sorts, frequently performed in churches.

Critic Janet Maslin described it as one of the songs that established Dylan as â€œthe voice of his generation â€“ someone who implicitly understood how concerned young Americans felt about nuclear disarmament and the growing civil rights movement: his mixture of moral authority and nonconformity was perhaps the most timely of his attributes.â€

Related: Bob Dylan unveils his largest-ever sculpture, of a railway freight car

Ionic Originals claims to be the first major new format in analogue music reproduction in more than seven decades, since the development of the polyvinyl disc replaced shellac records. Peter Klarnet, a senior specialist at Christieâ€™s, called Blowinâ€™ in the Wind â€œone of the most important songs written in the last century â€¦ I very much share T Bone Burnettâ€™s passion for the sonic excellence of analog sound.â€

Dylanâ€™s US tour begins later this month. He will publish a new book, the Philosophy of Modern Song â€“ containing more than 60 essays on songs by artists such as Nina Simone, Hank Williams and Elvis Costello â€“ on 1 November.

results.webTitle: Security warnings at UK nuclear facilities hit 12-year high as inspections fall

fields.headline: Security warnings at UK nuclear facilities hit 12-year high as inspections fall
fields.trailText: Exclusive: Fears over regulatorâ€™s ability to cope with planned expansion in nuclear energy
fields.body:
The number of formal reports documenting security issues at the UKâ€™s civil nuclear facilities has hit its highest level in at least 12 years amid a decline in inspections, the Guardian can reveal.

Experts said the news raised concerns about the regulatorâ€™s capacity to cope with planned expansion in the sector.

A total of 456 incident notification forms documenting security issues at UK nuclear facilities were submitted to the Office for Nuclear Regulation (ONR) over 2021, according to information obtained by the Guardian and the investigative journalism organisation Point Source.

This is 30% higher than the 320 reports filed during the whole of 2020 and more than double the 213 reports that were filed in 2018.

Reported incidents include physical security issues, such as unauthorised people gaining unsupervised access to secure areas, as well as cybersecurity issues such as attacks by malicious software.

Dr Paul Dorfman, the chair of the Nuclear Consulting Group and a former secretary of the governmentâ€™s committee examining radiation risks of internal emitters (Cerrie), said operators and the regulator needed to take action to address the rise in reported incidents.

â€œThe higher number of security issues that we are seeing documented at nuclear facilities is extremely concerning,â€ he said.

â€œThese figures seem to show a relaxation in security standards when it comes to the operation and regulation of sites that have the potential to cause great human and environmental harm.

â€œWhen the stakes are so high, it is important that ONR takes all these security incidents seriously, looks at why they happened, tries to address the relevant issues, and reduces the number of incidents that are occurring.â€

Dorfman added: â€œThe broader picture raises significant concerns about ONRâ€™s technical and human capacity to regulate and monitor what is potentially a very risky industry.

â€œThis is especially concerning in the context of the UKâ€™s ageing nuclear fleet as well as the new-build plans the government is currently pushing.â€

The recent rise in reported security incidents comes ahead of a planned large-scale expansion of the UKâ€™s civil nuclear sector.

Last month, Boris Johnson said nuclear was â€œcoming homeâ€ when he unveiled plans for eight new reactors in the UK.

Johnson has set a target of 25% of electricity coming from nuclear. That means increasing capacity from 7GW to 24GW by 2050, a process that will be overseen by a new body, Great British Nuclear.

During 2021, there was an increase in the number of â€œmoderateâ€ security incidents reported, according to the data obtained from the ONR using freedom of information legislation.

Over the year, a total of 42 security incidents documented were rated as â€œmoderateâ€. This is up from the 24 moderate incidents reported in 2020 and is the highest number recorded in at least 12 years.

Moderate is the second-most severe category and is described by the ONR as an incident where there has been â€œa significant departure from expected standardsâ€.

The rising number of reported security incidents comes amid a decline in the number of security inspections carried out by the regulator.

There are concerns that during 2021 the frequency of nuclear security inspections carried out by the ONR may have fallen to its lowest level in at least four years.

Data obtained in a separate freedom of information request shows that in 2021, up to 17 December, just 136 security inspections had been carried out by the ONR, down from the full-year figure of 144 in 2020 and 169 in 2019.

Information security inspections are among the types to have seen the biggest decline, with only 40 carried out in 2021 up to 17 December, down from 74 over the whole of 2020.

Dorfman said this was particularly worrying, given the growing risk of cyber-attacks on nuclear infrastructure.

â€œThere is no question that nuclear is operating in an increasingly dangerous and unstable world where the threat of state-sponsored or non-state cyber-attacks is increasing,â€ he said.

In a statement, the ONR said: â€œWe welcome the increase in reported events as our analysis indicates that this reflects improvements in security awareness and culture across the industry. The vast majority of reported events (80-90%) are minor breaches of security arrangements, which have been proactively reported to us.â€

The regulator also said it believed its engagement with nuclear operators had increased over recent years despite the decline in official inspections.

It added: â€œThe data we provided under freedom of information law relates only to on-site compliance inspections and does not include other assessment work. This separate regulatory scrutiny, which is not represented in the data, is essential to ensure site security arrangements comply with the law and includes site visits to reinforce regulatory judgments.â€

results.webTitle: Food bank demand for items to eat cold â€˜mind blowingâ€™, says Jack Monroe

fields.headline: Food bank demand for items to eat cold â€˜mind blowingâ€™, says Jack Monroe
fields.trailText: Anti-poverty campaigner says many people cannot afford to turn on the hob because of high energy bills
fields.body:
Jack Monroe, the writer and campaigner, has described as â€œmind blowingâ€ the rising number of food bank users who are asking for items that can be eaten cold because they canâ€™t afford to heat them.

Monroe, a former food bank user who campaigns against poverty and publishes recipes that can be made on a tight budget, said cold foods were becoming a lifeline for families who could not afford to turn on the hob.

â€œPeople are increasingly asking for products that can be eaten cold,â€ Monroe told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme. â€œTheir gas or electric has been cut off, or their energy bills are so high, or theyâ€™re on prepaid metres so theyâ€™re whatâ€™s known as â€˜self-disconnectedâ€™, which is an industry term for: â€˜I donâ€™t have the money to put my heating on.â€™

â€œItâ€™s mind blowing in the scale of it. I donâ€™t have words actually.â€

Monroe said food banks were increasingly in need of canned items as a result. â€œBaked beans, snacks, tin meats, things like spam, tin puddings, tend to be things that get missed out in peopleâ€™s donation list because theyâ€™re not particularly fashionable anymore. But they are really useful ways to get something sort of mildly nutritious inside in a hurry,â€ Monroe explained.

Her comments came as the chancellor, Rishi Sunak, prepared to announce a package of support to help people with rising household bills, including through a windfall tax on energy firms.

Speaking on Thursday morning, the chief executive of Citizens Advice, Dame Clare Moriarty said food bank vouchers had become a fact of life for many households in recent months. She said more people were coming to the consumer charity despite being in work, and many were asking for food vouchers despite never needing them before.

â€œWeâ€™ve got people in this country who cannot put food on the table. They cannot keep the lights on and the heating on,â€ Moriarty told the Today programme.

â€œI was in Hammersmith and Fulham yesterday talking to our advisers, and they are desperately worried about people coming to them who have made sure that theyâ€™re claiming all the income theyâ€™re entitled to, they are living as cheaply as they can, and they still need food bank vouchers.â€

â€œFood bank vouchers are becoming a fact of life â€¦ Itâ€™s not sustainable,â€ Moriarty said.

results.webTitle: Save your breath: traditional Kyrgyz dance helps ease chronic lung disease

fields.headline: Save your breath: traditional Kyrgyz dance helps ease chronic lung disease
fields.trailText: Exercise to help COPD hospital patients is being rolled out across Kyrgyzstan and to neighbouring countries
fields.body:
Every day on the respiratory ward at one of Kyrgyzstanâ€™s biggest hospitals, Aidai Temiraly Kyzy, a 24-year-old nurse, puts on the music and leads her patients in the Kara Jorgo, the national dance of the central Asian country.

This involves a range of body movements and leaves everyone smiling â€“ but Kyzy is not doing it for fun. The session is part of a treatment programme offered to people with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) â€“ a common, preventable and treatable lung condition.

â€œAlmost all patients, before doing this, complain of shortness of breath, a cough and say they have no physical aptitude,â€ she says. â€œBut, even on the second or third day, the improvement is noticeable. Physically, they can do more.

â€œIâ€™ve seen patients with really low mood transform and, by the end, they smile and are so grateful,â€ says Kyzy.

COPD develops from midlife onwards; symptoms include breathlessness, a chronic cough, often with phlegm, and tiredness. It is usually caused by smoking, but also by air pollution. There is no cure, and if left untreated it can lead to premature death. If detected early, it can be treated and managed.

It is one of the top three causes of death worldwide, and 90% of deaths occur in low- and middle-income countries. Globally, there are 3 million deaths a year from COPD but this number is expected to rise to 5.4 million by 2060, according to the latest report from the Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease.

â€œIn Kyrgyzstan, COPD is a very serious problem,â€ says Prof Talant Sooronbaev, director of the National Centre of Cardiology and Internal Medicine, located in Bishkek, the capital city. Although official figures put the prevalence at between 30,000 and 40,000 cases, he cites research that suggests up to 200,000 people, out of a population of about 6.5 million, have the disease.

â€œWe have patients who donâ€™t understand why they have a cough, or problems with breathlessness. They donâ€™t visit health services and remain undiagnosed,â€ he says.

The number of sufferers is expected to rise. Sooronbaev says the country has more than 500,000 smokers, and there is widespread indoor pollution caused by people in mountainous and remote regions heating their homes with wood, dung or coal during long and harsh winters.

Sooronbaev decided to act. Treatment for COPD in many countries involves prescribing oxygen, inhalers and antibiotics, which patients have to buy. In Kyrgyzstan this can cost more than a monthly salary. Sooronbaev and his team started experimenting with pulmonary rehabilitation, a physical exercise programme designed in 2016 for people with lung conditions, as part of an EU-funded research project called Fresh Air.

I didnâ€™t believe it would work. I thought only inhalers or injections could help. But it had a massive impact

Tokhorbek Makeshov, patient

Over the years, the programme has evolved, and incorporated patient feedback. Now it is being adopted by Kyrgyzstanâ€™s health ministry, and is already in place in three hospitals and two GP surgeries. It runs for six weeks, with a couple of two-hour sessions a week. Added to lectures, dietary information and patient support groups is a regime of physical exercise incorporating elements of volleyball â€“ which is popular in Kyrgyzstan â€“ walking, cycling on exercise bikes, and dance. The idea is that patients can continue with what they are taught afterwards at home.

Dr Azamat Akylbekov, a pulmonologist in Bishkek, has seen the transformative effect. â€œI remember one woman who was 63,â€ he says. â€œShe cried because she had severe shortness of breath, coughed all the time, was dependent on oxygen, and took a lot of strong antibiotics and inhalers. She was really depressed.â€

She was invited to take part in the programme and the results surprised him. â€œAfterwards, she was like a flower â€“ she smiled and her body language was more active. That sticks in my mind.â€

Tokhorbek Makeshov, 48, works at an animal market and lives in a village in the Naryn region, 190 miles (300km) from Bishkek. He noticed his health deteriorating in 2015 but thought it was just a smokerâ€™s cough. By 2016, he was coughing up phlegm and becoming increasingly breathless. His GP referred him to hospital in Bishkek where he stayed for 10 days and was diagnosed with COPD.

Related: Big Tobacco is killing the planet with plastics. No smokescreen should be allowed to hide that

The hospital later invited him to take part in the pulmonary rehabilitation programme, which at that time was still part of a research project. He says: â€œI didnâ€™t believe it would work; I thought only inhalers or injections could help. But it was something new â€“ I had nothing to lose.

â€œIt had a massive impact. The rehab didnâ€™t cure me; I still cough and have flare-ups [of COPD] but Iâ€™m more active. I can walk more and do more around the house. I was surprised to see that such simple exercises could improve my respiratory health. My whole outlook changed.â€

Sooronbaev wants pulmonary rehabilitation to be available throughout the country from this year. Patients who have undergone the programme are being trained to teach others, and Sooronbaev and colleagues are due to speak at medical conferences to inform other healthcare professionals about their progress with the programme.

â€œWhen we give patients with COPD medicine and drugs, this is not a real medical service,â€ he says. â€œPulmonary rehabilitation is an important part of treatment. This is why we have plans to extend, and why we will share our experience with neighbouring countries â€“ Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan.â€
