results.webTitle: Penny Wong tells Pacific nations â€˜we have heard youâ€™ as Australia and China battle for influence

fields.headline: Penny Wong tells Pacific nations â€˜we have heard youâ€™ as Australia and China battle for influence
fields.trailText: Foreign minister uses speech in Fiji to declare â€˜this is a different Australian governmentâ€™ that will act responsibly on climate change
fields.body:
The new foreign affairs minister, Penny Wong, has promised to treat Pacific island countries with respect, telling an audience in Fiji that Australia is â€œa partner that doesnâ€™t come with strings attachedâ€ and wonâ€™t â€œimpose unsustainable financial burdensâ€.

Wong promised to respect Pacific priorities and institutions as she set out an implicit contrast with China, which is pursuing a sweeping regional economic and security deal with Pacific nations that would dramatically expand Beijingâ€™s influence and reach into those countries.

When asked on Thursday whether she would actively encourage Pacific island countries to opt out of Chinaâ€™s proposed deal, Wong said each nation would make its own choices â€“ but suggested leaders should think about long-term implications.

â€œWhat we would urge, as Australia, is consideration of where a nation might wish to be in three or five or 10 years,â€ Wong said during an event at the Pacific Islands Forum secretariat in Suva, Fiji.

Related: Deal proposed by China would dramatically expand security influence in Pacific

â€œI always think thatâ€™s a good way to approach big decisions: think about where you might be in a decade.â€

In her first trip to the region since being sworn in as Australiaâ€™s foreign affairs minister on Monday, Wong also vowed to â€œput more energy and resourcesâ€ into the Pacific.

Wong devoted a significant portion of her speech to the climate crisis, which Pacific leaders have repeatedly warned posed an existential threat and must trigger stronger action. The audience included diplomats and officials from across the region.

She said Australia under past governments had â€œneglected its responsibility to act on climateâ€ and showed disrespect to Pacific nations â€“ but she wanted to â€œassure you that we have heard youâ€.

Wong said the election on Saturday showed â€œa huge groundswell of support for taking real action on the climate crisis in Australiaâ€.

She said Labor had promised a 43% cut in emissions by 2030 and net zero by 2050 â€“ and the new government was â€œfirmly committed to making it happenâ€. Those policies would be enshrined in law and submitted to the UN â€œvery soonâ€.

â€œWe will end the climate wars in Australia,â€ Wong said.

â€œThis is a different Australian government and a different Australia, and we will stand shoulder to shoulder with you, our Pacific family, in response to this crisis.â€

Later, when pressed on whether Australia should go further on climate, including curbing coal and gas projects and exports, Wong said the global economy was in transition. She defended her governmentâ€™s policies.

â€œI understand for some people, particularly the younger generation, they donâ€™t want to wait for that transition but we all have to manage that transition responsibly and in a way that enables continued economic prosperity and equity.â€

Wong said she had travelled to Fiji in her fourth day in office â€œto make clear on behalf of the new Australian government and in particular on behalf of the new prime minister, Anthony Albanese, [of] our commitment to youâ€.

â€œWe will listen and we will hear you â€“ your ideas about how we can face our shared challenges and achieve our shared aspirations together,â€ she said in a speech titled A New Era in Australian Engagement in the Pacific.

In a nod to the growing strategic competition in the Pacific, Wong said the region had â€œnot faced a more vexing set of circumstances for decadesâ€.

Wong said Australia would â€œdraw on all elements of our relationships to achieve our shared interests in building a stable and prosperous region, where rules and sovereignty are respectedâ€.

â€œThe triple challenges of climate, Covid and strategic contest will challenge us in new ways,â€ she said.

She said Australia would remain a critical development partner for the Pacific family in the years ahead, and â€œcontribute to the long-term stability and security of the Pacificâ€.

Wongâ€™s trip comes as China proposes a regional deal with 10 Pacific island nations.

The agreement will be discussed by Pacific leaders and Chinaâ€™s foreign minister Wang Yi, who has embarked on a marathon tour of the Pacific, visiting eight countries in 10 days.

A draft of the deal, written in a similar style to the controversial bilateral security deal signed by Solomon Islands and China last month, and a five-year action plan, both of which have been seen by the Guardian, cover a huge range of issues, include trade, financing and investment, tourism and public health.

The arrangement would see a dramatic expansion of Chinaâ€™s engagement with policing in the region, with the draft deal proposing to â€œexpand law enforcement cooperation, jointly combat transnational crime and establish a dialogue mechanism on law enforcement capacity and police cooperationâ€.

China is proposing to hold â€œintermediate and high-level police trainingâ€ for Pacific island countries.

China is hoping the deal will be signed by 10 Pacific countries in Fiji next week when Wang hosts the second China-Pacific foreign ministers meeting.

Wong alluded to Wangâ€™s visit â€“ and a lack of transparency on Beijingâ€™s part â€“ during a question-and-answer session with journalists on Thursday.

â€œI hope that you get the opportunity to ask as many questions of the foreign minister when he comes as you get to ask of me,â€ Wong said, prompting laughter in the room.

Earlier, without directly mentioning China, Wong set out Australiaâ€™s case to be the partner of choice for the region.

â€œAustralia will be a partner that wonâ€™t come with strings attached, nor imposing unsustainable financial burdens,â€ the Australian foreign affairs minister said.

â€œWe are a partner that wonâ€™t erode Pacific priorities or Pacific institutions.

â€œWe believe in transparency. We believe in true partnerships. We will respect Pacific priorities and your institutions. We will support growth and development that is sustainable.â€

Wong said Australiaâ€™s relationship with its Pacific family was not just â€œa suite of initiativesâ€ such as memoranda of understanding (MOUs).

â€œIt canâ€™t be counted only in dollars or MOUs,â€ Wong said.

â€œIt so much more, because nothing will change our geography, our proximity. Nothing will change the fact that our future is intertwined.â€

Related: Five things we learned about Chinaâ€™s ambitions for the Pacific from the leaked deal | Anna Powles

Wong said Albanese looked forward to â€œlistening and contributing positivelyâ€ to the next Pacific Islands Forum leadersâ€™ meeting.

The secretary general of the Pacific Islands Forum, Henry Puna, said he was â€œparticularly heartenedâ€ by the new governmentâ€™s commitment to the Uluru Statement from the Heart and to weave the voices and practices of Indigenous people into Australian diplomacy.

Puna welcomed Australiaâ€™s â€œrecognition of the ongoing climate crisisâ€ and its commitment to work with the Pacific.

â€œMinister, this is an issue so critical for our survival and we cannot settle for anything less than urgent climate action now,â€ he said.

results.webTitle: Zombie workers and sexual hang-ups: how Edvard Munch foresaw our lonely lives â€“ review

fields.headline: Zombie workers and sexual hang-ups: how Edvard Munch foresaw our lonely lives â€“ review
fields.trailText: From the grief of loss to the despair of impotence and the misery of work, the Scandinavian master wallows gloriously in pain, filling the soul with the ecstatic sorrow of his colours
fields.body:
We love anniversaries. This year is being pushed as the centenary of modernism, since The Waste Land and Ulysses were both published in 1922. But Edvard Munch had TS Eliot and James Joyce beat. In 1892, Munch painted the first modernist masterpiece of the city, anticipating their radical visions of urban life by a full three decades. Now that masterpiece, Evening on Karl Johan, has come to Britain as part of a precious loan of incendiary Munchs from a collection in Bergen, Norway.

These people really need to work from home. They come towards us at the close of day, their faces harrowed by the misery of the office or factory. They are ghoulish grey cartoons of loneliness and sadness lit by yellow glowing windows. A woman stares out with white circles for eyes, her pupils shrunk to dots, while a man in a funereal top hat has a shrunken skull-like face, as if modern life has reduced him to one of the walking dead. In fact, they are all workaday zombies, their bodies stunted, their pace robotic, approaching in a single mummified mass.

This is the very alienation Eliot would put into words 30 years later: â€œA crowd flowed over London Bridge, so many, / I had not thought death had undone so many. / Sighs, short and infrequent, were exhaled, / And each man fixed his eyes before his feet.â€ Evening on Karl Johan prophesies the 20th-century city of lonely crowds trudging hopelessly between nowhere and nothing.

If being first means being the best, Munch deserves the title of the first true modernist, making this the movementâ€™s 130th anniversary rather than its 100th. But that is just one way to judge art. What marks out Munch is the authenticity of the pain. Raw as Evening on Karl Johan is, itâ€™s eclipsed by the painting next to it.

By the Deathbed portrays people standing over a childâ€™s motionless body. Their agony is so complete there is hardly anything left of them. The woman closest to us has a mask of whiteness, like a bandage, over her face, leaving just little patches of pink around her eyes. Her features have been destroyed by her loss. Another woman has already gone further, her face just a pale cartoon with dot-eyes. All we can see of the departed is a small thin form under the sheets with lank brown hair. But we see death in the mournersâ€™ black-clad forms. It has entered every fibre of their being. Life has been stolen from them.

Munchâ€™s creamy brown and violet sky, above a dead purple sea, expresses the young man's mood perfectly

It was stolen from Munch as a child, too. This painting remembers the devastating loss of his favourite sister Sophie from tuberculosis, which had already killed his mother. Grief infected how he saw life. TS Eliotâ€™s protagonist in The Love Song of J Alfred Prufrock admits he was â€œnot Prince Hamletâ€ â€“ but the young man in Munchâ€™s painting Melancholy clearly resembles the tragic Scandinavian hero as he broods by the shore, his head resting on his hand in a medieval symbol of melancholia that is as old as the Lewis Chessmen. Munchâ€™s creamy brown and violet sky above a dead purple sea lets you feel his mood for yourself.

That is why it is so special to see Munchâ€™s paintings up close, as opposed to his prints. This show may be modestly scaled, with just 18 paintings, but that is a lot of Munch on canvas â€“ and in this perfectly lit, perfectly spaced exhibition you can get not just an eyeful but a soulful of the ecstatic sorrow of his colours. Munch wallows gloriously in his pain. All that melancholy spills out in his luxurious feel for paint. Among the dark green woods in his huge 1894 canvas Woman in Three Stages is what looks like a big bloodstain: he has hurled red paint at the canvas to create this gash of horror. Or at least thatâ€™s what Iâ€™m assuming happened. Perhaps they should test to see if itâ€™s blood.

As if the overpowering sense of grief wasnâ€™t enough, Munchâ€™s art unashamedly confesses to massive sexual hangups. Thereâ€™s a young man to the right of this work, brooding beside three images of women: one is a dreamer by the shore, another walks wraith-like in the woods, and in the very middle stands a tall naked woman with her head cocked in sexual challenge. Youâ€™d think Munchâ€™s male alter ego would be pleased but he looks wretched. And in Man and Woman, a naked man has his head lowered in despair as he helplessly sits facing his nude girlfriend. This bedroom scene is nothing if not unmanning. Munch clearly identifies with this male ego crushed into impotence by the womanâ€™s nudity. How many artists have been this frank?

Related: Walter Sickert review â€“ serial killer, fantasist or self-hater? This hellish, brilliant show only leaves questions

This exhibition shows how Munch leapt from lovely 1880s post-impressionist scenes â€“ including a portrait of his sister Inger by a misty sea â€“ to his intense, abstract fin de siÃ¨cle images of unveiled emotion, so extreme it seems he is missing a skin. Self-Portrait in the Clinic, painted in 1909, shows why he could not go on like that. Munchâ€™s most expressive period was bought at the expense of traumatic love affairs and alcoholism. In 1908, he had a breakdown and entered a â€œnerve clinicâ€. This painting shows him in recovery: at first sight it may seem a more formal work, with Munch adopting a respectable, serious pose, but then you realise he is actually painting himself trying on this pose, in the uneasy hope he can maintain it from now on. Yet his jacket is a frenzied pattern of purple daubs. Munch canâ€™t forget what he saw when he looked into the bloodstained forest.

  • Edvard Munch: Masterpieces from Bergen is at the Courtauld Gallery, London, 27 May to 4 September.

results.webTitle: Anne Webster will stand for Nationals deputy, saying party needs â€˜not just Queenslandâ€™ leadership

fields.headline: Anne Webster will stand for Nationals deputy, saying party needs â€˜not just Queenslandâ€™ leadership
fields.trailText: Victorian MP says Nats need â€˜reasonable and stable leadershipâ€™ and notes Barnaby Joyceâ€™s description of himself as â€˜polarisingâ€™
fields.body:
Mallee MP Anne Webster will run for the deputy leadership of the National party, acknowledging Barnaby Joyceâ€™s â€œpolarisingâ€ style and urging the party to back â€œstable and reasonableâ€ leadership.

â€œI am definitely sticking my hand up, I have nothing to lose,â€ Webster told Guardian Australia.

Webster said the combination of new MPs and the â€œcaginessâ€ of the existing ones meant she did not know whether she would have support.

In a clear reference to the domination of northern interests in the party, Webster said that all regional electorates needed Nationals leadership representation, â€œnot just Queenslandâ€.

â€œBarnaby has stated that heâ€™s polarising. You know, itâ€™s just who he is,â€ Webster said.

Related: Barnaby Joyce says all is well with the Nationalsâ€™ vote â€“ but a deeper dive suggests thatâ€™s not the case | Gabrielle Chan

â€œNo doubt that has reaped him rewards over time or he wouldnâ€™t continue in that vein. But I think, you know, Australians are sick and tired, they are election-exhausted, theyâ€™re politician-tired, and they do want the country to move forward with some stability.

â€œAnd the Nats have a part to play in that as well, even though weâ€™re in opposition. I think people need to be a little more collaborative, you know, in terms of Coalition.â€

She said while her views might â€œrileâ€ some people who wanted to see the Coalition fall apart, some stability was needed in the next parliament.

â€œI just think that there is work to be done on all of our parts and we need reasonable and stable leadership to do that,â€ Webster said.

â€œIâ€™m not saying that thatâ€™s not possible with the current leadership. But I think that, the reality is that after an election, the Nats always reset leadership.â€

  • Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

Websterâ€™s move may force the hand of the current deputy, David Littleproud, who is yet to declare his leadership intentions.

All positions are spilled as a matter of course in the Nationals party room after an election, and MPs and senators will meet on Monday to vote. Former leader Michael McCormack is considering running again for leadership, as is Gippsland MP Darren Chester. Both McCormack and Chester have been critical of Joyceâ€™s leadership.

Websterâ€™s electorate of Mallee represents one-third of Victoria and she attracted a swing of more than 4% on a two party-preferred basis, though that was off the 2019 base, when there was also a Liberal candidate in the race.

She noted that her Victorian colleague Chester also got a swing towards him, as did Kevin Hogan in his northern NSW electorate of Page, which was devastated by flooding. All three members backed the 2050 net zero target.

Related: New Coalition MP was founding member of club promoting climate science denial

Webster said the swings to more moderate members of the party gave her more confidence.

â€œIt gives us confidence to step up and say, listen, you know, there are things that would help us in the north as well,â€ she said.

Webster pointed out while she did not have a coalmine in her electorate, she had 11 windfarms and 44 solar farms, with more in the planning stage. But she said the marginal seats in Queensland were â€œdriving a lot of the activity in the campaignâ€.

Webster described Matt Canavanâ€™s statement that the net zero 2050 target was dead as â€œprovocativeâ€ and unnecessary, given the party room had â€œbeen there, done thatâ€.

â€œBarnaby said it this last week, you know that weâ€™ll be having the discussion in the party room again. One of my hopes is that we stick with what was agreed to because it matters in the long term,â€ Webster said.

â€œItâ€™s just what can I do to ensure that Malleeâ€™s voices are heard and the people in my electorate and the businesses in my electorate are represented and supported in the best possible way,â€ she said.

Webster said she was by no means â€œa raving climate change enthusiastâ€ but rather a pragmatist.

She said the moratorium on nuclear power should be lifted.

â€œLabor has shown no interest in going down that path. And I believe itâ€™s the most honest conversation to have. You know, if weâ€™re going to be talking clean energy, then letâ€™s really genuinely talk all options.â€

results.webTitle: US referee numbers are plunging and aggression is to blame

fields.headline: US referee numbers are plunging and aggression is to blame
fields.trailText: We all want better officiating. But itâ€™s tough for referees to develop when abuse from players and spectators hound them out of the game
fields.body:
â€œMy three-year-old couldâ€™ve made that call!â€ exclaimed commentator Kaylyn Kyle after an apparent handball wasnâ€™t called at the end of an NWSL Challenge Cup game between OL Reign and the Washington Spirit.

Unfortunately, most three-year-olds who grow up to be soccer fans will be armchair referees rather than being on the field where theyâ€™re actually needed.

Theyâ€™ll grow up to spend their hours on Twitter, dissecting photos and videos often taken from sightlines the actual referee and assistant referees do not have. They will also have far more time to process plays than the officials. And too many of them will grow up to become parents and coaches who prowl sidelines yelling at referees until those officials finally toss aside their whistles and quit.

We all want better referees. But itâ€™s tough for referees to develop when thereâ€™s much more incentive for them to quit than there is for them to stick with it and improve.

Itâ€™s a simple spiral. Referees drop out of the sport, especially after discovering the joys of extra free-time during the pandemic. Less experienced referees fill their spots. Coaches, players and parents harass and abuse the less experienced referees. Then those referees quit. And then the pool of referees drifting upwards to the top level is that much smaller.

Related: Using artificial intelligence to rule on handball is a tantalising possibility | Jonathan Wilson

The story is familiar to players in England, where some semi-professional games are going forward with teenagers and some games below that level have no officials at all. In the US, the shortages are rampant at youth level and can even reach up to MLS Next, Major League Soccerâ€™s academy program, for which some grassroots referees in Virginia have seen urgent calls for help.

In Utah, the state youth association had reached the point of canceling 570 matches and rescheduling more than 1,000 in one season. They sent out an email trying to drum up interest in referee certification. The response was telling.

â€œWe were flooded with responses stating they would never register as referees or allow their children to register because theyâ€™ve seen how horrible the treatment of referees has been, and they refuse to be subjected to it,â€ said Jen Rader, the Utah associationâ€™s marketing and media manager.

The response: A â€zero toleranceâ€ policy on complaining to referees. The name is more draconian than the actual policy, which recognizes the reality of heated competition.

â€œExclamations in the moment are part of the game,â€ the policy states. â€œA â€˜handballâ€™ or â€˜offsideâ€™ as an immediate response to a situation is more than acceptable so long as that exclamation ends there.â€

Coaches and players can still speak respectfully with refs. And if things are unresolved, thereâ€™s a complaint procedure that takes place electronically, not with a barracuda parent going after a terrified teenager.

To an extent, referee shortages arenâ€™t new. Wisconsinâ€™s youth association instituted its own zero tolerance policy in 2015, citing a â€œpersistent shortage of referees.â€ The most recognizable referee in recent history, the imposing Pierluigi Collina, warned in 2017 that soccer may face a global shortage of referees. The National Federation of State High School Associations (NFHS), which oversees all US scholastic sports, launched a recruitment drive in 2017.

But the pandemic has worsened the situation. The US is dealing with labor shortages in many fields, all part of what has been called the Great Resignation, and refereeing is no exception. Spending weekends somewhere other than a soccer field has proven alluring for some, especially when players apparently have pent-up frustration to unleash.

â€œSince the pandemic, I have seen more heated parents, coaches and players than usual,â€ said Janet Campbell, who chairs referee abuse and assault hearings for North Texas Soccer. â€œThey need to settle down and let the children play the game and let the referees do their jobs. They donâ€™t seem to understand that you have to have referees to play the game.â€

And the NFHS, five years after launching that recruitment drive, has had to redouble its efforts after seeing referee numbers drop from about 240,000 to 200,000 in three years.

Wisconsin is now offering financial incentives â€“ paying for certification and uniforms for new refs, then raising game fees paid to referees in fall 2022 â€“ in addition to beefing up its zero tolerance enforcement.

â€œZero tolerance policies continue to be enforced and we are also taking steps to be more transparent back to referees and referee leadership of suspensions and sanctions that have been assessed to show the association is working to curb behavioral issues,â€ said Brandon Wachholz, Wisconsinâ€™s youth referee administrator.

Another factor feeding the frenzy on the sidelines â€“ the US now has no shortage of games on television, which means parents and players witness (and are perhaps tempted to emulate) pundits and the professionals dissenting refereesâ€™ decisions.

And to be sure, sometimes the critics have a point. Though Kyleâ€™s rant of nearly three minutes over what was, at worst, a simple mistake was over the top, NWSL fans canâ€™t be faulted for complaining about a few institutional issues. Namely:

  • The Professional Referee Organization (PRO) assigns NWSL games to Tier B and Tier C referees in their development ladder, multiple tiers below MLS.

  • The league lacks VAR, which might have shed some light on the incident Kyle decried as well as a horror tackle, committed by Washingtonâ€™s Sam Staab, of which the referee didnâ€™t have a clear view â€“ screened, as is so often the case even with top-notch referees, by the defender trailing back to catch the attacker.

  • MLS has some transparency via a weekly YouTube review, while PRO offers a weekly behind-the-scenes look at VAR in MLS.

  • Refs assigned to the league also have a curious aversion to red cards â€“ in 2018, Carli Lloyd and Marta were the only players to be sent off.

Kyle also happened to be on the field for one of the most controversial games in recent international play â€“ a 2012 Olympic semi-final in which her Canadian team suffered two dubious calls in quick succession that allowed the US to get back into the game and eventually march on to the final. That game still elicits strong feelings in Canada. It was also the last major international game officiated by Norwayâ€™s Christina Pedersen, who was just 31 at the time. By the letter of the law, she didnâ€™t even make mistakes â€“ she simply made decisions that arenâ€™t usually made. Fifa and Uefa arenâ€™t prone to announcing that a referee has been removed from the public arena, but whether her disappearance was their decision or Pedersenâ€™s, those two calls were clearly pivotal.

Pedersenâ€™s exit from the international stage also proves that referees are held accountable â€“ in many ways, more than players or coaches are. One bad game or even a couple of simple mistakes can sink a refereeâ€™s career. Players can fill blooper reels and still get called up to national teams. Players, coaches and even commentators can look at a play multiple times and still misunderstand the call. Case in point: On a 2010 World Cup broadcast, Efan Ekoku ranted about what he considered an erroneous offside call, either failing to notice that the attacker was well past the goalkeeper or failing to realize the rules say â€œsecond-to-last opponent,â€ not â€œlast outfield player.â€

And thereâ€™s no shortage of commentators. Ex-players happily line up to take a microphone, not a whistle. Weâ€™ll never hear of a broadcast in which the broadcaster simply couldnâ€™t find anyone willing to take the gig.

But if the referee pool keeps dwindling, plenty of games will go forward without a full officiating crew. Maybe Kyleâ€™s three-year-old should go ahead and sign up now.

results.webTitle: Ancient cypress in Chile may be the worldâ€™s oldest tree, new study suggests

fields.headline: Ancient cypress in Chile may be the worldâ€™s oldest tree, new study suggests
fields.trailText: The tree, in Chileâ€™s Alerce Costero national park, is known as the Great-Grandfather and could be more than 5,000 years old
fields.body:
Scientists in Chile believe that a conifer with a four-metre-thick trunk known as the Great-Grandfather could be the worldâ€™s oldest living tree, beating the current record-holder by more than 600 years.

A new study carried out by Dr Jonathan Barichivich, a Chilean scientist at the Climate and Environmental Sciences Laboratory in Paris, suggests that the tree, a Patagonian cypress, also known as the alerce milenario, could be up to 5,484 years old.

Maisa Rojas, who became Chileâ€™s environment minister in March and is a member of the United Nationsâ€™ Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, hailed the news as a â€œmarvellous scientific discoveryâ€.

Known in Spanish as the alerce, the Patagonian cypress, Fitzroya cupressoides, is a conifer native to Chile and Argentina that belongs to the same family as giant sequoias and redwoods.

Related: â€˜We need politicians and expertsâ€™: how Chile is putting the climate crisis first

They grow incredibly slowly and can reach heights of up to 45 metres (150ft).

In 2020, Barichivich took a bore sample from the Alerce Milenario, a tree he would visit as a child, but the tool he used was not able to reach its core. He then used computer models to factor in environmental factors and random variation to pinpoint its age.

As he has not yet carried out a full count of its growth rings, Barichivich has not formally published his estimate in a journal, although he hopes to do so in the coming months.

If his findings are proven, the Alerce Milenario would outstrip a 4,853-year-old bristlecone pine in California known as Methuselah, and now thought to be the oldest tree, by 600 years.

The Great-Grandfather towers over a cool, humid valley in the Alerce Costero national park, its gnarled crevices sheltering mosses, lichens and other plants.

Visitors are still able to circle its base, which according to Barichivich is causing harm to the tree, along with climate change drying out the area.

Logging plantations cover more than 2.3m hectares of southern Chile, according to the countryâ€™s forestry institute, and cellulose production is a major industry for the country.

Thirsty non-native pine and eucalyptus plantations make up 93% of this total area, threatening Chileâ€™s native species.

Between 1973 and 2011, more than 780,000 hectares of native forest were lost in Chile, and the forestry commission estimates that over the last two decades, between 60,000 and 70,000 hectares or native woodland has been destroyed each year.

results.webTitle: â€˜You have to let the anger goâ€™: Mina Smallman on her daughtersâ€™ murder â€“ and the police who shared photos of the bodies

fields.headline: â€˜You have to let the anger goâ€™: Mina Smallman on her daughtersâ€™ murder â€“ and the police who shared photos of the bodies
fields.trailText: It is nearly two years since Bibaa Henry and Nicole Smallman were killed in a London park and pictures of their bodies were shared by the officers who were supposed to be guarding them. Their mother talks about taking on the Met, and how she carries on in the face of overwhelming grief
fields.body:
Mina Smallmanâ€™s home is idyllic. Overlooking Ramsgate harbour, in Kent, it is bathed in natural light. A sign in the kitchen says: â€œWelcome to Party Palaceâ€. Tiny speakers are embedded in the ceiling from the party days. A gorgeous family photograph is framed on the wall, with her husband, Chris, towering over Mina and her three daughters. â€œWeâ€™ve got lovely memories here with the girls,â€ Mina, 65, tells me.

On 6 June it will be two years since her life was ripped apart. Two of the daughters were murdered by a stranger at Fryent country park in Wembley, north London. Bibaa Henry was a 46-year-old senior social worker, Nicole Smallman a 27-year-old photographer. A group of 10 friends had been celebrating Bibaaâ€™s birthday with a socially distanced picnic in the park â€“ Britain was in lockdown and indoor gatherings were banned. By 12.30am the friends had left, but Bibaa and Nicole stayed on, dancing to music, draped in fairy lights, taking joyous selfies. At 1.05am Nicole sent a text to her boyfriend, Adam Stone, saying she and Bibaa were dancing in a field by themselves.

Soon afterwards they were killed. Danyal Hussein was a 19-year-old satanist who had pledged to â€œperform a minimum of six sacrifices every six months for as long as I am free and physically capableâ€ in exchange for winning the Mega Millions Super Jackpot. He stabbed Bibaa eight times, Nicole 28 times.

Although the women were reported missing at around 5am, the police did not search the park. Instead, the family were left to look themselves. That afternoon, Adam discovered the bodies. Horror soon piled upon horror. Mina was informed that the two police officers designated to guard the crime scene, Deniz Jaffer and Jamie Lewis, had taken photographs of the dead womenâ€™s corpses and posted them on WhatsApp groups, referring to the women as â€œdead birdsâ€. One of the WhatsApp groups, called â€œthe A teamâ€, contained 41 police officers. The other, containing friends of Jaffer, was called â€œCovid cuntsâ€.

With all her remaining strength, Mina took on the Metropolitan police. She was convinced that, had her daughters been white, the police would have searched the park, and Jaffer and Lewis would not have taken the photographs of her daughters. Hearing how the officers violated Bibaa and Nicole, she felt she had lost them for a second time. â€œI hadnâ€™t even imagined what they looked like until we were told the officers had taken photographs. I began to have flashes of what I thought they looked like. Your kids are murdered and then you hear this. In the natural order of things, you would say the kids being murdered is the worst thing. However, when you are hanging on to a life raft, trying to keep yourself together to function, get up, dress, do what youâ€™ve got to do â€¦ when that happened, any reserves that we had were stripped away.â€

Throughout it all, she showed an astonishing dignity and capacity for forgiveness. She forgave the killer because he was obviously sick. And when the two officers were eventually sentenced, last December, to 33 months in jail after pleading guilty to misconduct in public office, she said she was prepared to meet them as part of a restorative justice process.

Yet the horror has not abated. Two weeks ago, she and Chris were in court again to hear the officers unsuccessfully appeal against their sentence. Mina thought the stress would kill her. â€œI had palpitations and my head was pounding. I thought to myself: â€˜Am I going to have a heart attack or a stroke here and now?â€™â€ She was disgusted by the arguments used by their defence: that the photographs were shared only with close friends and would have gone no further; that taking selfies is just what people do nowadays to show what they have been up to. Jafferâ€™s barrister asked how his two teenage daughters would cope when he was in prison, oblivious to the casual cruelty of his question.

She had been prepared to give the officers the benefit of the doubt. Now, she tells me, she has withdrawn her offer to meet them. â€œIf theyâ€™d served their time without complaining, I would understand that they had repented. But when they challenged the sentence I thought that was bullshit.â€ Why had she agreed to meet them originally? â€œIâ€™ve said all along I donâ€™t need to meet with them to bring me peace. I wanted to be a mirror so they can look at the mother of the two girls they took photos of. I froze the request because I donâ€™t want them to use it as part of their defence â€“ â€˜The mother has reached out and weâ€™ve said yeah weâ€™re going to meet her.â€™â€

***

Mina Smallman is as tough as she is warm. She says she had to be to progress as a working-class woman of dual heritage (her mother was Scottish, her father Nigerian). She left school with two CSEs, then returned to do O-levels as a mature student, graduated with a bachelor of education in her early 30s, then taught drama for 15 years. After gaining a degree in contextual theology she was ordained into the Church of England at St Paulâ€™s Cathedral in 2006. In 2013, she became Britainâ€™s first black female archdeacon. Throughout her career she says she experienced misogyny and racism, mainly from privileged white men who questioned her right to a place at the table.

She became part of the establishment, but never stopped challenging it. When she was asked to mentor students from ethnic minorities, she agreed only if she could also mentor the white working-class boys she felt were equally disadvantaged. Later, she introduced unconscious bias training for vicars. She says she has always been able to sniff out institutional bigotry, and never more so than now.

Bibaa (Minaâ€™s daughter from her first marriage, along with her surviving daughter, Monique) was black while Nicole (Minaâ€™s daughter with Chris) was of dual heritage. Smallman believes that they were victims of racial profiling and classism; that the police were not interested in searching for them because Bibaa lived on a notorious estate in Wembley. The former Met chief superintendent Dal Babu supported her, saying: â€œIf this was a 40-year-old professional white woman, I question whether we would have had the delay and difficulties we have had.â€

Mina was furious when the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC) concluded that although the level of service provided to family and friends of the women after their disappearance was â€œunacceptableâ€ (the duty inspector closed the police logs after receiving information about the sistersâ€™ possible whereabouts, while a call handler referred to one of the sisters as a â€œsuspectâ€), it was not a result of bias. â€œI call the IOPC the three blind monkeys â€“ hear no evil, see no evil, speak no evil. Independent? They canâ€™t even investigate the Met without the Met agreeing they can investigate.â€

Chris, a former English teacher, arrives home. He has an Everton shirt on. â€œAs soon as he knows you love footy, youâ€™ve got your old bromance thing going,â€ Mina says. He takes off his trainers. â€œChris, your shoes stink.â€

â€œThe other guys say that, too.â€

They laugh. She asks him to leave the trainers outside.

Chris and Mina have very different coping methods. He keeps himself active with sport and tutoring. She has her faith and activism. So many couples separate after suffering such extreme trauma. How has it affected their relationship? â€œItâ€™s made us closer. Chris and I were good friends before we were a couple.â€ She smiles. Weâ€™re brother/sister, husband/wife, we squabble, weâ€™re real. He doesnâ€™t judge me for the way I grieve and I donâ€™t judge him for the way he grieves. He needs to be out there playing tennis, walking football â€“ he talks to everyone in the street. I retreat. My challenge now is to be out there more.â€

She has just made Two Daughters, a BBC documentary about her life since the girls were murdered. I ask why she has stayed in the public eye. She quotes Emmeline Pankhurst on fighting for womenâ€™s suffrage: â€œYou have to make more noise than anybody else, you have to make yourself more obtrusive than anybody else, you have to fill all the papers more than anybody else.â€ She says there are two Mina Smallmans: one is the activist, the other is the mother. In the documentary, we see a lot of the activist, campaigning about womenâ€™s safety and Black Lives Matter. But in the most devastating scene she howls with grief, inconsolable. This is Mina the mother.

Today, I get to see plenty of the latter. She talks lovingly about her daughters. Bibaa, the oldest, was a pocket-sized dynamo â€“ barely 5ft, stylish, streetwise and a devoted social worker. She had an adult daughter and was about to become a grandmother. Nicole had gone to a performing arts school, was a talented musician and a natural-born hippy. Despite their age difference, Bibaa and Nicole were exceptionally close.

Monique is a personal trainer who lives in Holland. I ask how she is coping. â€œItâ€™s been hard,â€ Mina says. â€œThe first few times she came here, we never talked about it. We couldnâ€™t. The girls used to share a room if they came at the same time. Just by habit, I said: â€˜Your roomâ€™s ready.â€™ The next day I asked how she slept and she said: â€˜I just kept thinking of the times Iâ€™d stayed in this room with Nikki.â€ When Monique visits now, she sleeps in a different room.

The longer I spend with Mina, the more I realise the number of lives devastated by the murders. Minaâ€™s sister, Anne, died soon after her nieces were killed. â€œI think Bibaaâ€™s murder finished her. She was fighting with cancer for five years and she was particularly close to Bibaa. She wanted to talk about her, and I couldnâ€™t do it. I was broken. I couldnâ€™t even go to her funeral because it was only few months after the girlsâ€™. I couldnâ€™t go back there.â€

I ask what life used to be like before the murders. â€œIt wasnâ€™t great. I have battled with my physical and mental health.â€ She was diagnosed with chronic fatigue syndrome and fibromyalgia, and in 2016 took early retirement. But in the months before the girls were killed, she was feeling more positive. â€œI was beginning to come out of the darkness â€¦â€ She trails off, disconsolate.

Once she knew the girls had not been sexually assaulted or tortured, she told the police she did not want to know the details. But they came out at the trials of Hussein and the police officers. â€œWhen your child has been murdered and you have to listen to their last moments â€¦â€ Again, words fail her. â€œHorrific. Horrific.â€

Husseinâ€™s legal team argued that because the officers entered the crime scene to take the photographs, they could have contaminated it. â€œThat sick monster had said he was going to kill six women every six months, so another four women were going to be murdered, and he could have got off because of what those officers did. From my perspective, Iâ€™m thinking we have spared potentially another four families.â€ She pauses. â€œNo thanks to those police officers.â€

The photographer arrives and suddenly the house is busy. As Mina has her photo taken, Chris and I chat. Chris says his daily routine hasnâ€™t changed much since losing Bibaa and Nicole. He tries to keep himself active. â€œIâ€™ve got a good friendship group through walking football. Thatâ€™s been a saviour. Iâ€™m pretty matter of fact as to the way I handle it. Iâ€™m not going into a spiral of emotional despair, which can easily happen. The way I look at it is the girls wouldnâ€™t want me to go into a hole and give up. Theyâ€™d they want me to keep going.â€ Has it been tempting to go in to a hole? â€œNot for me, no. Iâ€™m not a very emotional person. If Everton lose, I get upset!â€

For about five years, he was both father and schoolteacher to Nicole. Was that difficult for her? â€œNo, she loved it!â€ Did she ever call him Dad in class? â€œShe did a couple of times.â€ He smiles at the memory.

Although he is trying his best to get on with life, he says that there are thoughts he canâ€™t get out of his head. â€œItâ€™s all the ifs and buts. Why the fuck did they stay there when everybody else went? Why wasnâ€™t the weather the same as it was the night before, because it had been raining then? It was the one night that was lovely. Itâ€™s all whys and ifs. The thing is it wouldnâ€™t have happened, but Boris said get out, donâ€™t have parties in your house. All those little things you think â€¦â€

Mina returns and he leaves the room to make us a drink. I tell her what Chris said to me about being unemotional and ask if itâ€™s true, or whether he was saying it because he didnâ€™t want to go there. â€œThe second,â€ she says quietly. â€œIf you speak to him about Nikki and Bibaa and what he loved about them, he canâ€™t get through that without crying.â€

I mention that one of the what-ifs he spoke about was lockdown. Mina had earlier told me she can go from nought to 90 in a nanosecond, and now she proves it. Last month the government minister Jacob Rees-Mogg dismissed the Partygate scandal as â€œfluffâ€ and â€œfundamentally trivialâ€, and sheâ€™s still apoplectic. Not least because she keeps thinking how the police would have reacted if his children had gone missing. â€œThe truth is if Bibaa hadnâ€™t had the picnic outside, if she had decided to break the rules, she and Nikki would still be alive. Itâ€™s like how dare you, Rees-Mogg?â€

Without a breath she turns her attention back to the Metropolitan police, which announced last October that it would apologise to the family because its response after Bibaa and Nicole went missing â€œfell shortâ€ and â€œcompounded the distress felt by their loved onesâ€. â€œSay sorry?â€ she fumes. â€œYou know sorry is what you say when you bump into someone in the street.â€

Mina finds it difficult to forgive the government hypocrisy or the police officers, but none of her anger is directed at the killer. She pities him. She mentions Gee Walker, the mother of Anthony Walker, who was brutally murdered in an unprovoked racist attack 17 years ago. â€œAfter his murder, she said: â€˜I forgive the killers because my faith tells me I should.â€™ I preached on that, saying this woman is amazing because Iâ€™m not sure I could do it.â€

And has she done? She pauses. â€œYeah, Iâ€™ve forgiven Hussein.â€ Would she meet him? â€œNo, because he clearly isnâ€™t well. Maybe with some therapy support, years later that might be possible.â€

What advice would she give to other people looking to forgive? â€œI would say to someone who has lost their child in extreme circumstances, try to let the anger go. Youâ€™re not letting your loved one down by letting go. If you imagine them looking down, they would be so upset that you have punctuated your life, so the aggressor, the murderer, wins. Let the anger go.â€

Yet still the grief remains overwhelming, and there are times she simply doesnâ€™t want to be here. Has she come close to giving up? â€œAbsolutely,â€ she says. â€œOnly now I canâ€™t take the escape route because I have personally felt how heartbreaking it is. I couldnâ€™t do it to Chris and Monique. Iâ€™ve experienced the loss of my girls, and I would never want to inflict that on Chris and Mon.â€

Weâ€™ve been talking for hours. Mina is exhausted. Chris offers me a lift to the station.

I ask if she has reached a stage where she can wake up and think itâ€™s a lovely day. She has recently been diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder. â€œNo. No. No, I canâ€™t. I donâ€™t go outside. I recently went shopping, and I tried to get back in the house before anybody saw me. I donâ€™t know why â€“ our neighbours are amazing.â€

She is finding it easier to get on with her public life as an activist than her private life as a mother. â€œI talk to my counsellor about the mum and the activist, and she said: â€˜Theyâ€™re both you, Mina, you donâ€™t need to separate them.â€™â€ Is she trying to reconcile the two? â€œYeah,â€ she says. But it seems more a question than a statement. â€œAs the activist, I feel totally empowered. But as the mum â€¦â€ She comes to a painful stop. â€œI think Iâ€™m moving forward, but thereâ€™s a lot of work still to be done.â€

â€¢ Two Daughters will air on BBC Two at 9pm on Sunday and be available on iPlayer shortly after broadcast.

â€¢ In the UK and Ireland, Samaritans can be contacted on 116 123, or email jo@samaritans.org or jo@samaritans.ie. In the US, the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is at 800-273-8255 or chat for support. You can also text HOME to 741741 to connect with a crisis text line counselor. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. Other international helplines can be found at befrienders.org

results.webTitle: Millions risk losing US healthcare when Covid emergency declaration expires

fields.headline: Millions risk losing US healthcare when Covid emergency declaration expires
fields.trailText: An estimated 5.3 million to 14.2 million could lose Medicaid coverage when the public health emergency ends in July
fields.body:
When the US federal governmentâ€™s pandemic health emergency declaration expires, millions of Americans are at risk of losing healthcare coverage through Medicaid with potentially devastating consequences.

According to an analysis by the Kaiser Family Foundation, an estimated 5.3 million to 14.2 million could lose their Medicaid coverage when the Covid-19 public health emergency ends on 15 July if it is not extended.

The analysts cited the wide range due to uncertainty on how states will respond to the end of continuous enrollment and how many people will lose coverage as a result. Medicaid enrollment is estimated to reach 110.2 million people by the end of fiscal year 2022, with enrollment expected to decline significantly when continuous enrollment ends.

Dylan Brown of New Jersey is disabled and relies on Medicaid for a home aide he requires around the clock to be able to get out of bed, dress and feed himself. He constantly worries about losing his Medicaid and Social Security disability insurance due to income and asset eligibility requirements and is very concerned about losing Medicaid when continuous enrollment ends.

â€œAs Iâ€™ve been learning, trying to maintain my eligibility, you get a different story every time and you just have to hope one of them is right. And Iâ€™ve sort of been learning, none of them are really right,â€ said Brown.

Without Medicaid, he would have to rely on his parents, who work full-time, to provide the care he needs and pay out of pocket for care to the extent his family could afford it. These options, Brown argued, arenâ€™t feasible as he is planning to start law school this fall at Rutgers University, and his parents shouldnâ€™t have to uproot their lives to help him function, which is the responsibility of Medicaid.

â€œThere shouldnâ€™t be a cutoff date. Thereâ€™s no reasonable argument for not giving disabled people the care they need to survive,â€ added Brown. â€œRegardless of what youâ€™re feeling on whether people should have free healthcare, the disabled need it. There are no alternatives for us. Itâ€™s Medicaid or bust, and when the Medicaid rules are this convoluted and hard to keep track of, it almost feels like a full time job just keeping my benefits.â€

During the pandemic, the federal government required states to continuously enroll Medicaid recipients into the program, providing $100.4 bn in new funds to cover the costs of doing so, halting coverage gaps and loss of eligibility for those who rely on healthcare coverage through Medicaid.

The current pandemic health emergency declaration is set to expire in mid-July. It is expected to be extended again, but an extension date has yet to be set by the US Department of Health and Human Services.

â€œMedicaid provided invaluable coverage to individuals during the pandemic. And thereâ€™s evidence that it helped insulate people from loss of coverage that is associated with job losses, especially in the early stages of the pandemic,â€ said Dr Eric T Roberts, assistant professor of health policy and management at the University of Pittsburgh. â€œNow, we face this unwinding of those provisions and a lot of confusion to beneficiaries and the public about how individuals will navigate that process and the schedule on which they will be required to do so. I think the great concern is that people lose their coverage without really knowing it, until they need it.â€

Roberts said policymakers need to address these problems, as Medicaid determination and redetermination is complex already. Those complexities are magnified when states have to start conducting those determinations on such a large scale without the proper administrative and navigational assistance and resources in place.

â€œThere is already a significant amount of administrative complexity to navigate Medicaid from the beneficiariesâ€™ perspective and that can uniquely disadvantage people who have greater difficulty just navigating the healthcare system in general, the most vulnerable,â€ added Roberts.

Federal government subsidies to make healthcare plans more affordable on the insurance marketplace are expected to end on 31 December 2022, making health insurance plans more expensive, possibbly resulting in more Americans losing health insurance coverage because they canâ€™t afford it.

Zachary Fusfeld of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, a PhD candidate in epidemiology at Drexel University, is anticipating the loss of his Medicaid coverage when continuous enrollment ends, because his university stipend increase will put him over the income limit.

A type one diabetic who suffers from other illnesses, Fusfeld said he will have to rely on his student healthcare and pay out of pocket for copays on medications, medical supplies, and doctor visits when his Medicaid coverage ends later this year, the costs of which are not affordable and not covered by his pay increase.

He recently required surgery on his ankle and is worried about affording the physical therapy he requires, though he noted there are many people who are facing the loss of Medicaid and donâ€™t have any sort of supplemental insurance coverage as he does.

â€œIâ€™m really worried that Iâ€™m just not going to be able to properly manage my health and life in a way that I can stay as healthy as I need to be,â€ said Fusfeld.

Chris Bergh of St Louis, Missouri, relies on Social Security disability insurance for income and Medicaid for medical coverage. Heâ€™s concerned about the risk of losing medical coverage through Medicaid when the pandemic emergency is lifted.

â€œIâ€™m at risk of losing coverage because I lost track of a piece of mail and the instructions in the letter were unclear about how I was supposed to proceed,â€ said Bergh.

He has repeatedly attempted to call Medicaidâ€™s service hotline, but hasnâ€™t been able to get through to speak to an actual person. Without Medicaid, he wouldnâ€™t be able to see his doctors, afford his prescription medicine, or get dental care.

â€œI think they make this system harder than it has to be, in the hopes of weeding people out, just like other public assistance programs,â€ added Bergh. â€œIâ€™m on social security so I have a fixed income and donâ€™t make enough to cover the out of pocket cost of these things and still be able to eat and do other things.â€

results.webTitle: European fishing fleets accused of illegally netting tuna in Indian Ocean

fields.headline: European fishing fleets accused of illegally netting tuna in Indian Ocean
fields.trailText: Reports handed to EU claim vessels likely to have entered coastal statesâ€™ waters where stocks are dwindling
fields.body:
European fishing fleets have been illegally netting tuna from dwindling stocks in the Indian Ocean, according to data presented to EU authorities and analysed by expert groups.

EU purse seine (a type of large net) fishing vessels were present in the waters of Indian Ocean coastal states, where they were likely to have carried out unauthorised catches, and have reported catches in the Chagos archipelago marine protected area and in Mozambiqueâ€™s exclusive economic zone.

Two investigations were made of fishing in the Indian Ocean, one conducted by the group OceanMind and another by the charity Blue Marine Foundation along with Kroll, the corporate investigation company. The first report found evidence, from the publicly available data published by the EU from its fishing fleet from 2016 to 2020, that EU vessels fished without authorisation in the region, where the main catches include the skipjack, bigeye and yellowfin tuna species.

The second report, by Blue Marine Foundation and Kroll, examined data from shipsâ€™ monitoring software, called the automatic identification system (AIS), and found that some vessels in the region had switched it off, which could be an indication of unauthorised fishing.

Populations of tuna are under increasing pressure as industrialised fishing fleets cash in on the growing market for the popular fish. The expansion of tuna fisheries could lead to extinction, scientists have warned.

The latest NGO findings, presented to government representatives at a meeting of the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission in Seychelles this week, highlight the problem of illegal, unreported or unregulated (IUU) fishing around the world, and of EU vessels taking catches from the depleting stocks of developing countries.

The analysts also found instances where vessels had â€œgone darkâ€ â€“ turned off monitoring through the AIS, which transmits a shipâ€™s position and is a safety tool that can also be used to ensure fishers keep within the rules â€“ at key points, suggesting they may have engaged in IUU fishing.

Some EU vessels in the western Indian Ocean went dark for an average of three-quarters of the period from 1 January 2017 to 30 April 2019, according to the Blue Marine Foundation findings.

The Guardian has spoken to a person familiar with the licensing situation, who confirmed EU vessels have had no licences to fish in Somali waters since 2013. Blue Marine Foundation said the Indian authorities also confirmed they had not issued licences to EU vessels.

Anne-France Mattlet, the tuna group director for the EU fishing trade association EuropÃªche, said: â€œThe EU purse seine vessels did not fish in Somalian waters.â€

An official for the European Commission said: â€œThe EU has a strict zero tolerance for IUU. In order to fight IUU in the IOTC convention area, the EU has also tabled a proposal to establish a high-sea boarding and inspection scheme, based on the work already done within the IOTC.

â€œThis would be an important tool to control better the fishing activities in the high seas and continue to fight against IUU fishing. We have also tabled a proposal to improve the traditionally weak IOTC compliance process, by putting more emphasis on the categorisation and follow-up to established situations of non-compliance.â€

The spokesperson said fishing crews may have valid reasons for switching off their AIS technology, and that the transmission power and signal can vary from place to place.

â€œ[Going dark] does not imply that they fish illegally. The AIS might be switched off under certain circumstances by professional judgment of the master,â€ the spokesperson said. â€œThe information given by the AIS may not be a complete picture of the situation in the area and of the vesselâ€™s activity.â€

Charles Clover, the executive director of Blue Marine Foundation, defended its claims. â€œThe report showing the locations of EU vessels is based on the findings of a study commissioned by Blue Marine Foundation and undertaken by OceanMind â€“ a highly reputable organisation â€“ which in turn was based on publicly available data reported by the EU and published by the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission on its website,â€ he said.

â€œThis data shows, for example, evidence of fishing on the part of vessels flagged to Spain in the waters of Somalia, in 2017 and 2018, and India, in 2018 and 2019.â€

He added: â€œThere is evidence to suggest that some of these fleets are fishing in coastal statesâ€™ waters without any kind of authorisation and we call on the European Commission to investigate these instances as a matter of urgency.â€

The Guardian also approached the Spanish government for comment.

results.webTitle: Liberal party should forgo â€˜entitledâ€™ Kooyong voters, says their own state Liberal MP

fields.headline: Liberal party should forgo â€˜entitledâ€™ Kooyong voters, says their own state Liberal MP
fields.trailText: Tim Smith, who is retiring in November, says Coalition needs to â€˜stop obsessing with the woke causes of inner-urban elitesâ€™ and focus on suburbs
fields.body:
The voters of Kooyong in Melbourneâ€™s east have been described as â€œloud, entitled and privilegedâ€ â€“ by their own state Liberal MP.

Victorian Liberal Tim Smith represents the state electorate of Kew, which overlaps the federal seat of Kooyong, where independent Monique Ryan defeated former treasurer Josh Frydenberg in Saturdayâ€™s election.

Writing for Spectator Australia, Smith suggested his seat was a lost cause for the Liberal party, who should forget about winning back heartland inner-city seats for the time being, and instead focus on the suburbs.

Related: Victorian Greens welcome â€˜tealâ€™ independents running in state election after historic federal result

Smith, who will retire at the upcoming state election after crashing his luxury car while under the influence of alcohol, gave his successor little chance of retaining Kew in Novemberâ€™s state election, after three neighbouring electorates were lost to Labor in 2018.

â€œI suspect before this year is out, based on last Saturdayâ€™s results, the Liberals will have no lower house representation at all where the party was founded,â€ he wrote.

While the former shadow attorney general was scathing of the Frydenberg campaign to retain Kooyong and the Coalitionâ€™s campaign messaging generally, Smith also wrote that it was â€œa global phenomenon that wealthy inner-urban elites are voting for the Leftâ€.

â€œThe Liberal campaign in Kooyong had no message, aside from â€˜Keep Joshâ€™, but most importantly it said nothing about what the Liberal party stands for that will improve the lives of the people of Kooyong or anywhere else in the years ahead,â€ he wrote.

This came as Tim Wilson urged his Coalition colleagues not to abandon their position on climate change, telling an industry conference that it was not the main issue that led to their election defeat.

â€œI donâ€™t think we should go backwards on our position and I donâ€™t think anyone seriously is entertaining that,â€ Wilson, who lost his seat of Goldstein to the independent Zoe Daniel, told the National Energy Efficiency Conference in Melbourne on Thursday.

â€œWhere our role has to be is really to give the communities that are represented by the Coalition a voice in the conversation â€“ to make sure that theyâ€™re not lost, because thatâ€™s always been my fear.â€

Wilson said he was concerned the Greens, who could hold the balance of power in the Senate, will dictate the terms of the transition to renewable energy without consideration for outer suburban, regional and rural communities.

â€œI very strongly believe, and still believe, the best way to build that sense of consensus â€¦ [and] support was actually under us because we were the ones that could have the conversations with those communities,â€ he said.

â€œItâ€™s an extreme challenge, and one we should all be excited about, but we shouldnâ€™t be deluded just how much any change of that structural nature can lead to dislocation.â€

He expressed hope that he could continue to be involved in Australiaâ€™s climate and energy debate from outside federal parliament.

Wilson was one of several Liberal MPs who lost blue-ribbon seats to independent candidates, who ran community-backed election campaigns on climate, integrity and gender equity.

But he denied the governmentâ€™s emissions policy, including a target of net zero by 2050 and a 2030 target described as unambitious, led to the losses.

â€œI think there are other issues that played out very strongly in the election, which made it harder for people to win their seats, including myself, which arenâ€™t related to climate change. That doesnâ€™t mean that itâ€™s not an important part of that, but it was a subset of issues,â€ Wilson said.

Amid the fierce debate about the future direction of the Liberal party after their election rout, Smith wrote that the party needed to â€œstop obsessing with the woke causes of inner-urban elitesâ€ and turn its attention to the â€œtrue forgotten peopleâ€ of suburbia and rural Australia.

â€œSwings at this election against Labor in their working-class heartland prove this is where the Liberal party must focus,â€ he wrote.

â€œThese are the Australians who will bear the brunt of what the â€˜tealsâ€™ are demanding in terms of emissions reductions by 2030.

â€œThe people of Kooyong, Wentworth, Goldstein, North Sydney and Mackellar arenâ€™t forgotten or quiet. They are loud, entitled, and privileged.

â€œThe future of the great party that Menzies founded was never about the top end of town. It was and will always be the party of John Howardâ€™s battlers.â€

Smith, who attended Scotch College where annual fees are about $30,000, pointed to the success of the UK prime minister Boris Johnson at breaking down the â€œred wallâ€ by winning working-class seats in northern England.

He lamented that students were being â€œindoctrinated into the new religion of climate change extremism and identity politicsâ€ and called for â€œtrue believersâ€ to lead the party.

Related: Victorian MP booted from Liberal party team after anti-abortion social media posts

Smith described his upcoming departure from state politics as a â€œforced retirementâ€. He was told not to run at the next state poll after last year crashing his Jaguar into a parked car and then into a home in Hawthorn. He returned a blood alcohol reading of 0.131 and resigned from the front bench.

Addressing his constituents last year after the crash, Smith apologised, and vowed not to drink again while in public office.
