Indeed, Kerr himself has had his own battles with Trump and attacked the former presidentâ€™s proposed ban on refugees and travelers from some Muslim-majority countries in 2017.

â€œI would just say that as someone whose family member was a victim of terrorism, having lost my father, if weâ€™re trying to combat terrorism by banishing people from coming to this country, by really going against the principles of what our country is about and creating fear, itâ€™s the wrong way of going about it,â€ said Kerr at the time.

He told me how that desire to listen to players is reciprocated when he is passionate about something like gun control. He told me the Warriors have team discussions, share opinions, learn from each other, and how that benefits them as a team. In that sense, Kerr is treating his team like a second family. â€œInternational issues and societal issues and political views were discussed at the dinner table [when Kerr was growing up],â€ Warriors assistant coach Bruce Fraser told the Guardian in 2018.

Players and coaches supporting each other as they speak out on topics they value is important as they seek to make positive changes in society. And the bond that support creates doesnâ€™t harm their day jobs either: the Warriors are just one win away from the NBA finals and a shot at the fourth championship of Kerrâ€™s reign at Golden State.

  • Etan Thomas played in the NBA from 2000 through 2011. He is a published poet, activist and motivational speaker

results.webTitle: Worldâ€™s most violent cities: MedellÃ­n crime surge helps Latin America top list

fields.headline: Worldâ€™s most violent cities: MedellÃ­n crime surge helps Latin America top list
fields.trailText: Region has two-thirds of worldâ€™s most dangerous cities, with BogotÃ¡, Rio, Mexico City and San Salvador also named in study
fields.body:
When police found the body of Marcela Graciano, a 31-year-old Colombian DJ, last Thursday, the brutality of the crime shocked even them. Her body, found in a house in a suburb of MedellÃ­n â€“ Colombiaâ€™s second city â€“ revealed signs of torture and her hands had been tied behind her back.

â€œThe body was in an advanced state of decomposition,â€ the local police chief, Col Rolfy Mauricio JimÃ©nez, said. The Valle de AburrÃ¡ municipality has had 11 murders this year, authorities said.

Gracianoâ€™s brutal killing marks part of a wider surge of crime across Latin America and the Caribbean, with new research showing that nearly two-thirds of the worldâ€™s most dangerous cities are in Latin America, according to the risk analysis firm Verisk Maplecroft. Kabul in Afghanistan and Mogadishu in Somalia are ranked as the worldâ€™s most dangerous places.

â€œThe regionâ€™s role in the transnational trafficking of narcotics and the continued strength of sophisticated drug-trafficking organisations and gangs is the key factor underpinning Latin Americaâ€™s risk profile,â€ the research, released on Thursday, found.

The study, which used data on crime (such as homicides, theft and property damage), terrorism, civil unrest and conflict, found that eight of the 12 cities that receive the worst possible score are in Latin America.

MedellÃ­n was believed to have turned a corner after being associated with the violence of the 1980s and 90s, when Pablo Escobarâ€™s feared MedellÃ­n cartel ruled swathes of the city and terrorised civilians and the police. But it recorded the highest possible risk score in Verisk Maplecroftâ€™s analysis, alongside San Salvador in El Salvador and Chihuahua in north-west Mexico.

Related: â€˜She represents meâ€™: the black woman making political history in Colombia

â€œMedellÃ­n is a nucleus of transnational crime networks and that is why it shows in this type of study,â€ said Pedro PiedrahÃ­ta Bustamante, a professor of political science at the University of MedellÃ­n, who added that weapons and people willing to use them were in ready supply. â€œThatâ€™s why, despite all the transformations of the last decades, negative indicators of crime persist in the city.â€

Colombiaâ€™s capital, BogotÃ¡, was flagged by Verisk Maplecroft as one of the top three riskiest of the worldâ€™s 30 largest cities, alongside Rio de Janeiro in Brazil and Mexico City.

â€œI see this neighbourhood through different eyes now,â€ said Juana San MartÃ­n, who was recently robbed at knifepoint in BogotÃ¡, outside her home. A friend who was with her at the time was beaten and knocked to the ground. â€œIt leaves you scared. It brings into reality that all these stories you hear about in the news are happening.â€

Cities in Venezuela, which has been racked by widespread crime and political instability, also placed highly, including Barquisimeto, Caracas, Maracaibo, Maracay and Valencia.

Also ranking high on the list is Port-au-Prince, the capital of Haiti, which has been embroiled in gang-related violence for years. The situation in the Caribbean country deteriorated further last year, when the president, Jovenel MoÃ¯se, was assassinated in his home in circumstances that remain murky, leaving a power vacuum that is still violently contested.

Amid a spate of kidnappings, robberies and turf wars, many people have fled their homes for makeshift shelters.

Nearly 150 people have been killed in recent weeks in gunfights between warring gangs in Haiti, while MÃ©decins Sans FrontiÃ¨res (MSF) said earlier this month that it had treated more than 96 people with gunshot wounds in its medical facilities in Port-au-Prince since 24 April.

â€œYou can get killed or kidnapped when you leave your house,â€ Coriolande Auguste, who fled the escalating violence, told the Guardian on a visit to a shelter in the Martissant neighbourhood in the Haitian capital last October. â€œWho wouldnâ€™t want out of this?â€

results.webTitle: Australian hospitals postpone screening tests as world grapples with shortage of imaging dyes

fields.headline: Australian hospitals postpone screening tests as world grapples with shortage of imaging dyes
fields.trailText: Australian Medical Association backs delay of non-urgent tests but says supply issues highlight need for national stockpile of critical medical supplies
fields.body:
Public hospitals in Australia are postponing non-urgent screening tests and are recommending doctors consider alternative imaging options as the health system grapples with a global shortage of medical imaging dyes, widely used in diagnostic tests such as CT scans.

The shortage of medical imaging dyes is further proof Australia needs to develop a national stockpile of critical medical supplies and increase its domestic manufacturing of crucial medicines, the Australian Medical Association has said.

Non-ionic contrast agents, marketed as Omnipaque and Visipaque, are in short supply due to Covid-19 lockdowns in Shanghai, China, where they are produced. They are used in computerised tomography (CT) scans and other medical imaging scans that rely on a contrast agent.

Related: Deaths from drug use rose in first year of pandemic to rate not seen since Australiaâ€™s late 1990s peak

Public hospitals in Australia have already implemented rationing measures, including postponing non-urgent screening tests and recommending doctors consider alternative imaging options that do not require contrast dyes.

The Australian Medical Association president, Dr Omar Khorshid, said that while the decision to delay tests was sensible, it could delay the diagnosis of potentially serious conditions.

He urged people to reschedule any delayed routine screening tests as soon as possible.

â€œWhen you postpone thousands of screening tests in people who may present as healthy you are going to miss some serious conditions, and some of them are going to be serious illnesses that may otherwise have been diagnosed early,â€ he said.

The dye rationing is expected to be in place until next month, when new deliveries are promised.

  • Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

The largest supplier of contrast dye to Australia, GE Healthcare, has advised the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) that normal supply will resume mid-June.

The TGA on Wednesday announced it had authorised the supply of a contrast dye that is registered overseas but not registered in Australia, until the shortage can be resolved.

If stocks are replenished on schedule there will be minimal impact on patient care, Khorshid, said.

â€œThe shortage is very serious but we have had some notice of it so hospitals were able to implement those rationing measures,â€ Khorshid said.

â€œIf this goes on longer than we thought and if we canâ€™t find alternative supplies then there is a possibility that we could run out and that would be a serious problem.â€

Health departments in Queensland, South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales confirmed they had modified protocols to ensure there are supplies for emergency and acute examinations.

Related: Delayed diagnoses and self-imposed lockdown: Australians living with cancer during Covid

The SA chief medical officer, Dr Michael Cusack, said that may involve â€œperforming CT scans without using a contrast agent where it is appropriate to do soâ€.

â€œClinicians have also been asked to consider alternative imaging options, such as ultrasound, MRI and nuclear medicine when suitable,â€ he said.

The Victorian department of health said doctors had been asked to prioritise â€œthe most clinically urgent casesâ€ but that decisions to delay screenings should be made on an individual not statewide basis.

Delaying elective surgery should be a last resort, it said.

Khorshid said the shortage was a reminder of how vulnerable Australia was to changes in the global supply chain in ensuring it could provide adequate medical care.

â€œWe need a national strategy to ensure supply of crucial medicines and medical supplies,â€ he said.

â€œBecause of just-in-time ordering no one is holding very much of anything, so you can run out very quickly.â€

Khorshid said Australia should increase its domestic manufacturing of crucial medicines or those for which there are only one or two global suppliers, even if that meant an increased cost.

He also said the country should develop a national stockpile of critical medical supplies.

results.webTitle: Persistence pays off for Ben Compton, Kentâ€™s early-season run machine

fields.headline: Persistence pays off for Ben Compton, Kentâ€™s early-season run machine
fields.trailText: A decade of trying to break into the county game was finally rewarded for the opener who is making the most of his belated opportunity
fields.body:
Even Ben Compton doesnâ€™t quite understand whatâ€™s happened in these last few weeks. Talking to him, itâ€™s clear he hasnâ€™t had time to reflect on the run of form thatâ€™s made the Kent opener the leading batsman in the country, and won him a call-up for the County Select XI to play New Zealand on Thursday.

â€œItâ€™s all been so relentless that I donâ€™t think itâ€™s really sunk in,â€ he says. â€œIâ€™ve just been busy trying to stay in the moment.â€ Compton has played nine games in nine weeks, and made 129 against Essex, 104 not out and 115 against Lancashire, 89 against Hampshire, 93 against Yorkshire, 47 and 63 not out against Surrey, 140 and 68 not out against Northants. With 878 County Championship runs at an average of 109 he must worry that if he thinks too hard about it heâ€™ll wake himself up.

Related: The Spin | Cricket stats give us deep joy, but can never reflect the gameâ€™s true drama

This time just last year, Compton was playing for Plumtree in the Nottinghamshire Premier League, against Radcliffe-on-Trent, Cavaliers & Carrington, and Kimberley Institute, picking off runs against club bowlers who had played for a minor county, or had a match or two in first-class cricket. Compton was one of them himself. He came here from South Africa when he was 19. In 10 years of trying to get ahead in English cricket, heâ€™d played five first class matches for Nottinghamshire, when heâ€™d made 98 runs at an average of 14 and a top score of 20.

The rest of the time, Compton was playing for Wimbledon, or Richmond, or Plumtree, or slogging away in the county second XIs. Now heâ€™s taking hundreds off some of the best attacks in the country. â€œI understand it comes across like Iâ€™ve come from nowhere,â€ Compton says, â€œPeople ask me where Iâ€™ve been and I try to explain that I had two-and-half years at Notts and that I was the leading run scorer in the country in second-team cricket for the last couple of years. Itâ€™s just that itâ€™s all been away from first-team level.â€

After Nottinghamshire let Compton go at the end of last summer he went out to play for the Mountaineers in Zimbabwe. Since then heâ€™s made 1,357 first class runs at an average of 97, and another 360 at 52 in one-day cricket. At Nottinghamshire, he had been competing with Haseeb Hameed, who the club had signed at the same time, and he found first-team opportunities were so rare that he â€œfelt like I was batting for my lifeâ€.

Now heâ€™s learned to be more relaxed about it. It helped that Kent, who knew Compton from a spell in their second XI, were so clear about what they wanted from him. They needed a steady left-handed batsman. â€œI canâ€™t promise,â€ he told them, â€œbut I think I can do that for you.â€

You can understand why Compton had felt so desperate at Nottinghamshire. He had been waiting six years for that chance to prove to himself, and everyone else, that he could do it. â€œI knew I wanted to be a pro in England,â€ says Compton. â€œThe dream was there from a young age but what was difficult for me was that I was on the outside for such a long time. Trying to earn an opportunity was something I really found difficult. I just didnâ€™t get a chance.

â€œI was just playing club cricket, trying to show what I could do, and doing a lot of work behind the scenes to make sure that my game was in good order. But the reality is county teams look to recruit from their academies, and as a guy coming from the outside it feels like youâ€™ve sort of got to do twice as well as those guys to get the opportunity.â€

Hampshire gave him a couple of second XI games, so did Durham, but it never led to a contract. A lot of people would have given up. Compton stuck with it â€œbecause I felt very firmly that this was what I wanted to do, but those younger years, 20 to 24 were very tough.â€ He gave himself until he was 26, and the end of the Open University degree he was studying for. In the meanwhile, he survived on what he earned in club cricket, and by coaching. Nottinghamshire got him just in time. When that didnâ€™t work out, he was lucky Kent were smart enough to take a chance on him.

This isnâ€™t just a story about Compton, but about opportunity in English cricket. If you donâ€™t know, or hadnâ€™t already guessed, he is part of one of the great cricketing dynasties. His father, uncle, and great uncle all played first-class cricket, his cousin, Nick, played for England, Somerset, and Middlesex, and his grandfather, Denis, was (of course) one of the greatest batsmen who ever played the game. He died when Ben was three so he only knows him â€œthrough stories, and family chats, or old guys telling me: â€˜Oh I watched your grandfather in 1947â€™â€.

Nick was his role model growing up. Imagine having all that going for you and still finding it so hard to break your way into the game because you didnâ€™t come up through the usual route. Now imagine how much harder again it must be for all the players out there who donâ€™t have one of the most famous names in the sport behind them, or access to a network of family connections, or the ability to support themselves on what they can earn in club cricket. There are a lot of them out there.

Compton has played with and against some himself. â€œI know a lot of guys who decided to move on, lads who ended up out of the sport by 24, when, realistically, the prime years for a batsman start when theyâ€™re 27 and you really begin to understand your game,â€ he says. â€œI always felt like I was doing all the right things, it just wasnâ€™t in the place where people were looking.â€

results.webTitle: My home town doesnâ€™t need a fawning monument to Margaret Thatcher | Frances Ryan

fields.headline: My home town doesnâ€™t need a fawning monument to Margaret Thatcher
fields.trailText: Grantham can do much better than this â€“ an Iron Lady statue facing off with a bronze poll tax protester would be more fitting
fields.body:
You could say I grew up under the shadow of Margaret Thatcher. Raised in Grantham, Lincolnshire, I went to Thatcherâ€™s former primary school, a mix of brick and portable buildings that by the 1990s were a fitting symbol of a decade of her underfunding. I went on to attend her old secondary school, both of us moving from near the street where her father once ran a grocery shop to the opportunity of the leafy state grammar. For seven years, I ate my lunch in the dining hall named after her â€“ and only choked on my sandwich once.

Until this month, though, Grantham noticeably had no monument to Thatcher. You could walk through the town centre and see more charity shops than references to an ex-PM. In contrast, Sir Isaac Newton, who went to school in Grantham, has long been immortalised in brass, and even had the local shopping centre named after him â€“ and no, it doesnâ€™t just sell apples. The storm that has emerged since Thatcherâ€™s long-delayed statue was erected last week is a clear lesson as to why. Within two hours of its installation, a man was seen egging it. The Â£300,000 statue, made by the sculptor Douglas Jennings, had already been rejected by Westminster council in 2018 to stand next to parliament.

Related: Leicester University â€˜does not condoneâ€™ staff member egging Thatcher statue

When Grantham agreed to give the (bronze) iron lady a home, it did so on the quiet; the planned Â£100,000 unveiling ceremony was ditched after a local outcry. The council was so concerned by the prospect of political activists making a pilgrimage for the town, it placed the statue on a 3-metre (10ft) high plinth to make it more difficult for protesters to damage. One desperate local Tory councillor suggested protecting Thatcher from vandals by placing the statue in a pond (this is a sign of respect in Lincolnshire).

You donâ€™t have to be a raging Thatcherite to think there should be a monument to her in her home town. Some argue that Grantham producing Britainâ€™s first female prime minister is something that should be marked with a statue, regardless of the ideology. Thereâ€™s a certain sense in this. The Thatcher exhibition in Granthamâ€™s museum attracts tourists â€“ and their cash â€“ from all over the world and many reportedly long asked why there wasnâ€™t a statue. As Nick Jones, a trustee of the museum told the Guardian: â€œThe primary attraction is Margaret. Iâ€™d like to say itâ€™s the Isaac Newton exhibition, but he doesnâ€™t bring them in.â€ Sure, Newt, you were a key figure in the Enlightenment and helped to give the world infinitesimal calculus but did you ever sell off a nationâ€™s council housing stock?

The problem with the â€œhistorical importanceâ€ argument is that statues are not simply commemorative â€“ they are celebratory. Thatcher, erected 10ft in the air with her lofty gaze presiding over passers-by, has â€“ quite literally â€“ been placed on a pedestal. To be immortalised in bronze is to be given an honour, one that signifies (or at least suggests) local pride in the person and aligns the area with their legacy. Thatâ€™s why the toppling of statues of slave owners became synonymous with the Black Lives Matter movement. The residents of Bristol didnâ€™t want to write these figures out of history â€“ they just didnâ€™t want to carry on lauding them.

Statues are, by definition, static â€“ they take a point of history and freeze it, staying revered and unmoved as societyâ€™s values change. In many ways, they are a particularly conservative snapshot of history, taking the viewpoint of the establishment and promoting it as the final narrative. There is a reason we got a statue of Thatcher and not a striking miner. Thatcher being a woman does not make any of this more progressive â€“ she is immortalised for the high street just as bigots and warmongers are up and down this country.

Granthamâ€™s dilemma over Thatcher in many ways speaks to the bigger question of how towns and residents deal with their complex past. The issue is never confined to the statue itself â€“ itâ€™s about what the statue represents. What is the legacy of the figure and what does the statue symbolise? What is it actually saying? Fairly or not, the style of the Thatcher monument hardly suggests a town ready to come to terms with the reality of her lifeâ€™s work. Her hands clasped piously below her lap and draped in a robe, there hasnâ€™t been a softer portrayal of the iron lady since Meryl Streep won the Oscar. That the local museum â€œcontextualisesâ€ Thatcherâ€™s premiership, including discussing her critics, will mean little to passers-by who see her statue looming over them, like a Midlandsâ€™ Maggie the Redeemer.

I canâ€™t help but think Grantham would be better off pulling down the statue and getting creative. If locals want a traditional monument, a statue of Thatcher facing off with a bronze poll tax protester would be more fitting to her spirit â€“ and faults. Better yet, sell the valuable statue to one of her wealthy admirers and use the cash to open an LGBTQ+ youth centre in her name. A statue that has to be hoisted up and shielded from the publicâ€™s touch is the ultimate example of how far removed monuments are from the communities they claim to be for. Our home town can do better than a fawning statue of Thatcher. Or we will all have egg on our faces.

â€¢ Frances Ryan is a Guardian columnist

  • Do you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a letter of up to 300 words to be considered for publication, email it to us at guardian.letters@theguardian.com

results.webTitle: Big Tobacco is killing the planet with plastics. No smokescreen should be allowed to hide that

fields.headline: Big Tobacco is killing the planet with plastics. No smokescreen should be allowed to hide that
fields.trailText: Greenwashing ploys cannot mask the pollution wreaked both by cigarettes and new nicotine products
fields.body:
The most common source of plastic pollution in our environment is not bottles, plastic bags or food wrappers, but cigarette butts. Smokers stub out nearly 800,000 metric tonnes of cigarettes every year, enough butts to cover New Yorkâ€™s Central Park. They are in every country on the planet, from city streets to rubbish tips, rivers and beaches.

Cigarettes contain single-use plastics because they are engineered and manufactured that way. Butts take a decade to degrade, releasing more than 7,000 toxic chemicals into the environment. Wildlife is also at risk: researchers found partly-digested cigarette butts in 70% of seabirds and 30% of sea turtles sampled for one study.

If cigarettes were treated appropriately as single-use plastics, they could theoretically be banned.

Itâ€™s not just cigarettes leaving a plastic trail. In South Asia, smokeless and chewing forms of tobacco such as gutka and khaini are sold in plastic pouches, millions of which litter the environment.

The industry uses a range of corporate social responsibility initiatives to paint itself green

Vaping, electronic tobacco and nicotine products are creating a new wave of pollution, from the mining of materials for batteries to metal and plastic waste leaching into soil and water. In a report last year, the US Environmental Protection Agency highlighted how lithium ion batteries are entering municipal waste systems as consumers incorrectly dispose of electronic tobacco and nicotine products in the household bin, because theyâ€™re branded â€œdisposableâ€.

The problem is global. Despite pledges from tobacco companies that they will eventually stop selling cigarettes, 6tn are produced every year. And manufacturing, sales and waste from electronic tobacco and nicotine products are increasing globally as tobacco giants seek to replace lost revenue as smokers quit or die.

The industry uses a range of corporate social responsibility initiatives to paint itself green. Clean-ups, anti-littering campaigns and other gestures distract the public. Partnerships with environmental institutes and ministries on reforestation and forest preservation projects mask how growing tobacco crops lead to deforestation and desertification in countries like Brazil and Tanzania.

In Mali and Senegal in west Africa, the industry-led Project Waterfall sought to improve access to water. A similar initiative in Burkina Faso aims to provide drinking water, even though the countryâ€™s laws prohibit tobacco-sponsored initiatives. The last time the government evaluated tobacco use among the population was 2013, when almost one quarter of all men were smokers.

In the US, around a fifth of adults smoke, while slightly less than a fifth of adolescents use e-cigarettes. The tobacco industry has funded conservation organisations that include Keep America Beautiful, the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation and the Center for Watershed Protection.

In the Philippines, where more than 40% of men smoke, the tobacco industry has partnered with government agencies on environmental projects, including a river clean-up and an anti-littering campaign.

If countries have ratified the WHO framework on tobacco control (a global health treaty) â€“ and most have â€“ this type of partnership is in violation. The treaty obliges government not to interact with tobacco companies other than when strictly necessary. This, of course, doesnâ€™t stop tobacco companies from wooing policymakers.

There are two main goals of public relations activities for tobacco companies. The first is that, from a regulatory perspective, they need to be able to manufacture, sell and profit from products that damage the environment. If electronic cigarettes were regulated out of the hands of children, it would not only protect them from addiction, but also protect the environment.

Governments should require the tobacco industry to clean up the waste that results from its products

The second is to portray themselves as sustainable to investors. British American Tobacco has featured on Dow Jones Sustainability Index for 20 years now and Philip Morris on the Climate Disclosure Projectâ€™s A List.

An industry that creates nearly 800,000 metric tonnes of toxic waste a year from cigarette butts sits oddly with environmental sustainability. Thereâ€™s no escaping the reality: tobacco waste continues to accumulate because these addictive products are not environmentally friendly but are designed to hook new customers and perpetuate consumption.

Related: Save your breath: traditional Kyrgyz dance helps ease chronic lung disease

This could change. A UN plastics treaty is on the table, offering a global mechanism to tackle the lifecycle of plastics. Many authorities around the world â€“ including India, Rwanda and the US state of California â€“ have put in place or are considering policies to ban single-use plastics. These policies should include the plastic waste coming from tobacco and nicotine products, including electronic products.

Governments should also require the tobacco industry to clean up the waste that results from its products and pay for the environmental damage. And they can implement the WHO treaty, which has provisions to help governments protect themselves from being the targets of industry-sponsored PR campaigns.

Governments, investors and the global community should refuse to accept the tobacco industryâ€™s greenwashing sleight of hand. Despite sustainability claims, its new portfolio of products could end up further polluting in terms of energy consumption, materials and waste.

Tobacco is killing us and the planet.

Dr Vinayak Prasad is programme manager, WHO Tobacco Free Initiative and
Andy Rowell is senior research fellow, University of Bath Tobacco Control Research Group

results.webTitle: Peter Dutton, a ferocious partisan, is now trying to walk both sides of the street | Katharine Murphy

fields.headline: Peter Dutton, a ferocious partisan, is now trying to walk both sides of the street
fields.trailText: Dutton has a delicate task ahead if he becomes Liberal leader. If he tacks too far right, he could easily split his own party
fields.body:
Last time Peter Dutton wanted to be the leader of the Liberal party, he thought he might smile more.

After the Queenslanderâ€™s right faction moved against Malcolm Turnbull in August 2018, ending a months-long proxy war for the prime ministership between himself and Scott Morrison, Dutton thought heâ€™d have liked to bring asylum seekers back from offshore detention â€œon a charter flight overnightâ€ if he wasnâ€™t constrained by the hardman rules of his portfolio.

During this brief hearts-and-minds tour, to the astonishment of many colleagues, Dutton continued with the extemporising and emoting. He felt consumer energy prices could be lower if he removed the GST from power bills. Bugger the states. Perhaps Australia also needed a royal commission into the power companies.

Related: Peter Dutton pledges to make Liberal party a â€˜broad churchâ€™ as he confirms leadership tilt

The intermittent smiling and the rollercoaster pitch didnâ€™t get him there. Morrison got the numbers, got the prime ministership, won an election, then failed upwards. Last Saturday, the Liberal party was trounced in its progressive metropolitan heartland because the personal brand Morrison cultivated had turned toxic.

If the Liberal party had full control of its destiny, or if there were a suite of viable options, this political movement would not be presenting a fresh leadership team of Dutton and Barnaby Joyce as the answer to Saturdayâ€™s electoral rout, because â€“ how can I put this politely? â€“ that would be nuts.

The next leader of the Liberal party was supposed to be Josh Frydenberg. Dutton would have wanted the opposition leadership, and fought Frydenberg for it, but I strongly suspect Frydenberg would have won. Senior moderates have been steeling themselves for the ascension of Dutton for weeks given the likelihood that Frydenberg would lose Kooyong.

Colleagues have been telling themselves Dutton is more complicated than the performative absurdity he carries on with. Yes, Dutton can be a parody of a hardman, a Saturday Night Live sketch, but heâ€™s actually bright, personable and competent when he clocks off from playing the role of Peter Dutton. Heâ€™s not sneaky. Heâ€™s straightforward.

Colleagues also tell themselves and each other that Dutton will need to refashion himself into a plausible portrait of putative prime ministership, and that will be an automatic stabiliser to any wholesale lurch to the right.

There are a couple of problems with this thesis. The first is this optimism overlooks recent history. Dutton is not going into the prime ministership, where prime ministerial tone is required; heâ€™s going into opposition. The Coalition has craved high visibility contrast in opposition, alpha male swagger, burning the village to save the village.

Perhaps Dutton has the credibility and clout within his faction to repudiate Tony Abbottâ€™s playbook. Anything is possible. But this would be one hell of a shapeshift. Dutton, like Abbott, is a ferocious partisan. This cohort of politician tends to think that ends justify means.

Duttonâ€™s record in public life in fact speaks only to ferocious partisanship: Manchurian candidates, Chinese spy ships, late campaign boat arrivals. This reckless, destructive, self-serving caper might delight 2GB and the Sky News nightshift, but Canberraâ€™s defence and intelligence establishment felt the need to distance themselves from Duttonâ€™s ripping yarns in a way Iâ€™ve not seen in more than two decades of political reporting.

Anthony Albanese did inject an ameliorating character assessment after Dutton finally confirmed on Thursday that his big moment had arrived.

Albanese said Dutton was a trustworthy character; someone who kept counsel when necessary and did what they said they would do â€“ an assessment that rings true. This quality certainly isnâ€™t everything, but it is something in Australiaâ€™s tortured, brutal, half-unhinged politics.

The test will be whether Dutton persists with these positive character traits when heâ€™s on the path to the biggest prize in politics. Dutton has just watched Albanese (the former Tory fighter) win the prime ministership with a political strategy that wasnâ€™t entirely about winner-takes-all. Dutton is human. Perhaps he can learn.

In any case, Duttonâ€™s got a huge job ahead. The remaining Liberal moderates have zero interest in being shackled to a doctrine of numpty populism espoused by the faux everyman of Australiaâ€™s Trump-lite political right â€“ seeing that as a recipe for permanent opposition.

They will want Dutton to grapple with hard electoral arithmetic â€“ the reality that the Liberals canâ€™t lose six or more heartland seats in major cities and then expect to form majority government in the future.

Some rightwingers will want Dutton to push through with the strategy Morrison tried and failed to execute in the 2022 campaign: writing off metropolitan professionals and grabbing outer suburban and regional seats from Labor. Theyâ€™ll think Dutton is a better frontman for that strategy, and thatâ€™s probably right in theory.

Related: Scott Morrison confirms he will remain in politics after election defeat

Dutton will also fancy his capacity to bounce off a new Labor government trying to avoid the crosshairs of a progressive parliament. Duttonâ€™s experience will tell him just as the election of 2022 is a correction to the poll of 2019, 2025 can be a correction to the centrist progressivism of 2022 if Albanese canâ€™t keep his agenda on an even keel.

So thereâ€™s opportunity, and opportunity consistent with Duttonâ€™s political brand. But managerially, Dutton has the significant challenge of keeping his own house in order. The remaining Liberal moderates want to refill the broad church rather than empty it, and if the new leader tacks too far right, he could easily split his own party.

Dutton is opening by trying to walk all sides of the street.

He told his old mate Ray Hadley on Thursday morning: â€œThe Liberal party has to get back to being the Liberal party, the broad church, making sure we represent all Australians but with a particular focus on people out in the suburbs, people who are doing it tough, people who are struggling to fill up the cars at the moment, people who are working hard and getting nowhere.â€

A head pat for the right. A head pat for the left.

Hadley tried to prompt him to declare a side. The Sydney shock jock thought the Liberals under Dutton might be a broad church with â€œa conservative leaningâ€. Dutton didnâ€™t take the bait. He said he was a suburban guy who had remained true to his values, but heâ€™d learned during the Howard era that things worked best when there was a fusion of views between wets and dries.

On Thursday there was no reference to smiling more, or scratch royal commissions into power companies. Dutton said he wasnâ€™t an extreme rightwinger. He wasnâ€™t religious. He was the leader of the Liberal party, not the moderate conservative party or the conservative moderate party.

Duttonâ€™s locution this time was about showing Australian voters the complete character. Leadership furnished that opportunity.

Well, Peter. By all means.

Weâ€™re watching. Bring it on.

results.webTitle: Texas school shooting: gunman was inside for 40 minutes, officials say â€“ updates as they happened

fields.headline: Texas school shooting: gunman was inside for 40 minutes, officials say â€“ updates as they happened
fields.trailText: Texas governor and local officials share more details about the shooting at the Robb elementary school in Uvalde
fields.body:
7.00am BST

Summary

It is the early hours of Thursday morning in Uvalde, where residents are still reeling after Tuesdayâ€™s school shooting.

Here are the latest developments and what we know so far:

  • The young victims have now been identified. A law enforcement official said all victims were in the same fourth-grade classroom at the Robb Elementary School.
  • The 18-year-old gunman charged into one classroom where he barricaded himself by locking the door, forcing a staff member to open the room with a key after Border Patrol agents struggled to breach the classroom door, a law enforcement official familiar with the investigation told the Associated Press. Earlier, Lt. Christopher Olivarez of the Department of Public Safety told CNN the gunman â€œbarricaded himself by locking the door and just started shooting children and teachers that were inside that classroomâ€.
  • About â€œ40 minutes or soâ€ elapsed from when the gunman opened fire on the school security officer and when the Border Patrol team shot him, Department of Public Safety Director Steve McCraw said.
  • Onlookers reportedly urged police officers to charge into the school. Juan Carranza, 24, who saw the scene unfold from outside his house across the street, told the Associated Press he felt arriving officers should have entered the school sooner. Javier Cazares, whose daughter, Jacklyn Cazares, was killed in the attack, said he raced to the school and arrived while police were still massed outside the building. â€œLetâ€™s just rush in because the cops arenâ€™t doing anything like they are supposed to,â€ he recalled. â€œMore could have been done.â€
  • However, US Border Patrol chief Raul Ortiz said agents â€œdidnâ€™t hesitateâ€ when responding to the shooting. â€œThey didnâ€™t hesitate. They came up with a plan. They entered that classroom and they took care of the situation as quickly as they possibly could,â€ he told CNNâ€™s Anderson Cooper.
  • More than 100 federal officers responded to Uvalde school shooting, Ortiz added. â€œWhen it was all said and done, we had over 80 officers immediately on the scene, and then right after that, 150 or so officers converged on this area,â€ he told CNN. Those officers came from several divisions, including the Border Patrol, Air and Marine Operations and Homeland Security Investigations.
  • Before attacking the school, the gunman shot and wounded his grandmother at her home. Neighbours called police when she staggered outside and they saw she had been shot in the face, Texas Department of Public Safety spokesperson Travis Considine said.
  • The gunman sent three online messages in the half-hour before the mass shooting, according to the governor of Texas, Greg Abbot. In the first message, he wrote that he was going to shoot his grandmother. The second message reportedly confirmed that he had shot her and in the last note, sent about 15 minutes before he reached Robb Elementary, he said he was going to shoot up an elementary school.
  • The private, one-to-one messages were sent via Facebook, and were â€œdiscovered after the terrible tragedy,â€ company spokesman Andy Stone said. He said Facebook is cooperating with investigators.
  • The gunman had legally bought the rifle and a second one like it last week, just after his birthday, authorities said.
  • Investigators have so far shed no light on the motive for the attack.
  • Community members attended a prayer vigil Wednesday evening at the Uvalde County Fairplex Arena.
  • Authorities in Texas have called for more armed officers and armed teachers in schools, though Republican leaders have doubled down on their opposition to gun control.
  • The National Rifle Association released a statement describing the shooting as â€œthe act of a lone, deranged criminalâ€ and pledged to â€œredouble our commitment to make our schools secureâ€. The group will gather in Houston for its first annual meeting in three years this weekend.
  • US president Joe Biden said he is â€œsick and tiredâ€ of continued mass shootings in the US and access to military-style weapons for youth. â€œWhen in Godâ€™s name will we do what needs to be done to, not completely stop, but fundamentally change the amount of carnage that goes on in this country.â€ he said. â€œTo state the obvious, Iâ€™m sick and tired, Iâ€™m just sick and tired of what is going on, what continues to go on.â€

Thank you for joining us for todayâ€™s live coverage.

Updated at 7.32am BST

6.49am BST

Hundreds of people gathered at a vigil held on Wednesday night at the Uvalde County Fairplex, a community arena, for the victims of the school shooting.

â€œAmazing Graceâ€ was played during the vigil as members of the community wept and hugged.

6.45am BST

The nearby Donna Independent School District has just released a statement saying it has â€œreceived a credible threat of violence that is currently under investigation.â€

â€œIn light of recent events and in an abundance of caution, we will be be canceling school district-wide and staff will work from home,â€ the statement reads.

The town of Donna is about 300miles south-east of Uvalde.

6.00am BST

Actor Matthew McConaughey, who was born in Uvalde, Texas, has called on Americans to act now to control an â€œepidemicâ€ of mass shootings.

â€œOnce again, we have tragically proven that we are failing to be responsible for the rights our freedoms grant us,â€ McConaughey posted on his Instagram account. â€œWe cannot exhale once again, make excuses, and accept these tragic realities as the status quo.â€

The actor did not describe any specific laws or policies he wants adopted and did not mention gun control.

As Americans, Texans, mothers and fathers, itâ€™s time we re-evaluate,â€ he wrote.

We have to rearrange our values and find a common ground.

This is an epidemic we can control, and whichever side of the aisle we may stand on, we all know we can do better.â€

5.29am BST

The US State Department has said the school shooting in Texas and other mass casualty incidents are hurting Americaâ€™s reputation abroad.

Spokesman Ned Price said Wednesday incidents like these not only cause damage to the US global reputation but also upset and confuse friends and allies who donâ€™t understand how they can continue to happen.

The fact is that what happens in this country is magnified on the world stage,â€ Price told reporters.

And countries around the world, people around the world, are going to fixate on what transpires here â€” oftentimes out of envy, but again thatâ€™s when weâ€™re at our best.â€

Price said the shootings â€œwill have implications for our standingâ€ and the US diplomats posted around the world are â€œvery mindful of that.â€

5.04am BST

Agents â€œdidnâ€™t hesitateâ€ when responding to the shooting, US Border Patrol chief Raul Ortiz has said.

Ortiz said dozens of on-duty and off-duty agents responded to the shooting in Uvalde, Texas, on Tuesday, adding that as soon as officers arrived, â€œthey didnâ€™t hesitate.â€

â€œWe responded from various locations. I had both on-duty, off-duty, folks that were in a training environment all responded to this location,â€ Ortiz said, adding between 80-100 officers responded.

They didnâ€™t hesitate. They came up with a plan. They entered that classroom and they took care of the situation as quickly as they possibly could,â€ Ortiz told CNNâ€™s Anderson Cooper.

Among those who responded were members of the Border Patrol Tactical Unit, or BORTAC, which is a specialised unit made up of highly trained officers that respond to â€œemergent and high-risk incidents,â€ according to the agency.

â€œNothing prepares you for a scene like they saw and witnessed yesterday,â€ Ortiz added.

4.49am BST

The name of another young victim has just been confirmed after family members spoke to the Washington Post.

Tess Marie Mata, 10, was also shot inside the Robb elementary school on Tuesday.

Her sister, Faith Mata, a college student at Texas State University, told the Post that Tess, a fourth-grader, loved TikTok dances, Ariana Grande and the Houston Astros.

The 10-year-old was currently saving money so that the whole family could go to Disney World, Mata said.

â€œMy precious angel you are loved so deeply. In my eyes you are not a victim but a survivor. I love you always and past forever baby sister, may your wings soar higher then you could ever dream,â€ Mata posted on Twitter.

4.09am BST

Gunman barricaded himself in classroom and locked the door, forcing officials to use key

We are receiving a little more information on what occurred when the gunman entered the Robb elementary school on Tuesday.

After entering the building, the 18-year-old is believed to have charged into one classroom where he â€œbarricaded himself by locking the doorâ€ , a law enforcement official has said.

[He] barricaded himself by locking the door and just started shooting children and teachers that were inside that classroom,â€ Lt. Christopher Olivarez of the Department of Public Safety told CNN.

A law enforcement official familiar with the investigation told the Associated Press that Border Patrol agents had trouble breaching the classroom door and had to get a staff member to open the room with a key. The official spoke on the condition of anonymity because he was not authorised to speak publicly about the ongoing investigation.

Department of Public Safety Director Steve McCraw said â€œ40 minutes or soâ€ elapsed from when Ramos opened fire on the school security officer and when the SWAT-like Border Patrol team shot him.

All those killed were in the same classroom, Lt. Christopher Olivarez added.

Updated at 4.33am BST

3.29am BST

Photos have emerged of Uvalde County Sheriff Ruben Nolasco crying during a community gathering at the Uvadle County Fairplex on Wednesday.

The sheriff was comforted by US Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.

3.13am BST

Onlookers urged police to charge into the school - reports

Onlookers reportedly urged police officers to charge into the Robb elementary school where a gunmanâ€™s rampage killed 19 children and two teachers, a witness has told the Associated Press.

Investigators worked to track the massacre that lasted upwards of 40 minutes and ended when the 18-year-old shooter was killed by a Border Patrol team.

â€œGo in there! Go in there!â€ nearby women shouted at the officers soon after the attack began, said Juan Carranza, 24, who saw the scene from outside his house, across the street from Robb Elementary School in the town of Uvalde. Carranza said the officers did not go in.

Carranza told the news agency he felt the officers should have entered the school sooner.

â€œThere were more of them, there was just one of him,â€ he added.

Javier Cazares, whose fourth grade daughter, Jacklyn Cazares, was killed in the attack, said he raced to the school when he heard about the shooting, arriving while police were still massed outside the building.

Upset that police were not moving in, he raised the idea of charging into the school with several other bystanders.

Letâ€™s just rush in because the cops arenâ€™t doing anything like they are supposed to,â€ he said.

More could have been done ... They were unprepared.â€

Updated at 3.41am BST

2.46am BST

results.webTitle: Yoga by Emmanuel CarrÃ¨re review â€“ terror comes from within

fields.headline: Yoga by Emmanuel CarrÃ¨re review â€“ terror comes from within
fields.trailText: From a meditation retreat via the Charlie Hebdo massacre to a catastrophic personal breakdown, this is a devastating portrait of the western capitalist everyman in crisis
fields.body:
Ranging across novels, memoir, experimental biography and true crime, French author Emmanuel CarrÃ¨reâ€™s body of work doggedly problematises the rules by which it is understood. The opening of his nonfiction breakthrough, The Adversary (translated by Linda Coverdale), juxtaposes spree killer Jean-Claude Romand murdering his family with CarrÃ¨re attending a parent-teacher meeting, as if determined to occupy, rather than bridge, the gap between author and subject. His biography of Philip K Dick, I Am Alive and You Are Dead (translated by Timothy Bent), eerily collapses that same distance, constructing for Dick a paranoid inner life so intimate that it feels claustrophobic. Now comes Yoga, with a cast both real and invented.

One way to understand CarrÃ¨reâ€™s oeuvre is to dispense with the idea of him as the author of discrete works. His books, each of which draws on and augments what has gone before, are a single, interrelated project, the subject of which is the project itself â€“ its fraught emergence, its blurred limits.

When we last saw CarrÃ¨re, at the conclusion of The Kingdom, he was on a Christian retreat, finding solace in the ritual washing of a strangerâ€™s feet. The version of him we meet at the start of Yoga is ebullient. The Kingdom was a creative and professional high-water mark. â€œI was full of myself,â€ he says. â€œI was happy. I believed it would last.â€

Heâ€™s also, perhaps, trying to recapture The Kingdomâ€™s alchemy of the personal and spiritual. CarrÃ¨re, we learn, has long been a devotee of yoga and meditation. Now it has occurred to him that the subject would suit â€œa short, unpretentious book in a conversational toneâ€ â€“ one that, given yogaâ€™s popularity, â€œcould sell like hot cakesâ€. On the hunt for material, he signs up for 10 days of silent vipassana meditation, deep in the French heartland.

Initially, that â€œconversational toneâ€ feels almost flippant. Apparently uninterested in differentiation, CarrÃ¨re blitzes â€œeasternâ€ thought into a distinctly beige stew. We get bits of ChÃ¶gyam Trungpa, Patanjali, tai chi, Iyengar yoga. When he first hears the voice of vipassana meditationâ€™s Indian founder, SN Goenka, CarrÃ©re is reminded, distastefully, of â€œthe English of Peter Sellers in The Partyâ€.

CarrÃ¨re, though, is well attuned to his flaws. Directing his attention to the patterns of his breath, he finds a disturbing insight into his mode of being. According to yoga, says CarrÃ¨re, â€œinhaling â€¦ is taking, conquering, appropriating, which I have no problem with at all. In fact, I canâ€™t do anything else â€¦ Exhaling is different. Itâ€™s giving rather than taking, returning rather than keeping. Itâ€™s letting go.â€

From its deceptively glib beginnings, Yogaâ€™s inexorable emotional arc has been obvious

We can glimpse, here, the project CarrÃ¨re envisaged â€“ chatty, replete with bankable insights, destined to sell like hot cakes. It is not to be. When terrorists attack the offices of Charlie Hebdo, killing one of his friends, CarrÃ¨reâ€™s retreat is cut short. Briefly, yet another book seems possible, one hinging on easy oppositions between asceticism and engagement, pacifism and violence. But CarrÃ¨re nods towards the reductive, only to reject it. The Charlie Hebdo attack is not, in fact, Yogaâ€™s defining crisis. Nor is it CarrÃ¨reâ€™s. â€œMy life,â€ he writes, â€œwhich I believed to be so harmonious, so well fortified â€¦ was in fact heading for disaster. And this disaster did not come from external circumstances, cancer, a tsunami or the Kouachi brothers kicking open the door without warning and massacring everyone with Kalashnikovs. No: it came from me.â€

CarrÃ¨re experiences a catastrophic mental breakdown. â€œEverything thatâ€™s ever mattered to me,â€ he says, â€œeverything Iâ€™ve dreamed of, glory and mansions, love and wisdom, has lost all meaning.â€ He doesnâ€™t just want to die, he wants â€œto be dead, to have never existedâ€. At the age of 60, having been happy for a decade, he is diagnosed with bipolar disorder, removed to a secure ward, and subjected to electroconvulsive therapy.

Now CarrÃ¨reâ€™s need to inhale becomes not appropriative, but pained and poignant. Alienated from the person he thought he was, he tries to breathe himself back in. He reads his own psychiatric reports, where his â€œmoral sufferingâ€ moves with terrifying swiftness from â€œsignificantâ€ to â€œintolerableâ€. He goes back over his own work, searching for traces of the mania that was to come. He even reviews a glossy New York Times profile of himself, worrying away at the veneer of professional success, exhuming the personal nadir it thinly conceals.

Related: 97,196 Words by Emmanuel CarrÃ¨re review â€“ essays from a French superstar writer

CarrÃ¨re is drawn as if by sirens to extremes. Desperate for a â€œchance to get away from myselfâ€, he retreats to a Greek island and finds himself teaching a small class of young refugees. From its deceptively glib beginnings, through the shocks and catastrophes that shake it, Yogaâ€™s inexorable emotional arc has been obvious. And yet still the force of its final third, in which a fragile, agonisingly unhealed CarrÃ¨re fills his psychic wound with the wounds of others, borders on the unbearable. One child recounts packing a small bag, alone, knowing he will never return home, and recalls his aunt telling him: â€œStop crying, my boy. In life you have to leave everything, always, and in the end itâ€™s life you have to leave, so thereâ€™s no use crying.â€ Another cannot even verbalise his trauma, and so simply hits his head repeatedly, wordlessly, against the desk. In CarrÃ¨reâ€™s helplessness, his stunned inadequacy, we finally see what he has offered us: not a self-portrait, but a collective one. Here, anatomised, is the white western capitalist everyman â€“ wandering the aisles of the spiritual supermarket, shopping for garishly packaged bliss, in terror of a threat from without, blind to the threat from within, and wholly, tragically incapable of incorporating into his reality the very subject of all the diluted eastern spirituality with which he is so enamoured: the truth of suffering, the crushing inevitability of loss.

â€œLife,â€ CarrÃ¨re observes, â€œis a machine for separating people.â€ What, then, is the machine that brings them together? CarrÃ¨re offers no easy answers. He doesnâ€™t need to. His singular, ever-expanding work, in which one pain need never obscure another, in which truths and half-truths are held not in opposition but in delicate, precarious balance, is an answer in itself.

â€¢ Sam Byersâ€™s Come Join Our Disease is published by Faber. Yoga by Emmanuel CarrÃ¨re, translated by John Lambert, is published by Vintage (Â£16.99). To support The Guardian and Observer, order your copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply

results.webTitle: Shear desperation: low price of wool pushes farmers to opt for moulting sheep

fields.headline: Shear desperation: low price of wool pushes farmers to opt for moulting sheep
fields.trailText: Shearing sheep can cost more than the wool is worth so farmers are switching to breeds that shed their own fleeces
fields.body:
No one shears sheep to sell the wool any more, explains James Edwards, a new-entrant tenant farmer with a flock of more than 1,200 ewes. Instead, most people do it for the sheepâ€™s sake, to get the wool off them.

After decades of wool prices that barely cover the cost of shearing, more and more farmers are seeing wool as an optional extra to the meat that brings in the bulk of their income.

A price crash during the pandemic saw farmers getting an average price of just 32p a kilo for wool. In contrast, a lamb currently has a value of about Â£90-Â£120.

Thatâ€™s why an increasing number of shepherds like Edwards are turning to â€œwool sheddersâ€ â€“ breeds of sheep that shed their own wool. The National Sheep Association (NSA) estimates there could be as many as 500,000 wool-shedding breeding ewes in the UK, out of a total population of 14.5 million.

Edwardsâ€™s wool shedders are exlanas, a breed that has been in development since 2008 and whose name means â€œwithout woolâ€ in Latin.

We bred them to have massive fleeces because of the wool trade. Fast forward to now, itâ€™s simply not worth anything

James Edwards

The wool-shedding trait has its origins in the Wiltshire Horn, a native breed of British sheep that was predominant in the south-west county during the 18th century, before the movement towards increasingly woollier sheep led to a decline in its popularity.

â€œWool is a man-made thing,â€ says Edwards. â€œNaturally, sheep donâ€™t have big woolly fleeces, because there wouldnâ€™t be anybody there to shear them. All forms of early, primitive or wild sheep either shed their wool or it falls out.

â€œWe bred them to have massive fleeces because of the wool trade; that was great, because wool was a fibre that was incredibly popular. Fast forward to now, itâ€™s simply not worth anything.â€

For Edwards, wool-shedding sheep were the only logical choice when he came to building his first flock of 100 sheep with a Â£10,000 bank loan.

â€œWhen I first went into it I didnâ€™t have any sheep. There was no home farm, so I just looked at what I thought made the most sense economically. Wool didnâ€™t feature in that.

â€œI am going to struggle to affect the price I sell a lamb for at the end, but I can affect the costs it takes me to get to the point of sale. By reducing the wool element and the jobs associated with it, I am reducing those costs,â€ says Edwards.

A sheepâ€™s fleece has the potential to be a serious welfare issue for the animal if it is not maintained and shorn every year. Wool-shedding sheep are more resistant to a condition called fly strike â€“ where an animal is eaten alive by maggots that hatch in its fleece.

â€œBecause thereâ€™s no wool, they donâ€™t get struck. Thatâ€™s labour saving: I donâ€™t have to run around all the time, worrying and looking for maggots in sheep. But also, Iâ€™m not using nasty chemical compounds [to treat the animals],â€ says Edwards.

Though recent evidence suggests that wool prices are beginning to recover, they still do not cover the shearing cost for most producers, according to British Wool, which is about Â£1.65 a sheep.

Phil Stocker, chief executive of the NSA, says a wholesale switch to wool-shedding sheep would be a â€œreal shameâ€ because wool is probably one of the â€œmost sustainable fibres in the world, growing naturally on the back of a sheepâ€.

Related: The blind farmer: â€˜Itâ€™s all I ever wanted to do. Now I can help others do itâ€™

However, for Edwards, the growing trend towards wool-shedding sheep is a reflection of modern farming.

â€œThe days of getting up in the morning and spending all day on the farm chasing 300 sheep around are gone to a certain extent,â€ he said. â€œWe work out that a reasonable number of sheep to make a living off is about 1,200 ewes per person.

â€œLike every industry, everyone is trying to work out ways to make yourselves more streamlined and efficient. Removing the wool is a way of doing this.â€

results.webTitle: â€˜Every day was an ethical quandaryâ€™: telling the difficult story of XXXTentacion

fields.headline: â€˜Every day was an ethical quandaryâ€™: telling the difficult story of XXXTentacion
fields.trailText: The late rapper, who was killed at the age of 20, was known for both his captivating music and a history of violence, a troubling legacy explored in a new documentary
fields.body:
In one of many chilling scenes in the XXXTentacion documentary Look at Me, the young musical artist whose real name was Jahseh Onfrey leaves a Florida jail and Googles himself. Itâ€™s March 2017. At the top of the search results is Onfreyâ€™s bio, accompanied with a mugshot from his 2016 arrest for brutally imprisoning and assaulting Geneva Ayala â€“ his girlfriend at the time. The detailed bio, evidence that he made it, has him squealing.

Related: The cult of XXXTentacion: how fans pay tribute to an abusive rapper

While Onfrey was inside for nearly six months without a data plan, a 2015 song he uploaded to SoundCloud called Look at Me went viral alongside that photo of his tatted face, Cruella-styled black-and-blond locks and piercing stare. His raps and rap sheet captivated the internet. His breakout success was immediately and intricately tied up with the horrifying domestic abuse, which, in that moment, didnâ€™t seem to bother Onfrey in the slightest. His celebratory squeal, which the film plays against the haunting and twisted sounds of Look at Me, leaves knots in the stomach.

â€œEvery day was an ethical quandary,â€ says Look at Meâ€™s director, Sabaah Foloyan. Sheâ€™s describing her experience grappling with the legacy left behind by the Billboard-topping artist, who was murdered at 20 during a 2018 gunpoint robbery. Before she got involved, Foloyan says she set her terms with the filmâ€™s producers, who include Onfreyâ€™s mother, Cleo Bernard, and his manager, Solomon Sobande. She said the documentary about the Florida musician would have to honestly confront â€œthe good, the bad and the uglyâ€, including the assault and battery allegations that Onfrey publicly denied while he was alive.

â€œWomen donâ€™t have any incentive to lie about abuse allegations,â€ says Foloyan, declaring a stance thatâ€™s diametrically opposed to all the toxic XXXTentacion stans who trolled and terrorized Ayala on social media, refusing to believe what she endured at Onfreyâ€™s hands. Foloyan says she half-expected Bernard and Sobande to be scared off from her position. Instead, they embraced her take on Onfreyâ€™s story, which isnâ€™t simply about a celebrity behaving badly.

Onfrey was diagnosed bipolar. He struggled with that openly in his music. Fans gravitated towards his vulnerability on hit songs like Sad, which gets into abusive and suicidal thoughts. His social media feed is also a live document of wildly erratic and violent behaviour, tearful pleas for empathy and heartfelt hopes for healing as he passed through various recording studios and detention centres. His is a story about mental illness, a predatory music industry that rewards bad behaviour and a carceral system that stands in the way of healing.

Foloyan is uniquely suited to tell that story. She has been a mental health advocate at the Urban Justice Center and also worked at the Osborne Association, an organisation that assists individuals and families affected by the justice system. She has an intimate understanding of how the criminal justice system exacerbates the countryâ€™s mental health crisis â€“ too many resources are directed towards incarceration instead of assistance and healing.

Look at Me also makes for an interesting follow-up to Foloyanâ€™s first film, Whose Streets?, which was about the protests in Ferguson fafter the shooting death of Michael Brown by police officer Darren Wilson. Whose Streets? homed in on the power social media gave the community to organize and demand justice for a Black teen. Look at Me is about how social media brought out the monster in a Black teen who didnâ€™t have access to the help he needed.

In Look at Meâ€™s early scenes, we see Onfrey as social media savvy in the worst ways. He would live-stream his vicious attacks because he knew they would get people to notice both him and his Soundcloud account. He had his friends create multiple online accounts to engage people in his music and tweak algorithms in his favour. As previously mentioned, his arrest after leaving Ayala battered landed him millions of followers, a new manager and a record deal.

This is also the story of hip-hop. The genre was born to represent, uplift and empower but it also has the tendency to glamorise misogyny and violence.

â€œThese young people are responding to what sells,â€ says Foloyan, explaining that young talents like Onfrey canâ€™t calculate how their contributions affect society. â€œTheyâ€™re responding to what is incentivised on a very basic level. I think itâ€™s a question of who are the adults in the room? â€¦ Who is really profiting off of the way that this culture is shaped? I do think a lot of responsibility needs to be taken by the people who hold structural and trendsetting power.â€

I asked Foloyan how much responsibility falls on Onfreyâ€™s manager, Sobande, who entered the scene while the teen was doing his six-month bid, and whether thereâ€™s something predatory about the documentary he is producing, which could be accused of finding yet another avenue to profit off bad behaviour.

â€œSolomonâ€™s perspective is that he was an advocate for a young man who was really, really troubled and really, really talented,â€ says Foloyan, who adds that she isnâ€™t ready to assign blame to anyone. â€œBut I think that this personâ€™s manager and representative is a part of that overall machine. Solomon came into this situation without really much clout. He was acting out of survival and personal ambition. Thatâ€™s a little bit different than someone who is sitting on top and greenlighting and financing certain things.â€

Foloyanâ€™s refusal to place blame is true to an overall ethos she brings to this conversation. She doesnâ€™t find blame helpful or constructive. She feels the same way about condemnations against Onfrey online, which she likens to posturing rather than problem solving.

â€œWe have an unevolved revenge-based carceral reaction when something bad happens,â€ says Foloyan. â€œWe run to a corner, raise our flag and say, â€˜Iâ€™m on this side. This is what I believe. Look at how right I am.â€™ But what happens in this situation is Geneva was left out to dry. She was unprotected and unsupported, even with all the energy that was put behind canceling him. The energy that was put behind canceling him ended up magnifying him further.

â€œWhat weâ€™re really doing is just consuming peopleâ€™s pain as entertainment,â€ Foloyan adds, acknowledging that this conversation also resonates with the way the public is digesting the Amber Heard and Johnny Depp trial, which has inspired memes and TikTok parodies mocking the former for not being the perfect victim. â€œOur public scrutiny is not always constructive. And I think that itâ€™s more constructive if we were a little bit more curious about our own lives and the people around us. Because we have a situation where survivors are unprotected and unsupported.â€

  • Look at Me: XXXTentacion is now available on Hulu in the US with a UK date to be announced

results.webTitle: Support staff at No 10 â€˜subjected to bullying for yearsâ€™, union claims

fields.headline: Support staff at No 10 â€˜subjected to bullying for yearsâ€™, union claims
fields.trailText: Sue Gray report found cleaners and security guards have been subjected to â€˜lack of respect and poor treatmentâ€™
fields.body:
Support staff at No 10 and the Cabinet Office have been subjected to bullying and harassment for years, according to a union member in Whitehall.

The claim comes after Sue Grayâ€™s report into the Partygate scandal disclosed that cleaners and security guards have been subjected to a â€œlack of respect and poor treatmentâ€, and yet felt â€œunable to raise [this] properlyâ€ with the authorities.

A member of the Public and Commercial Service (PCS) union working in the Cabinet Office said: â€œThe prime ministerâ€™s apology is too little, too late. Thereâ€™s been a culture of bullying, harassment and sexism in No 10 for many years.â€

Incidents recalled to the Guardian by staff include sexually derogatory comments made by senior civil servants about female staff in front of union members; and swearing and drinking alcohol in front of cleaning staff.

In the conclusion of her report, Gray states: â€œI found that some staff had witnessed or been subjected to behaviours at work which they had felt concerned about but at times felt unable to raise properly.

â€œI was made aware of multiple examples of a lack of respect and poor treatment of security and cleaning staff.

â€œThis was unacceptable. I am reassured to see that steps have since been taken to introduce more easily accessible means by which to raise concerns electronically, in person or online, including directly with the permanent secretary in No 10.

â€œI hope that this will truly embed a culture that welcomes and creates opportunities for challenge and speaking up at all levels.â€

Addressing MPs in the Commons, Boris Johnson offered an apology to the security and cleaning staff for their â€œappallingâ€ treatment.

He insisted he had â€œno knowledgeâ€ of such treatment, saying he was â€œsurprised and disappointedâ€ to hear about them.

According to the union member, poor treatment of staff was apparent under his predecessorâ€™s premiership and has continued under Johnson.

â€œIt was going on behind Theresa Mayâ€™s back before he took office, yet he did nothing to address it. His empty words will be no consolation to the hard-working cleaners and security guards who have suffered under his leadership,â€ they said.

A union representing cleaners in other government departments, meanwhile, said it was â€œnot in the least bit surprisedâ€ about the revelations in the Gray report.

â€œWe have many members who work as cleaners and security guards, and these workers face disrespect on a daily basis in offices across London, not just in Downing Street,â€ said Petros Elia, general secretary for the United Voices of World (UVW) union. â€œMost of the cleaners and security guards out there are ethnic minority workers, Black, brown and migrant people, who are disproportionately impacted by poor working conditions and racialised inequalities.â€

The UVWâ€™s members include cleaners at the Ministry of Justice who staged a walkout during the pandemic after the union repeatedly raised concerns over workersâ€™ safety, a lack of PPE and failure to promise full sick pay those who might need to self-isolate.

A Cabinet Office spokesperson said: â€œWe do not tolerate bullying, harassment or discrimination in any form of anyone in our workplaces, whether staff or contractors.

â€œOur latest data shows reported incidents in the civil service have fallen to their lowest recorded level, with a large increase in the number of people who believe appropriate action was taken, but we know there is more work to be done.

â€œThe Diversity and Inclusion Strategy builds on the progress made in recent years by setting out clear and specific actions for departments, including regular reviews of progress and running campaigns across government that support staff in raising concerns.â€

results.webTitle: Anti-vaxxer Canadian ranch retreat has lassoed my Â£2,000

fields.headline: Anti-vaxxer Canadian ranch retreat has lassoed my Â£2,000
fields.trailText: I deferred my holiday because of lockdown but now the owner refuses to accept vaccinated guests â€“ and has kept my money
fields.body:
Before the pandemic, I booked a Â£2,000 retreat, hanging out with horses on a Canadian ranch, for May 2020. When lockdowns began, the ranch informed customers that no refunds would be given but that bookings would be honoured when they were ready and able to travel again. I knew they were a small family business so I accepted that. Now Iâ€™ve received a newsletter stating that vaccinated customers are not welcome as the vaccine could transfer to the animals. The ranch owner declares that we will not receive refunds because the business is â€œnearly bankruptâ€ and suggests we sell our holiday to someone unvaccinated.
JW York

The Equinisity ranch in British Colombia promises a â€œfull immersionâ€ experience with horses that will â€œchange your life foreverâ€ because â€œclearing old energies, opening hearts, and connecting us to one consciousness and higher guidance is what the horses do bestâ€. Itâ€™s a new-age utopia of equine â€œspirit lodgesâ€ and â€œliberty playâ€. The trouble is, thereâ€™s no place for Covid protocols or consumer law. The owner, Liz Mitten Ryan, reckons the vaccine is a â€œbioweapon designed to reduce the population of the unaware and compliantâ€. She is, she says, awaiting the â€œgreat awakeningâ€ when â€œgood will overtake evilâ€. In the meantime, she is unrepentant about pocketing the cash of the customers sheâ€™s banned. â€œMy business has been illegally shut down for two years by government mandates,â€ she told me. â€œWe definitely donâ€™t accept people who have succumbed to the bioweapon depopulation tool and can shed on our sacred land and animals.â€

She repeated her suggestion that you find an unvaccinated person and sell your trip to them. As for how they would cross the border into Canada, where tourists must be fully vaccinated, Mitten Ryan says: â€œWe are encouraging the unvaxed to take advantage of fake vax cards and doctorsâ€™ notes of exemption.â€

Mitten Ryan is entitled to her views on vaccines, but not to ride roughshod over consumer rights. I got in touch with the consumer regulator in British Colombia, Consumer Protection BC, which said that it would consider unresolved complaints about breaches of a consumer contract, although it warned your case was complicated by the fact that you accepted an open-ended deferral. As you paid by debit card you are not protected by section 75 of the Consumer Credit Act, which holds the card issuer jointly liable for a breach of contract. There is a voluntary chargeback scheme for debit-card transactions, but as you paid more than 540 days ago you are out of time to make a claim. The Canadian regulator seems your only hope.
