results.webTitle: Love Island has embraced secondhand clothes? Iâ€™ve spent half my life in charity shops | Chitra Ramaswamy

fields.headline: Love Island has embraced secondhand clothes - if only they understood the joy of a good charity shop
fields.trailText: They are not just the best places to pick up PD James novels or porcelain dogs, but for priceless encounters with strangers, writes Chitra Ramaswamy
fields.body:
I see the makers of Love Island have decided to dress contestants in secondhand clothes from eBay. This counts as good news, sustainability-wise, but I would have been even happier if theyâ€™d gone to the local charity shop.

Iâ€™ve loved a good chazza, as no one in Leith calls it, since I spent most of my childhood getting dragged around them. Coming across one of those rotating bookcases stuffed with Georgette Heyer and PD James paperbacks is a deeply Proustian experience for me. Charity shops are microcosms of our high streets, telling us all we need to know about the cut of a placeâ€™s jib. Anything thatâ€™s kind to the climate and mean to capitalism should be welcomed as warmly as a vintage porcelain boxer dog for Â£3. (No regrets.) There should really be a Great British Charity Shop Off on telly by now.

I love them for their specificity, and the identi-kitsch that lies within: the dressmaking patterns, maps, mugs, dusty glassware, Jamie Oliver cookbooks and James Last records. When I go home to visit my dad and sister in south-west London, itâ€™s all last seasonâ€™s Margaret Howell and, no matter the decade, giant Monsoon dresses. The kind of charity shops Mary Portas once spruced up. Here in Leith, people do their actual shopping in them and as the cost of living crisis deepens, they will be used more. How appalling that it should fall, once again, to charities.

Theyâ€™re also where the best encounters happen. Yesterday I was examining a Count Basie record for scratches in my local British Heart Foundation shop when a middle-aged man tapped me on the shoulder. My first thought was: â€œHE WANTS TO TAKE MY Â£2 COUNT BASIE RECORD! NEVER!â€ Swiftly followed by: â€œHE WANTS TO MANSPLAIN JAZZ TO ME! NEVER!â€ Well, he wanted to let me know that in â€œthe Bethany up the road there are three Basies, rare ones, Â£1.50 eachâ€. He winked at me, told me to â€œgo for it, lassâ€, and we went our separate ways.

results.webTitle: Outrage as NRA to gather in Houston just days after Texas school massacre

fields.headline: Outrage as NRA to gather in Houston just days after Texas school massacre
fields.trailText: Counter-protests expected as about 55,000 NRA members to attend event, including Donald Trump, Ted Cruz and Greg Abbott
fields.body:
Just days after the deadliest mass school shooting in Texas history, the National Rifle Association (NRA) â€“ Americaâ€™s leading gun lobbyist group â€“ will meet a few hours away in Houston on Friday.

Ashton P Woods says they are not welcome in his home town.

â€œThese people are coming into our community. The city of Houston needs to kick them out,â€ said Woods, an activist and founder of Black Lives Matter Houston. â€œWe have to be just as tough about these things as they are.â€

Woods is helping organize one of several protests planned just outside the George R Brown Convention Center, where NRA members will browse through exhibits of firearms and gun paraphernalia and hear speeches from key Republican leaders.

The goal of the Black Lives Matter protest, Woods said, is to â€œget loudâ€ outside while powerful speakers â€“ including the Texas governor, Greg Abbott, Texas senator Ted Cruz and former US president Donald Trump â€“ take the podium inside. Woods said the issue of firearms was particularly important to the civil rights group that primarily tackles issues of police brutality in America.

â€œWhether it be death by suicide, death by cop, death by mass shooter, we need to control the access people have to deadly weapons,â€ Woods said. â€œThese things are interconnected.â€

The NRA is a powerful lobbying organization in American politics, spending nearly $5m in 2021 to pressure lawmakers to oppose measures like universal background checks for gun sales and bans on powerful assault weapons.

About 55,000 NRA members are expected to attend the event in Houston. The annual meeting is often a draw for activists and counter-protests as members inside discuss firearms policy â€“ often the need for expanding access to guns.

Outside the convention center, multiple counter-demonstrations are expected in Houston â€“ especially in light of a mass shooting that killed 19 children and two adults at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas.

Houston police are also expecting crowds at the convention center. Jodi Silva, a police spokeswoman, said the department does not share details of its policing strategies, but that there would be a visible presence of officers.

â€œWe always are aware of the demonstrations and/or counter-demonstrations and staff accordingly,â€ Silva said. â€œWe staff accordingly to make sure that everyone can participate and be safe.â€

Megan Hansen and the Rev Teresa Kim Pecinovsky watched the news updates from Uvalde on Tuesday in shock. When they found out the NRA would be in Houston Friday, they decided they also needed to take action.

â€œWe live in a state full of people who love their guns more than they love the lives of the children in their community,â€ Pecinovsky said. â€œI had to do something with that amount of rage and lament.â€

Hansen and Pecinovsky have organized an interfaith gathering that will include a silent march and a moment of reflection when organizers will read the names of those who died in Uvalde.

While Texasâ€™s politics are staunchly conservative, the Houston area has become a bastion of progressivism. Harris county, which includes Houston, voted for Joe Biden by 56% in 2020. Hansen said she wants others to know that the NRAâ€™s message does not reflect that community.

â€œHouston is the most diverse city in the United States and we have people from all over the world who do not agree with the rhetoric of the NRA,â€ Hansen said. â€œWe want to just say, remember the people who we lost and how can we take this feeling and turn it into action?â€

That action â€“ specifically legislative measures to restrict access to high-powered firearms â€“ is unlikely to come from Republican lawmakers in the state. Yet activists in Houston want the shooting in Uvalde and protests this weekend to spark more pressure on political leaders to prevent the next tragedy.

â€œIâ€™m hopeful this will not just be something people attend and then leave,â€ Pecinovsky said. â€œIt needs to be a catalyst for real and tangible change.â€

results.webTitle: Cancelling Socrates: how the great philosopher sealed his fate with comedy

fields.headline: Cancelling Socrates: how the great philosopher sealed his fate with comedy
fields.trailText: Playwright Howard Brenton asks why ancient Athens turned on its famous citizen, and how such an uncompromising free-thinker might fare in our own â€˜age of rageâ€™
fields.body:
Did Socrates â€œcancelâ€ himself? At his trial in Athens, in 399BC, did he deliberately incense the jury with an outrageous comic speech to ensure they condemned him to death?

Socrates was charged with denying the gods exist and inventing new ones, and of corrupting youth. Actually, Socrates was deeply religious and it was fighting dirty to accuse him of sacrilege. But powerful people had had enough of him. A scruffy 70-year-old man hanging out in public places surrounded by adoring pupils, teaching that a life unexamined is not worth living but we must learn we know nothing, corroded certainty. And certainty was what the city craved.

The uncompromising voice of Socrates in a dangerous time resonates with our own â€œage of rageâ€. After Tom Littler, artistic director of the small but heavy-punching Jermyn Street theatre, proposed a Socrates play, I drafted a scene based on Platoâ€™s dialogue Euthyphro â€“ a hilarious encounter between Socrates and an upright Athenian citizen outside the law courts. Socrates came across as impish, empathic and provocative, great fun to write. Then his wife and the mother of their two sons, Xanthippe, and his lover Aspasia, the one powerful woman in Athenian politics we know of, took over the next scene. The play was up and running.

Socrates never wrote anything, though in jail he composed poems based on Aesopâ€™s fables. Or Plato says he did. And there is the problem: the four dialogues we have describing the trial and execution are vivid, shot through with humour and drama, yet they are suspect, distorted by Platoâ€™s worldview. There is one other account of Socratesâ€™ speech by Xenophon but it is a dull read and has nothing whatever in common with Platoâ€™s. Plato is effectively our only source.

Euthyphro, Defence of Socrates and Crito are thought to have been written near the time of the execution. A fourth dialogue, Phaedo, is obviously much later: Plato has Socrates believe in reincarnation, of which there is not a trace in the early works â€“ but his intensely moving description of his teacherâ€™s death and cryptic last words rings true. So, turn the glass this way and that and a very real Socrates emerges.

In bad times, cutting down tall poppies was an Athenian sport. And Socrates was a very tall poppy

Athenian democracy in 399BC was fragile. There had been a brutal coup by oligarchs in 411BC, which collapsed after a year. There was a second coup when Athens surrendered to Sparta in 404BC. Democracy was restored but national pride was deeply wounded. The economy was threatened: farms had been burned by Spartan troops and there were outbreaks of plague. People were angry, exhausted, and wanting to blame someone â€“ in bad times, cutting down tall poppies was an Athenian sport.

And Socrates was a very tall poppy. He was the most famous man in the city, but not universally popular. He only held public office once, for a day, as president of the Assembly. He used his vote to try to block the execution of six generals when the whole city was baying for their blood, arguing that their trial was illegal. He had a long, passionate relationship with his student Alcibiades, a war hero who defected, twice, first to Sparta then to Persia. He was wildly popular with the young, and parents worried he was leading their sons astray.

The jury of 501 was probably merely out to clip his wings, narrowly condemning him on a first vote. The law allowed Socrates to propose an alternative punishment â€“ exile, or a large fine â€“ which the jury would accept and everyone would go home. But he did not ask for exile or a fine; instead he asked to be given free dinners for life by the state â€“ an honour accorded to national heroes. Enraged, the jurors voted heavily to confirm the death sentence. Then, in jail, he refused to escape, arguing that to flee would destroy his reputation, and that he must honour the laws of the democracy, even though it be perverted by enemies.

Was he testing the state to destruction by destroying himself? Or was it the culmination of a profound inquiry: does the soul survive death? The relevance of great stories can go way beyond the immediate moment.

  • Cancelling Socrates is at Jermyn Street theatre, London, 2 June-2 July

results.webTitle: Megaliths and hoopoes: chance encounters in untamed Brittany

fields.headline: Megaliths and hoopoes: chance encounters in untamed Brittany
fields.trailText: A five-day walking trip along the shoreline and around the islands of Brittanyâ€™s Gulf of Morbihan reveals a fascinating blend of the familiar and the exotic
fields.body:
Iâ€™m in a dark corridor with four strangers. The ceiling is low, as is the temperature, and the granite walls are covered in engravings: overlapping patterns of wavy lines and psychedelic swirls, like giant notepad doodles etched in stone. We stumble slowly along the passage, peering at the carvings by torchlight. It feels a bit like being in an art gallery during a power cut â€“ except here, the gallery in question is a 6,000-year-old burial chamber on an uninhabited island.

â€œThis is the Cairn de Gavrinis,â€ says my guide, Maude, as I emerge blinking into the French afternoon. â€œWe call it the neolithic Sistine Chapel. Itâ€™s empty now, but we think it held the most important members of local stone age society.â€ Iâ€™ve come to the Gulf of Morbihan, a natural harbour speckled with more than 30 green islands on Brittanyâ€™s south coast, but Iâ€™ve been beaten to it by some six millennia. The cairnâ€™s builders, and its original occupants, were here in an era so distant that the islands here werenâ€™t islands at all, but low hills separated by rivers.

The megalithic legacy left by these settlers, in the form of dolmens, stone circles and this richly decorated burial chamber â€“ which sits at the heart of a mansion-sized cairn â€“ is one of the bayâ€™s chief attractions. But there are other good reasons to visit this relatively little-known corner of north-west France. If mention of the Brittany coastline throws up images of windblown cliffs and ferry ports, the Gulf of Morbihan turns such lazy generalisations on its head. Looking out from the mainland on my first morning, Iâ€™m greeted by a scene that seems to belong to another place entirely, with pink camellias and shaggy vegetation fringing a calm, glassy inlet.

The gulf is no blink-and-youâ€™ll-miss-it backwater. About 30 miles east of the seaport of Lorient, itâ€™s more than 12 miles long and runs north-south for about seven miles. It opens into the Bay of Biscay, but is almost entirely enclosed by two long headlands, giving the gulf and its sleepy islands the feel of somewhere hidden from the wiles and waves of the ocean.

Iâ€™m here to sample a new four-night walking itinerary offered by KE Adventure, an operator that made its name running trips to the Himalayas. This break is intentionally a far tamer affair, with an emphasis on slow days and quiet coastal paths: less K2 and crampons, more coffee and croissants. Iâ€™ve travelled here by train, initially by Eurostar to Paris, then on a two-and-half-hour ride to Vannes, the capital of Morbihan, a journey which seems in keeping with the whole no-rush experience.

I venture inland to reach the spectacular Neolithic tomb of the Dolmen de Penhap, where Iâ€™m the sole person present

My base is the family-run Parc FÃ©tan hotel (swimming pool at the back, gooey brie de Meaux on the breakfast buffet), in the small mainland commune of Larmor-Baden. Itâ€™s a likable waterside village with bay views, a few seafood restaurants and a boulangerie that does fantastic baguettes, but only seems to open when youâ€™re looking the other way.

The hiking, too, is laid-back. My first full day is taken up with a gentle nine-mile wander along the shore, following a meandering, needle-strewn path that largely sticks to GR34, one of Franceâ€™s official national trails. Giant cypresses and maritime pines arch overhead, while the gulf itself has an almost lake-like quality, with the odd fishing boat the only sign of life. Islands slumber off the beaches, low-slung and tree-cloaked.

The walk is a combination of the familiar and the more exotic. The surface underfoot is laced with knobbly roots and scattered with pinecones. White-tailed bumblebees bump around beds of sea campion. Long-tailed tits jitter among the cypress boughs. Grebes dive offshore, robins hop across the path, and at one point â€“ thrillingly â€“ two hoopoes swoop overhead. I pass well-tended houses and a striped Breton flag flapping from a garden pole. When the sun comes out, the warmth is quiet and cosseting.

This is a break more focused on pottering and puttering than clocking up the kilometres

Thereâ€™s more of the same the next day. The bay has a handful of tidal islands â€“ accessible by foot, but only at certain times. One, the plurally named Sept Ãles, is part of the first dayâ€™s walk, while another, Berder, is factored in today. The timetable says it can be reached at 13.11; I brave the 100 metre crossing at 12.56 and arrive with wet socks. The island just two miles round,appears to be entirely uninhabited â€“ although there is a locked chapel with morose gargoyles. Its trees are tall, bluebells grow in the grass, and the water in its coves is cold and clear. â€œBerder is un bijou â€“ a jewel,â€ Iâ€™d been told that morning at the hotel. â€œItâ€™s all about seeing life slowly.â€ And the visit is a precursor to my late-afternoon boat trip to Gavrinis, where itâ€™s all about the prehistory.

The gulf would make a fine short-break destination in its own right, thanks to the twin appeal of delicate light and ancient remains. The larger islands are all reachable by foot or boat â€“ longer bay cruises are also available â€“ and the concentration of megaliths (and accommodation) around the little town of Locmariaquer, on the gulfâ€™s western shore is a further draw.

Even as a walking holiday, this is a break more focused on pottering and puttering than clocking up the kilometres. There are terraces to linger on, which qualifies me to recommend Brasserie Kerblei for local beer, and Cidrerie du Golfe for cider, enjoyed with Emmental-stuffed galettes. In terms of the hiking itself, however, the itinerary leaves the best until last, with a day trip to the largest island in the bay, Ãle-aux-Moines.

The full shoreline walk measures around 24km, though you can improvise by wandering the single-track lanes that thread around the island. Some 600 lucky souls live out here. Egrets step in the shallows; horse chestnuts tower over the paths. I stick mainly to the shaded, gorse-laden shore, but venture inland to reach the spectacular neolithic tomb Dolmen de Penhap, which I have to myself. Drizzle comes in, so I shelter on a wall under a blackthorn thicket. Somehow I nod off, and when I wake up the rain has gone and the whole harbour seems to zing with freshness.

Folk have been drawn to this part of the French coast since at least 4,000 BC. Were their stone-carved swirls and zigzags some sort of tribute to the shifting watery landscapes they saw around them? Weâ€™ll never know. But to come here today still carries a lesson for the ages: that taking your time on a walk can be mighty enjoyable.

The trip was provided by KE Adventure, whose new five-day Self-Guided Walking on Brittanyâ€™s South Coast runs until 30 September and costs from Â£510pp. The price includes accommodation, breakfast, full route notes, oyster and wine tasting, and boat journeys. The trip starts and finishes in Larmor-Baden. Travel was provided by Eurostar,which has faresfr om London St Pancras International to Paris Gare du Nord from Â£39. Trains to Vannes from Paris Montparnasse cost from Â£45 one way.

results.webTitle: Safety regulator refused to investigate some NHS staff Covid deaths

fields.headline: Safety regulator refused to investigate some NHS staff Covid deaths
fields.trailText: Health and Safety Executive did not look into at least 89 incidents in England, including 10 deaths
fields.body:
Britainâ€™s safety at work regulator refused to investigate reports from NHS trusts that 10 frontline staff had died as a result of catching Covid-19 during the pandemic.

The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) declined to look into at least 89 dangerous incidents that NHS trusts said involved healthcare workers being exposed to Covid, including 10 deaths.

The stance taken by the HSE, which oversees workplace health and safety and can bring prosecutions, is disclosed in freedom of information requests by the Pharmaceutical Journal. It has prompted concern that the regulator is too strict in its definition of workplace harm.

It found that 173 trusts in England submitted at least 6,007 reports about employeesâ€™ exposure to Covid-19 in the course of their duties to the HSE between 30 January 2020 and 11 March 2022, under the Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations (RIDDOR).

They included 213 â€œdangerous occurrencesâ€, which are incidents that have the potential to cause significant harm; 5,753 cases where a staff member had caught Covid-19; and 41 deaths among people who had been exposed to the disease at their workplace.

However, the HSE refused to look into five Covid deaths reported under the RIDDOR scheme by the Yorkshire ambulance service (YAS) because of what it considered a lack of evidence.

The YASâ€™s response to the Pharmaceutical Journal said that â€œHSE maintained that the occupational exposure of Covid-19 could not be clearly linked to the workplace as community cases were also highly prevalent at the timeâ€.

The regulator also decided not to look into the Covid deaths of five staff at University College London hospital acute trust, despite the trustâ€™s belief they had caught it at work. â€œThe HSE found that there was no reasonable evidence that the infection was contracted at work,â€ a trust spokesperson said.

Shelly Asquith, the health, safety and wellbeing officer at the Trades Union Congress, said the HSEâ€™s decisions and claimed lack of evidence was â€œreally concerningâ€. It suggested a continued â€œelement of denial about Covid being airborne and it not being possible to necessarily pinpoint where exactly somebody was exposed once itâ€™s in the airâ€, she added.

Prof Raymond Agius, the co-chair of the British Medical Associationâ€™s occupational medicine committee, said: â€œThe HSE threshold for RIDDOR reporting, as shown by HSEâ€™s guidance and its correspondence with employers [trusts], is too high. It does not take into account the increased risk health and care staff face simply by sharing the same environment as patients, even if they arenâ€™t directly clinically treating those who are known to be Covid-positive.â€

An HSE spokesperson said that while â€œthe pandemic was challenging for all concernedâ€, it was important that RIDDOR reports were based on â€œaccurate information about workplace exposure and riskâ€.

While it insisted during the pandemic on trusts submitting reports based on â€œreasonable evidenceâ€ that infection was work-related, â€œthis does not mean that we discouraged reportingâ€, they added.

results.webTitle: Texas gunman was inside school for about 40 minutes, officials say

fields.headline: Texas gunman was inside school for about 40 minutes, officials say
fields.trailText: Timeline of events leading up to attack emerges, amid claims police had trouble opening door of classroom where attacker had barricaded himself in
fields.body:
The Texas gunman who shot and killed 19 children and two teachers was inside the school for about 40 minutes before being killed by border patrol agents, officials have said, as onlookers spoke of their frustration at what they viewed as delays by law enforcement.

The first reports of an armed man approaching the school began to surface at about 11.30am on Tuesday. Just after 1pm, the 18-year-old was confirmed dead after he was shot inside the Robb elementary school classroom in the small city of Uvalde.

There have been conflicting reports about what happened before the shooter entered the building and how law enforcement outside tried to â€œengageâ€ and stop him.

About â€œ40 minutes or soâ€ elapsed from when the gunman opened fire on the school security officer, entered the school through a back door and when the border patrol team shot him, the Texas department of public safety director, Steve McCraw, told a news briefing.

Related: â€˜He was just a loving little boyâ€™: the victims of the Texas school shooting

Officials said that officers at the scene were able to successfully â€œcontainâ€ the gunman until more specially trained officers could arrive.

Lt Christopher Olivarez of the department of public safety told CNN the gunman charged into a classroom where he â€œbarricaded himself by locking the door and just started shooting children and teachers that were inside that classroomâ€.

A separate law enforcement official familiar with the investigation told the Associated Press that border patrol agents had trouble breaching the classroom door and had to get a staff member to open the room with a key.

Onlookers have also since said they urged police officers to charge into the school, claiming more could have been done.

Juan Carranza, 24, who saw the scene from outside his house, across the street from the school, told the Associated Press he felt the officers should have entered the school sooner. â€œGo in there! Go in there!â€ nearby women shouted at the officers soon after the attack began, he said. Carranza said the officers did not go in.

Javier Cazares, whose fourth-grade daughter, Jacklyn Cazares, was killed in the attack, said he raced to the school when he heard about the shooting, arriving while police were still massed outside the building.

Upset that police were not moving in, he raised the idea of charging into the school with several other bystanders. â€œLetâ€™s just rush in because the cops arenâ€™t doing anything like they are supposed to,â€ he said. â€œMore could have been done â€¦ They were unprepared.â€

The US border patrol chief, Raul Ortiz, told CNN that dozens of on-duty and off-duty agents responded to the shooting, adding that as soon as officers arrived, â€œthey didnâ€™t hesitate.â€

â€œWe responded from various locations. I had both on-duty, off-duty, folks that were in a training environment all responded to this location,â€ Ortiz said, adding that between 80 and 100 officers responded.

â€œThey didnâ€™t hesitate. They came up with a plan. They entered that classroom and they took care of the situation as quickly as they possibly could.â€

The gunman also discussed his plans on Facebook before the attack, the governor of Texas said at a press conference on Wednesday.

Greg Abbott said the shooter â€œpostedâ€ on Facebook three times before the deadly massacre at Robb elementary school.

Although Abbott described them as posts, which are typically distributed to a wide audience, Facebook later stepped in to note that the gunman had sent one-to-one direct messages, not public posts, and that they werenâ€™t discovered until â€œafter the terrible tragedyâ€.

â€œWe are closely cooperating with law enforcement in their ongoing investigation,â€ tweeted the Facebook spokesperson Andy Stone on Wednesday.

In the first message, sent 30 minutes before the gunman went to the school, he said he would shoot his grandmother. The second said, â€œI shot my grandmother.â€ And the third, sent about 15 minutes before the attack, said: â€œIâ€™m going to shoot an elementary school.â€ He did not specify which school, officials said, and it was not clear who the messages were sent to.

Related: â€˜He was just a loving little boyâ€™: the victims of the Texas school shooting

The Texas governor described the messages at a news conference where he said the shooter, identified as 18-year-old Salvador Ramos, used an AR-15 to attack the school in Uvalde, a predominantly Latino city of about 16,000 people in a farming area about 75 miles (120kms) from the Mexican border and 85 miles from San Antonio. Abbott also said the shooterâ€™s grandmother had called the police before he shot her.

The shooting was the deadliest gun rampage in an American school in almost a decade. Authorities have said the victims were all killed in the same fourth-grade classroom, where the shooter barricaded himself inside.

A high school dropout, Ramos lived in Uvalde and had no known criminal record or history of mental health problems, Abbott said.

Investigators have also been scrutinizing an Instagram account that apparently belonged to the gunman. In the days before the shooting, posts featured a photo of a hand holding an ammunition magazine and another photo of two AR-15-style rifles. The account asked another Instagram user to share the latter photo with her 10,000 followers; she declined, saying it was â€œscaryâ€ and she barely knew him.

On the morning of the massacre, the account linked to the attacker sent her an ominous message: â€œIâ€™m about to.â€

Instagram declined to answer questions from the Associated Press about the postings.

The latest mass shooting is likely to further intensify pressure on social media companies to heighten their scrutiny of online communications. The attack in Texas follows the shooting at a Buffalo grocery store less than two weeks ago, where the gunman used social media to plan, promote and live-stream the massacre that killed 10 people. The New York attorney general has since opened an investigation into Twitch, 4chan, 8chan and Discord along with other platforms the Buffalo shooter used to amplify the attack.

Facebookâ€™s parent company, Meta, has said it monitors peopleâ€™s private messages for some kinds of harmful content, such as links to malware or images of child sexual abuse. But images can be detected using unique identifiers â€“ a kind of digital signature â€“ which makes them relatively easy for computer systems to flag. Trying to interpret a string of threatening words â€“ which can resemble a joke, satire or song lyrics â€“ is a far more difficult task for artificial intelligence systems.

Facebook and other platforms therefore rely on user reports to catch threats, harassment and other violations of the law or their own policies. As evidenced by the latest shootings, the information often comes too late, if at all.

results.webTitle: â€˜Evil will not winâ€™: sorrow and disbelief as Uvalde mourns its children

fields.headline: â€˜Evil will not winâ€™: sorrow and disbelief as Uvalde mourns its children
fields.trailText: Town comes together to try to come to terms with horrific attack in which 19 young children and two teachers were killed
fields.body:
The tears started before anyone even spoke. Inside a Uvalde county building that usually hosts the rodeo in this part of south-west Texas, young children and parents cried and held each other. Together, they waited for a group of pastors to offer some words of comfort for their unfathomable loss.

This week in Uvalde began with a mood of celebration. The high school graduation was to be held on Friday â€“ giant senior portraits lined the lawn outside city hall. Younger children were wrapping up the school year as well, attending classroom parties and awards ceremonies. But on Tuesday, life in this largely Latino town was upended when a gunman barricaded himself in an elementary school classroom and slaughtered 19 children and two teachers.

Related: Texas school shooting: gunman was inside for 40 minutes, officials say â€“ latest updates

The shooting at Robb elementary school is the deadliest in a US school in nearly 10 years. The attack, the latest in a long line of gun violence in America, came just 10 days after the deadly shooting in Buffalo and has left Uvalde and the country reeling.

With all schools in the district cancelled for the remainder of the year and the town mourning for those it lost, hundreds of people came to a vigil at the Uvalde County Fairplex arena on Wednesday. There, pastors, seated on a stage on the dirt normally reserved for horses, tried to offer solace to their community.

â€œPray for those children that saw what happened to their friends â€¦ pray for each of us as we help them,â€ said Pastor Tony Grubin, feeling nervous as he addressed the crowd of adults and children, many of them wearing red school shirts. â€œEvil will not win.â€

Grubin and other pastors urged the town to rely on its faith and on one another, encouraging them to join together in prayer. As the pastors spoke, attendees in the bleachers bowed their heads, sometimes joining hands and singing or just holding loved ones as they cried.

Related: â€˜He was just a loving little boyâ€™: the victims of the Texas school shooting

Grubin said the idea for the vigil came up on Tuesday night as he and other pastors sat with families who were waiting to hear whether their loved ones had survived. â€œWe thought tonight should just be as simple, as respectful and as loving as we knew how to be,â€ said Grubin, who said several prayers to the crowd.

â€œIâ€™m afraid to be in front of people, but my fear is inconsequential to the needs of others,â€ he added. â€œWe just wanted to provide some encouragement and an expression of love.â€

Sophia Fulcher, 15, reunited with her friends at the vigil for the first time since Tuesday when her school, along with all the others in town was on lockdown. â€œIt was emotional, just a lot of emotions. I donâ€™t know how to feel,â€ she said. â€œHow sickening it is for someone to do something so violent like that.â€

In this tight community of 16,000, the shooting has touched almost everyone, if not directly then through relatives of friends and co-workers.

Downtown on Wednesday afternoon, cars honked and passersby waved to a group holding supportive signs. Ravenn Vasquez and several friends spent the afternoon on Main Street waving their signs with phrases like â€œUvalde strongâ€.

â€œWe just didnâ€™t know what to do. We donâ€™t want to be glued to our phones and just mourning,â€ said Vasquez, who graduated from Uvalde high in 2019. â€œWe want to be there for the community and let them know weâ€™re out here.

â€œI havenâ€™t slept,â€ she added. â€œI couldnâ€™t sleep last night. I couldnâ€™t shake that feeling â€¦ you hear about this in other cities. Itâ€™s really sad to see in Uvalde.â€

Signs of what happened this week are all around, from the dozens of messages reading â€œpray for Uvaldeâ€ and â€œUvalde strongâ€ at businesses to the endless stream of news media vans at the civic center and the elementary school. Outside the campus itself, dozens of white, yellow and red flowers surrounded the Robb elementary school sign, barely visible in between the TV cameras and law enforcement vehicles.

The welcoming town is known for its rivers, a Labor Day rodeo and music festival, and as the birthplace of Matthew McConaughey, Vasquez said, but now itâ€™s known for something horrific. Vasquez tried not to think of that. Instead she tries to remember the happy moments the elementary school students experienced, like an event on Monday where the graduating seniors came to visit.

Desiree Vera was at Robb elementary school on Monday, where she and other high school seniors, dressed in their red caps and gowns, stopped by their old classrooms and high-fived the young students: â€œIt was sweet to see the school and all the kids who were one day gonna be us.â€

No one ever expects such a tragedy to befall their community, several residents remarked, and coming to terms with the fact that it happened here is difficult.

â€œYou would never think that something like this could happen in such a small town, but then you have to think, donâ€™t ever think it canâ€™t happen to you, because it can and it did happen to us,â€ said Desiree Vera, a Uvalde High senior.

Her sister, Monica, added: â€œIt just doesnâ€™t feel real. Did this actually happen in our home town?â€ Monica was in the middle of a geometry class at the high school when the shooting started, prompting their school to go into lockdown for four hours. â€œI donâ€™t think weâ€™ll ever recover. Everybody is close here, so it affects everybody.â€

results.webTitle: Thursday briefing: Grayâ€™s report confirms Boris Johnsonâ€™s agenda - his own survival

fields.headline: Thursday briefing: Grayâ€™s report confirms Boris Johnsonâ€™s agenda - his own survival
fields.trailText: In todayâ€™s newsletter: When limiting the harm of the Partygate scandal is the governmentâ€™s number one priority, what does that mean for how the country is run?
fields.body:
Good morning. Itâ€™s the little things, isnâ€™t it? The disrespect shown towards security and cleaning staff; the wine on the walls; the Downing Street staffer getting so drunk they were sick; two others having a fight; the senior civil servant who texted â€œwe seem to have got away with itâ€. Sue Grayâ€™s report has not dislodged the prime minister. But it has created an indelible image of the culture he oversaw, and the sense of tacit sanction under which his staff were operating.

Jessica Elgot reports that MPs keeping count believe three more letters of no confidence in the prime minister have gone in â€“ but yesterday was also a victory of sorts for Boris Johnson, who emerged wounded but still in place. One Tory MP tells the FT (Â£) today: â€œMost of us are resigned to the fact that he wonâ€™t be going but that weâ€™ve lost the next general election.â€

That assessment reflects the larger problem â€“ the fact that Johnsonâ€™s purpose as prime minister has narrowed to his own survival, and the way the rest of the political agenda has been co-opted to that end. Alcohol has been consumed, we read; so has Downing Street.

Todayâ€™s newsletter, with Guardian columnist Rafael Behr, is about how the tail started to wag the big dog, and what that means for how the government operates. Thatâ€™s right after the headlines.

Five big stories

  1. Texas shooting | The gunman who killed 21 people in Uvalde signalled his intentions in a Facebook message a few minutes before beginning his attack.

  2. Cost of living | Rishi Sunak is expected to set out plans for a controversial windfall tax on energy companies on Thursday, as he proposes measures to ease the pain of rising household bills.

  3. Parliament | Sexual abuse, harassment and bullying accusations made against MPs are treated as â€œmere gossipâ€, dozens of Conservative staffers have said, in a letter urging Boris Johnson and party HQ to do more to tackle the problem.

  4. Medicine | NHS surgeons have successfully performed the worldâ€™s first double hand transplant for scleroderma, an autoimmune disease. Steven Gallagher, the recipient, said the operation had given him â€œa new lease of lifeâ€.

  5. US | Supermodel Kate Moss testified in the Johnny Depp-Amber Heard defamation trial. Moss said that the rumour that Depp pushed her down a flight of stairs when they were in a relationship was untrue.

In depth: â€˜Johnson will always act in the interests of whoever heâ€™s most afraid ofâ€™

At the end of his statement to the House of Commons yesterday, Boris Johnson tried to draw a line under Sue Grayâ€™s investigation by emphasising his priorities for the future. â€œI hope very much that now she has reported we will be able to move on and focus on the priorities of the British people,â€ he said. â€œThat is my mission, that is our mission, that is the mission of the whole of the government, and we will work day and night to deliver it.â€

Itâ€™s a noble sentiment â€“ but one which recent events appear to fatally undermine. Here are some of the ways Johnsonâ€™s government appears to have reoriented its mission from the good of the country to the good of the prime minister.

***

Big announcements are emerging with suspiciously good timing

After weeks of delay and disagreement, a package of measures to help with the cost of living will finally be announced today â€“ and if Rishi Sunakâ€™s embrace of the near-mythological windfall tax helps to turn the page on the Sue Gray fallout, so much the better. The day after Johnson became the first serving prime minister to have been found to have broken the law while in office, the governmentâ€™s controversial plan to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda to be processed was all over the front pages. And if Volodymyr Zelenskiy wants to know when heâ€™s going to get a phone call from the British prime minister, all he has to do is set a Google alert for â€œnew Partygate revelationsâ€.

Governments always time their announcements for maximum political impact, and dead cats can be so overrated as a theory of politics as to edge into conspiracy. But there is now a sense that governing priorities are being specifically tailored to minimise the harm of the Partygate story to the prime minister, instead of to the benefit of the government and the country as a whole.

â€œIâ€™m generally wary of that sort of thinking,â€ said Rafael Behr. â€œBut with this lot â€“ one former cabinet office official said to me, if you are ever in doubt about the motives for anything theyâ€™re doing, imagine the most cynical, short-termist reason you can think of, and thereâ€™s your answer. [Borisâ€™s] entire career has been about getting out of scrapes, and that means there wonâ€™t be any sustained thinking behind anything.â€

***

The people in the background

â€œThe entire senior management has changed,â€ Boris Johnson said yesterday, doughtily ignoring the hecklers who pointed out that actually, one quite important part of the senior management had stayed the same. Nonetheless, itâ€™s true that he has a new chief of staff, a new director of communications, and a new parliamentary private secretary. The question is whether we should be persuaded that this is really about instituting a new working culture â€“ or firming up the prime ministerâ€™s grip on power.

The most controversial new appointment is one Johnson didnâ€™t mention in the House of Commons: the installation of David Canzini, an acolyte of his previous election guru Sir Lynton Crosby, as deputy chief of staff. Canzini â€œhas a very similar ethos to Dominic Cummingsâ€, said Rafael. His idea, inherited from Crosby, of getting â€œthe barnacles off the boatâ€ and focusing on the most broadly appealing policies, is â€œa campaign ethos, not a governing ethosâ€.

Canzini has set about instituting â€œdividing lineâ€ policies which are driving the government further to the right. He is said to have been an enthusiastic advocate for the Rwanda policy, and responsible for the governmentâ€™s decision to drop a ban on conversion therapy for trans people.

â€œItâ€™s kind of amazing that the appointment of deputy chief of staff can change the whole strategic direction of government,â€ one backbencher told the Times (Â£) recently. â€œBut thatâ€™s a reflection of Boris. For Boris it doesnâ€™t matter what the policies are, as long as heâ€™s still prime minister.â€

***

Backbenchers are dragging the government to the right

When Johnson won an 80-seat majority in the last election, it was hailed by some as a chance for him to show his true colours as a â€œone nationâ€ Tory or â€“ in his own words â€“ a â€œBrexity Hezzaâ€ who believed Tories should be â€œthe warriors of the dispossessedâ€. But there is plenty of evidence to suggest that the threat of his removal has been enough to neuter those instincts and force him to pander to the most rightwing voices in his party.

â€œAll thatâ€™s gone out of the window,â€ Rafael said. â€œJohnson knows the underlying dynamics of his party well enough to understand that when you are unpopular, the bit of the party you have to be wary of is the faction that has done in just about every Tory leader in our lifetimes.â€ Indeed, one MP, described as a senior Brexiteer, told the BBCâ€™s Newsnight last night: â€œWe have to destroy Boris Johnson for the sake of this country and the sake of our party.â€

That might explain why Johnson delayed â€“ or dumped â€“ measures designed to attack Britainâ€™s obesity crisis, like an end to â€œbuy one get one freeâ€ deals on junk food and a pre-9pm watershed for TV advertising. Meanwhile, there are fears the government could soon ditch some of its net-zero commitments, an attack on Channel 4, the abandonment of animal cruelty legislation, and draconian measures against the right to protest.

â€œThere was no reason to jettison the obesity stuff other than to appease the mindless libertarian wing,â€ Rafael said. â€œIâ€™d keep an eye on the deadline for replacing gas boilers, too.â€

Not for nothing did right-wingers Peter Bone and Desmond Swayne leap to Johnsonâ€™s defence even before the Sue Gray report was published. â€œThey donâ€™t like Boris, and they donâ€™t trust him,â€ Rafael said. â€œBut they like having a wounded prime minister, who believes in nothing, and bears the imprint of whoever last sat on him, and will always act in the interests of whoever heâ€™s most afraid of.â€

***

Read more on the Sue Gray report

  • â€œIf being prime minister is to captain a ship, the Johnson of the Gray report commands a cruise vessel,â€ writes Peter Walker in his analysis. â€œOne where the main task involves being amiable to passengers at the dinner table.â€

  • The Guardianâ€™s leader: â€œMr Johnson told MPs he took responsibility, but failed to explain how. The assertion was no more convincing than his affectation of humility.â€

  • John Craceâ€™s sketch: â€œâ€˜We are humbled,â€™ he said with a dismissive, regal wave of his arm. Except he wasnâ€™t at all.â€

  • Sue Gray said she did not fully investigate an alcohol-fuelled gathering in the flat shared by the prime minister and his wife Carrie. Aubrey Allegretti reports on Tory MPsâ€™ fears of a â€œcover-upâ€.

  • ConservativeHome sees the prime ministerâ€™s secret weapon as boredom. â€œBy simply hanging on in there, he has given much of the parliamentary party, and a majority of party members, the time and space in which to become sick and tired of his foes.â€

What else weâ€™ve been reading

  • Itâ€™s been two years since the murder of George Floyd at the hands of Minneapolis police. The flagrant display of brutal violence sparked a movement, but Afua Hirsch wonders what has actually changed since. Nimo

  • Martin Lewis didnâ€™t really mean to be political. But in an era where the poorest need to be money saving experts to survive, he tells Zoe Williams, it was an inevitability. Archie

  • Writer Jack Rooke has a Channel 4 comedy called Big Boys coming out all about a friendship between Jack, who is gay, and his straight best pal, Danny. Rooke writes about his own best friend, and why this kind of relationship is often neglected in British TV. Nimo

  • When Harry Styles dresses in a blouse or a tight crimson jumpsuit or something else that makes the public swoon/panic, Harry Lambert had something to do with it. Morwenna Ferrier talked to the stylist whoâ€™s â€œThomas Cromwell to Stylesâ€™s Henry VIII, but dissolving binaries instead of monasteriesâ€. Archie

  • Elephantâ€™s breath! Revere pewter! Chic Shadow! These, and many other names for â€œgreigeâ€, are enumerated in Elle Huntâ€™s read on how it became the suffocatingly dull paint colour of our times (and, ahem, my living room). Archie

Sport

Tennis | Emma Raducanu lost in the second round of the French Open. She fell to world No 47 Aliaksandra Sasnovich 3-6, 6-1, 6-1.

Football | Roma won the inaugural Europa conference league final with a 1-0 victory over Feyenoord. The trophy is the first ever Uefa title for Jose Mourinhoâ€™s side.

Football | Burnley are close to appointing the former Manchester City captain Vincent Kompany as their manager. Kompany is understood to be ready to leave his job at Anderlecht to bring Burnley back up to the Premier League.

The front pages

Thereâ€™s quite a contrast in how the papers report the findings of Sue Grayâ€™s report. â€œDrinking, fights, vomiting: all in a dayâ€™s work, says PMâ€ is the Guardianâ€™s splash headline, while the Mirror says that the government was having parties and â€œLaughing at us allâ€ while people were sacrificing and mourning alone during lockdown. The Metro picks up the comment from a senior aide to Boris Johnson as its headline â€“ â€œâ€˜We got away with itâ€™â€ â€“ and the i runs with the theme of Grayâ€™s conclusion: â€œâ€˜Failure of leadershipâ€™â€. In Scotland the Record says â€œTory party enough to make you sickâ€.

For some editors, the Gray report is a damp squib. The Mail asks â€œIs that it?â€ and the Express has a similar â€œReallyâ€¦ is this what all the fuss is aboutâ€. The Sun declares that â€œThe Party(gate) is overâ€. The Telegraph leads on â€œSunak to extend energy bill reliefâ€, although it does have a front page report headlined â€œJohnson denies cover-up of â€˜Abba partyâ€™ at Downing Street flatâ€. Similarly, the Times leads on â€œEnergy bill handouts to ease the big squeezeâ€ with â€œGray report vindicates me over No 10 parties, claims Johnsonâ€ as a second story.

Today in Focus

The Partygate saga culminated with the release of the Sue Gray report yesterday. Peter Walker and Jonathan Freedland analyse what it means for Boris Johnson.

Cartoon of the day | Martin Rowson

The Upside

A bit of good news to remind you that the worldâ€™s not all bad

After the Grenfell Tower caught ablaze in 2017, taking the lives of 72 people, Tayshan Hayden-Smith was, like much of the country, distraught. In an effort to do something he went to local garden centres and plant nurseries to ask for donations to transform the area.

Hayden-Smith had become a guerrilla gardener and began dedicating his time to reclaiming community spaces. The space came to be known as the Grenfell Garden of Peace, injecting sense of unity and togetherness into the area. Hayden-Smith is now the founder of Grow2Know and is taking his project to other parts of London. These include the RHS Chelsea flower show, where the Hands Off Mangrove garden this week won a silver gilt medal.

Bored at work?

results.webTitle: NAB to introduce buy now, pay later product placing further pressure on existing operators

fields.headline: NAB to introduce buy now, pay later product placing further pressure on existing operators
fields.trailText: Standalone operators feel burden of rising interest rates and slowing growth as third big Australian bank enters BNPL scene
fields.body:
NAB will become the third of the big four Australian banks to offer a buy now, pay later (BNPL) product to customers, putting additional pressure on standalone operators battling corporate losses amid rising interest rates that make it harder to survive.

The bank will offer its NAB Now Pay Later product from July using the existing Visa credit card system, meaning it will not have to sign up merchants to offer the service in the same way that standalone operators Zip and Afterpay do.

NABâ€™s offering will allow customers who pass a credit check to split purchases of up to $1,000 into four payments. The bank said it will not charge interest, late fees or an account fee.

The move adds pressure on a BNPL market that has seen the number of players in Australia shrink as losses mount and share prices plunge.

Grant Halverson, the managing director of consultancy McLean Roche, said the banks had a huge advantage because they already had big debit and credit card businesses which they could leverage to target BNPL customers.

At the same time, rising interest rates are making it more expensive for BNPL operators to borrow the money they need to keep their businesses going.

â€œThey [banks] also have huge muscle and can ride out the increase in funding costs,â€ Halverson said.

  • Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

NABâ€™s offering comes on top of similar products launched by ANZ and CBA, leaving Westpac the only one of the big four currently not offering a BNPL service. The banks are entering the BNPL market at a time when growth in the product has tapered off.

For existing BNPL-only operators, the entry of the banks will cause â€œa massive squeeze, because the Australian and New Zealand BNPL market has already peaked and growth is now single digit,â€ Halverson said. â€œItâ€™s going to be very tough.â€

Consumer advocates have criticised BNPL operators for using a loophole in the law that means their products are not classified as credit, and accused them of targeting vulnerable customers.

The loophole means BNPL services are not subject to the same laws protecting consumers as credit cards and personal loans. They are instead subject to an industry code that itself has been criticised by advocates as too weak.

Advocates have called for the loophole to be closed, but Halverson said he did not expect the new Labor government to do so in the face of ferocious industry lobbying.

â€œI would be very sceptical. My guide would be the Senate hearings theyâ€™ve had on this [and] both sides have been very reluctant so far,â€ he said. â€œThe whole thing is a regulatory arbitrage, thatâ€™s what it is, and theyâ€™ve fought tooth and nail to stop it being closed.â€

Related: Legal action launched against Australian companies accused of overcharging the vulnerable for electronics and whitegoods

The number of BNPL operators listed on the Australian stock exchange is shrinking. Afterpay was sold to the US company Block in January, while the consumer finance arm of Humm (formerly known as Flexigroup) is in the process of being sold to Latitude Financial Services, while Zip is in the process of taking over junior player Sezzle.

All the ASX-listed players, except Humm, have declared losses and share prices have fallen as dreams of big profits recede. Halverson estimates the total market capitalisation of the ASX-listed players has tumbled from $46bn in April last year to about $6bn now.

According to data compiled by Halverson, in addition to nine ASX-listed BNPL operators, there are an additional 36 unlisted companies with similar business models. Some specialise in niches including small business finance, rental payments, paying for tattoos and wage advances.

â€œMost of these will disappear within the next 18 months or so because funding rates are starting to ramp up,â€ Halverson said. â€œTheyâ€™re all desperately trying to cling to credibility.â€

results.webTitle: â€˜Always a possibility of changeâ€™: incarcerated teens seek justice as adults

fields.headline: â€˜Always a possibility of changeâ€™: incarcerated teens seek justice as adults
fields.trailText: Harsh sentencing in the US has led to many economically deprived young men receiving hard-to-contest life sentences but in new documentary Since I Been Down, hope awaits
fields.body:
At 1.30pm on Friday 8 July, Kimonti Carter will learn whether he must spend the rest of his life in prison â€“ or if American justice allows for the possibility of redemption.

Carter was riding in a car with fellow gang members in 1997. One told him to shoot at a car in the next lane, mistakenly believing that it belonged to a rival gang. Carter fired several shots, killing Corey Pittman and injuring two other passengers.

Related: â€˜The birthplace of hostage negotiationâ€™: inside a groundbreaking 1973 standoff

Just over 18, he was tried as an adult, convicted of aggravated first-degree murder and sentenced to 777 years, 77 months and 77 daysâ€™ imprisonment. Since Washington state has no parole system, it effectively locked him up and threw away the key.

But instead of yielding to hopelessness, Carter has dedicated his life behind bars to working as a teacher, mentor and founder of a groundbreaking prisoner-led higher-education programme. At a resentencing hearing at Pierce county superior court in Tacoma, Washington, on 8 July, he will ask to be set free.

â€œHe never thought he was getting out and so he decided to make the most of his grieving by doing something so he can prevent things from happening,â€ says Gilda Sheppard, who interviewed Carter for her documentary, Since I Been Down. â€œThereâ€™s always a possibility of change. I have to think that.â€

Filmed over 12 years, Since I Been Down paints a stark portrait of a predominantly white state, Washington, whose prison population is overwhelmingly Black. It shows Tacoma, near Seattle, as scarred by drugs and lack of investment in housing, education and employment. With opportunities scarce, gangs offer a seductive sense of identity. One former gang member recalls: â€œI got addicted to being feared.â€

Sheppard, who teaches at a liberal arts college in Tacoma, says: â€œItâ€™s like Everytown USA. It has been a victim of gentrification, a legacy of people not being able to have bank loans, or any kind of loans, to rehabilitate their homes. As a result, these neighbourhoods become infested with public health issues. Disinvestment in communities and education and employment comes with gentrification.â€

In 1993 Washington became the first state in the US to pass a â€œthree strikesâ€ policy, which mandates life in prison without parole for people thrice convicted of certain offences, from robbery to assault to murder. The consequences were devastating for a generation. By the end of 2020, Black people, representing 4% of the stateâ€™s population, accounted for 38% of those sentenced under the law.

Speaking via Zoom from her home in Seattle, Sheppard reflects: â€œItâ€™s not just the three strikes and youâ€™re out but a culture of punishment that you see in many different urban communities, particularly Black, brown and poor communities. Tacoma, Washington, is a visual metaphor for the legacy of those things.â€

This was the era of moral panic and so-called â€œtough on crimeâ€ policies across America that targeted Black â€œsuper-predatorsâ€, including three-strikes laws that sent young people to prison for life. President Bill Clinton signed a national crime bill now widely blamed for giving the US the highest incarceration rate in the world.

Mary Flowers, an anti-racism organiser, says in the film: â€œThis country is based on fear. When you have a country that is based on or has grown out of colonisation and slavery, people donâ€™t rest easy. Thatâ€™s why everyone needs to be armed in this country to protect what they have, because what they have was stolen.â€

But this is also a documentary about resistance and reinvention. For more than a decade Sheppard has been teaching sociology classes in Washington state prisons through the Black Prisonersâ€™ Caucus, which started half a century ago and is now in a dozen prisons across Washington. She was surprised by the inmatesâ€™ academic discipline and engagement.

â€œI taught this concept of sociological imagination that looks at a personâ€™s biography and how history informs that biography,â€ Sheppard recalls. â€œI was getting all this brilliant analysis and I was like, â€˜Iâ€™m supposed to impart this. You all know this! Whereâ€™s the scaffold for this political and creative thinking?â€™

â€œSo then I went to a summit of the Black Prisonersâ€™ Caucus talking about youth violence, legislative process; they brought representatives, senators, the head of the department of corrections, some victims that could and other people in the community, their families, and I thought to myself, as James Baldwin said, to be an artist is to be a lover.

â€œIf I love you, I have to show you things that you donâ€™t see. I didnâ€™t see this and I dare say Iâ€™m not sure a lot of people saw who we are imprisoning in our culture of punishment, even with the triumphs and redemptive possibilities of these men and women in prison. I just wanted to share that in my art.â€

In 2013 Carter and the caucus created a programme called Taking Education and Creating History (Teach) in which prisoners teach literacy, maths and language courses to one another. It includes white inmates and is now at three Washington prisons. Carter now teaches algebra, financial literacy, interpersonal communication and African studies.

Sheppard witnessed how the initiative gives incarcerated people a sense of purpose, self-possession and hope. â€œWhen you meet one member of a community that has been shut off and wants to maintain those views of fear and hate and all those things, but that one member of that community gets a little bit of light, itâ€™s hard to stop that light from shining. Iâ€™m not talking about optimism. Iâ€™m talking about real work.â€

She was particularly struck by a â€œhealthy thinkingâ€ class â€œto understand that to have education is not enough. What is your perspective? Who are you looking at as the good guys and the bad guys? Does history repeat itself or do people repeat history?

â€œIn those classes I heard from different incarcerated folks from their heart and soul about their families, how they could cry together, going deep into remorse. One guy said his son wanted to come to prison so he could be with him. Or thereâ€™s one white guy who says, â€˜I got seven kids. I donâ€™t want to be like this. I want to change the way Iâ€™m thinking,â€™ Oftentimes prison is not a place where you can reflect. But these prisoner-initiated programmes realise what is needed in a personâ€™s life and oftentimes they would invite some of the staff.

â€œWhen they go and hear these guys talking, they canâ€™t help but listen a little bit. I am not naive to think that everybodyâ€™s going to change, but maybe a member of that community has something else that they havenâ€™t looked at, and who knows what they can do?â€

Carter, a leader in the Black Prisonersâ€™ Caucus, emerges as the documentaryâ€™s central protagonist. Sheppard came to admire his â€œcompassionate leadership and visionâ€, she says. â€œHe would look at situations, but also imagine what was possible, hence his development of Teach across race lines. Heâ€™s remorseful but his remorse is not in a kind of grieving thatâ€™s only filled with tears but a kind of grieving thatâ€™s filled with activity.

â€œJust the other day, my film was shown at a juvenile facility, Green Hill school â€“ young men between the ages of 16 and twentysomething â€“ and they were very quiet afterwards. Kimonti Carter calls in sometimes when Iâ€™m doing these post-screening discussions and it was the most amazing discussion you could ever hear. Heâ€™s devoted his life to this.â€

In 2006 Carter spoke at the Black Prisonersâ€™ Caucus justice reform summit, apologising to the family of Pittman and taking responsibility for his crime. His life sentence was based on arbitrary legal technicalities. If he had been on the street instead of inside a moving vehicle at the moment he opened fire, or if he had been just six weeks younger when he committed the crime, he would probably now be a free man.

Yet the lack of a parole option meant he was told that, irrespective of how he behaved in prison, he would never be released. Sheppard reflects: â€œYouâ€™ve been held accountable. You did the time. But not only did you do the time, you helped to redeem so many other people who were in prison, across race lines.â€

Carterâ€™s sentence was finally vacated after the Washington supreme court ruled that mandatory life sentences without parole are unconstitutional for people aged 18 to 21, not just those under 18. At his hearing on 8 July, Carter will ask a judge to resentence him to â€œtime servedâ€, amounting to the 25 years that he has been imprisoned already. This would allow the 43-year-old to be released immediately.

In one scene of the film, Carter is seen hosting a caucus meeting. Wearing white T-shirt and beige trousers, with pen behind ear and notebook in hand, he tells fellow inmates: â€œNot only do you have to make a commitment but you have to make a choice: if I still want to continue living the life that got me here or I want to try to live a better life, right? We can never become somebody different but we can become a better version of who we are.â€

  • Since I Been Down is now available on Sundance Now or to rent digitally in the US with a UK date to be announced

results.webTitle: The network of organisations seeking to influence abortion policy across Europe

fields.headline: The network of organisations seeking to influence abortion policy across Europe
fields.trailText: The ultra-Christian, anti-abortion and far-right network is allegedly seeking to replicate anti-choice efforts in the US
fields.body:
A network of ultra-Christian, anti-abortion and far-right organisations is building momentum in its quest to influence abortion policy in Europe as the US supreme court considers striking down Roe v Wade, the 1973 ruling that legalised the procedure in America.

Elements of the network originally came together under the name Agenda Europe, holding yearly summits across the continent between 2013 until at least 2018, by which time it had grown to comprise 300 participants, including politicians and Vatican diplomats.

Related: â€˜This is realâ€™: in Oklahoma, a post-Roe world has arrived

The aim of the group was to â€œrestore the natural orderâ€ by devising ways to gradually erode abortion rights, gay rights and policies on combating violence against women, as well as to reduce access to contraceptives.

Organisers behind Agenda Europe summits included Terrence McKeegan, a former legal adviser to the Holy Seeâ€™s mission to the UN in New York, and Gudrun Kugler, a Catholic theologian, member of the Austrian parliament and human rights spokesperson for the Austrian Peopleâ€™s party.

â€œIt is a rather loose network that brought together all the different groups â€“ mostly from around Europe â€“ that identify themselves as pro-life or pro-family, so anti-abortion or anti-LGBT rights,â€ said Neil Datta, secretary of the European Parliamentary Forum for Sexual and Reproductive Rights who conducted an inquiry into the network and shared documents detailing the groupâ€™s aims, meeting programmes and participants.

â€œYou can see they started out trying to find their relevance, and by the third meeting they were actually coming up with proactive ideas about how to roll back human rights in sexuality and reproduction.â€

Today, people connected to Agenda Europe are linked to the Political Network of Values (PNfV), a global platform with strikingly similar values that sprung up as the formerâ€™s visibility appeared to diminish.

PNfV is hosting its fourth transatlantic summit â€“ which includes Kugler and other Agenda Europe personalities among the speakers â€“ in Budapest on Thursday and Friday.

When it comes to abortion rights, the network is allegedly seeking to replicate recent anti-choice efforts in the US, where rightwing activists have gradually manoeuvred people who share the same views into the judicial and political systems.

â€œTheyâ€™ll be really pumped up by the potential reversal of the Roe v Wade,â€ Datta added.

â€œFirstly, because it provides them with a model of one of the most advanced countries taking a position that conforms to their own thinking. But the US court is not responding to changes in society; this is the result of a 20- to 30-year strategy by the US Christian right to influence the whole American judicial system by training and placing its own people in the system.â€

The network is believed to have already made headway in Europe, including heavily influencing Polandâ€™s near-total ban on abortion as well as the outcome of same-sex marriage referendums in countries including Croatia, Romania and Slovenia.

Although abortion is legal in Hungary, the procedure has become more difficult to access under Viktor OrbÃ¡nâ€™s rightwing populist government.

Meanwhile, LGBT rights have been gradually eroded in the country over recent years. Last year the Hungarian parliament passed a law banning gay people from featuring in school educational materials or TV shows for under-18s, and in 2020 effectively banned adoption for same-sex couples and ended legal recognition for gender changes.

In Italy, the network is believed to have gained a foothold in 2019 when the country hosted a conference of the controversial World Congress of Families (WCF), a US Christian-right supported global coalition, in Verona.

Related: City of love? Christian right congress in Verona divides Italy

Matteo Salvini, leader of the far-right League, a key component of the Italian government, spoke at the event, as did his far-right counterpart, Giorgia Meloni, who leads Brothers of Italy, the party currently leading in opinion polls.

Since then, measures to restrict abortion â€“ such as banning health clinics from providing the abortion pill or allowing anti-abortion activists to infiltrate hospitals to pressure women not to end their pregnancy â€“ have been introduced in regions led by a coalition of the two parties and Silvio Berlusconiâ€™s Forza Italia, including Marche, Lombardy, Piedmont, Umbria and Veneto.

Moreover, even though abortion was legalised in Italy via a referendum in 1978, it has become increasingly difficult for women to access a safe procedure due to the high number of gynaecologists â€“ seven out of 10 â€“ who are â€œmoral objectorsâ€.

â€œWe know that the broader networkâ€™s strategy in relation to abortion is to first prevent, then restrict and ban,â€ said Datta.

â€œWhat weâ€™re seeing now in Hungary and in countries such as Italy are attempts to prevent abortion from ever taking place, through conscientious objection and ways of dissuading women.â€

Silvana Agatone, who until she retired was one of the few gynaecologists in Rome who carried out abortions, said: â€œItâ€™s getting worse in Italy. Weâ€™ve always had objectors but now the life of a doctor who does do abortions has been made more difficult as you have these anti-abortion people going into hospitals pressuring them, and women, not to abort.

â€œThey are also trying to rewrite medicine by paying people to produce material on the dangers of abortion that are purported to be scientific.â€

An influential politician with the League is Simone Pillon, who until his election as senator in March 2018 was an adviser on the board of Novae Terrae, an anti-abortion organisation headed by his close friend, Luca VolantÃ¨, a politician with the now defunct Union of the Centre party and former chairman of the parliamentary group of the European Peopleâ€™s party.

Novae Terrae was an integral player in Agenda Europe, at least until VolantÃ¨ was investigated for money laundering. VolantÃ¨ was recently cleared of the allegations.

Pillon said he is aware of Agenda Europe, which he described as akin â€œto a group of friends getting togetherâ€, but never attended any of its meetings.

Pillon has a 20-year history of close relationships with Italian anti-abortion groups and attended a large anti-abortion demonstration in Rome on Saturday.

â€œI am from the pro-life world and then I entered into politics to bring forward the voice of the pro-life associations,â€ he said.

Pillon said he was â€œenviousâ€ of the situation regarding Roe v Wade in US, adding that a similar outcome would arrive in Europe â€œsooner or laterâ€.

â€œIt was an ideological current that brought the liberalisation of abortion to the US in the 1970s, which then led to European legislation being adapted to this way of thinking,â€ said Pillon. â€œI am convinced this new wave will [unfold] in Europe. I donâ€™t know when, but I hope sooner rather than later.â€

Related: Trump shares CPAC Hungary platform with notorious racist and antisemite

With the coalition of the League, Brothers of Italy and Forza Italia standing a good chance of winning general elections next spring, he may soon have even more power to influence abortion policy.

Meanwhile, PNfV will continue to strive to make waves. The speaker lineup at the Budapest summit includes politicians from Hungary, Spain and Slovakia.

Hungarian speakers include MEPs from the ruling Fidesz party, such as Balazs Hidveghi and EnikÅ‘ GyÅ‘ri. Miklos SzÃ¡nthÃ³, the director of the Center for Fundamental Rights, who hosted CPAC Hungary last week, is also expected to speak, as is ZoltÃ¡n Balogh, a commissioner to prime minister OrbÃ¡n.

Hungaryâ€™s newly elected president and former families minister, Katalin NovÃ¡k, had been a board member of PNfV since as early as 2015 and became its chairperson in 2019.

However, she resigned from the role in March after being elected Hungarian president. In comments to Breitbart in 2019, she said there is no â€œchoiceâ€ when it comes to abortion. â€œPro-abortion is pro-killing, it is against choice,â€ she said.

results.webTitle: TV tonight: Jack Rookeâ€™s Big Boys is really beautiful television

fields.headline: TV tonight: Jack Rookeâ€™s Big Boys is really beautiful television
fields.trailText: Dylan Llewellyn and Jon Pointing star in the coming-of-age drama. Plus: Art That Made Us looks at post- second world war earthshakers. Hereâ€™s what to watch this evening
fields.body:
Big Boys

10pm, Channel 4

Based on creator Jack Rookeâ€™s coming-of-age years, this wonderful six-part comedy-drama will have you laughing then bawling in the opening two minutes. It follows Jack (a superbly cast Dylan Llewellyn as â€œa closeted mummyâ€™s boy with a newly dead dad and a crap permâ€). Despite not wanting to leave his mum, he takes the leap to university, where he shares accommodation with Danny (Jon Pointing) â€“ a mature student who wants a wingman for pulling â€œfit birdsâ€. Cue an unexpected friendship between the two as they support each other while navigating grief, sexuality and mental health issues. With Rooke narrating, this is really beautiful television. Hollie Richardson

The Flight Attendant

9pm, Sky Max

Kaley Cuoco returns as trouble-prone Cassie for a second season of this black comedy-drama. Cassie is now sober and in a good place as she continues to serve the skies. She is also casually moonlighting as a CIA agent in Berlin. Kicking off with a double bill tonight, she soon becomes entangled in another murder â€“ and the strain of it all could cause her to lapse back into drinking. HR

The Princeâ€™s Trust Awards

8.30pm, ITV

Last year, this ceremony â€“ celebrating the extraordinary achievements of young people â€“ was so emotional it drew tears from celebrity ambassadors such as Hugh Dennis, Richard E Grant and Kate Garraway. Expect similarly moving tales from this yearâ€™s event â€“ televised for the first time in its 17 years and hosted by Ant and Dec. HR

Art That Made Us

9pm, BBC Two

In the final part, lesser-sung British pop artist Pauline Boty features among the profiled post-second world war creatives, who shook up the old order. Lesley Sharp reads from A Taste of Honey, Liv Wynter hails Tracey Emin, and we meet photographer Charlie Phillips, who documented the changing community of 60s Notting Hill. Ali Catterall

The Staircase

9pm, Sky Atlantic

We return to 2001, and Thanksgiving has made ill-fated Kathleen anxious. Five tumultuous years later, film editor Sophie (a brilliant late-season entry by Juliette Binoche) begins following her own lead. If youâ€™ve kept up with this true crimeâ€™s multilayered structure, the narrative richness is really starting to pay off. Henry Wong

PRU

10pm, BBC Three

After last yearâ€™s pilot, this fractious sitcom, set in a pupil referral unit, returns for a four-episode run. Volatile fashionista Belle (Pia Somersby) and restless Halil (Jaye Ersavas) are among the excluded kids being schooled by harried teachers. The result is plausibly in-your-face, but with real sweetness beneath the classroom aggro. Graeme Virtue

Film choice

Suspicion, (Alfred Hitchcock, 1941), 9pm, BBC Four
Alfred Hitchcockâ€™s thriller was the first of four fruitful collaborations with Cary Grant, though itâ€™s the only one where his leading man plays a bit of a wrong â€™un. Grantâ€™s Johnnie is an eligible bachelor, though a bit â€œwildâ€ â€“ but for generalâ€™s daughter Lina (Joan Fontaine) he represents the excitement she canâ€™t find in her comfortable, rural life. However, after they elope, she realises he is an inveterate gambler and liar, heavily in debt and, she suspects, capable of murder â€“ for financial gain. Fontaine won an Oscar for her role, seesawing convincingly between bliss and fear. Simon Wardell

results.webTitle: Claes Bang: â€˜I did two whole plays entirely naked. I thought Iâ€™d done enoughâ€™

fields.headline: Claes Bang: â€˜I did two whole plays entirely naked. I thought Iâ€™d done enoughâ€™
fields.trailText: From spanking to swordfighting, why does the Dane have to keep stripping off? As he appears alongside Christopher Walken in Outlaws, the actor talks about dodgy directors, the joy of physical contact â€“ and his booming synth pop sideline
fields.body:
This spring, film fans and theatregoers got a lot of Claes Bang for their buck, with the brilliantly named Danish actor starring in two of the most talked-about offerings of the season. In The Northman, he was the evil FjÃ¶lnir the Brotherless, stealing the crown of his nephew Amleth (Alexander SkÃ¥rsgard). In â€œDaddyâ€, at the Almeida theatre in London, Bang played Andre, the gay billionaire art collector who struck up a relationship with a much younger, much poorer, emerging Black artist, and installed him in his Hollywood pad â€“ complete with a real pool that drenched the front row.

Bang infused both roles with sinister charm â€“ he was also, let us not forget, a superb Dracula on the BBC â€“ while exhibiting a very Scandinavian attitude to nudity. In The Northman, he was swordfighting in the buff, while at the Almeida, a small venue in which there is no hiding place, he and co-star Terique Jarrett ambled around completely nude for quite a while. â€œIâ€™ve done two plays where I was naked for the entirety,â€ he says. â€œI thought, â€˜Thatâ€™s it. Iâ€™ve done my naked duty. No more.â€™ But then I was approached for â€˜Daddyâ€™, loved everything about it, and it makes total sense that we are naked for that stretch of time.â€

I had a five-week break while shooting The Northman â€“ but they wouldnâ€™t let me leave

Bang is talking via Zoom from a cabin in the Danish countryside, which he and his wife, Lis Kasper, bought at the outset of the pandemic. â€œFrom Christmas 2020 to spring last year we were here 95% of the time,â€ he says, surveying an overgrown, deer-infested garden. â€œIt was a nightmare to be in Copenhagen â€“ thereâ€™s nothing worse than a city that is closed.â€

Bang says working on â€œDaddyâ€ was a much-needed antidote to The Northman, which was shot around Belfast before vaccines had been developed. If one actor had got the virus, the whole film would have been shut down.

â€œFilming during Covid has been a very alienating process,â€ he says. â€œFor one thing, I have not been able to really see the director because everyoneâ€™s in masks and visors. I think, in the street, Iâ€™d probably walk past 95% of the people I worked with on that movie, because I wouldnâ€™t be able to recognise them. Normally thereâ€™ll be a bit of socialising â€“ you go out for dinner or to a football game â€“ and we couldnâ€™t do that, either. In the middle, I had a five-week shooting break, so I asked if I could go back to the cabin. But they wouldnâ€™t let me leave.â€

Bang was overjoyed to get back to the hands-on world of theatre â€“ so much so that when the Almeida sent him an email saying he would have to be masked during rehearsals, he threatened to quit. â€œI said, â€˜Iâ€™m super happy to do your play, but if weâ€™re not allowed to work without masks in the rehearsal room, I will have to ask you to find someone else because that is exactly what I need.â€™ Itâ€™s become very clear to me during Covid that the contact thing is why Iâ€™m here.â€

There is certainly plenty of contact in â€œDaddyâ€: snogging, spanking, sodomy. â€œI thought it was important that we really got in there,â€ Bang says. â€œAnd I have to say, the director and the intimacy coordinator and Terique and I, we did a really good, very respectful job of getting that relationship to be as alive as I thought it was.â€ Bang is a big fan of intimacy coordinators, who guide actors through sex scenes movement by movement, with the agreement of everyone involved. He recently pulled out of a film that had three major explicit scenes because the director wouldnâ€™t employ a coordinator, saying: â€œI think theyâ€™re just in the way.â€

Bang explains: â€œIâ€™ve had directors back in the day who would say, â€˜OK, itâ€™s a sex scene. Thereâ€™s the bed, get undressed, do your thing and Iâ€™ll be filming it.â€™ But Iâ€™ll say, â€˜Um, but hey, excuse me, this will be far too private if you donâ€™t say what you want it to be.
