Should it be a tender or a rough thing? Dominant or messy?â€™ If youâ€™ve put the scene in the movie, you want to say something. It canâ€™t be just about seeing two people shagging.â€™â€

At 55, Bang is far too long in the tooth (and not just when wearing his Dracula fangs) to be pushed into doing something against his better judgment. After years as a jobbing actor in Denmark, five years ago he made an international breakthrough with The Square, which won the Palme dâ€™Or at Cannes. It stars Bang as an urbane art museum director who makes a succession of increasingly terrible decisions, from sleeping with a journalist played by Elisabeth Moss to commissioning a promotional video in which a toddler is blown up.

Itâ€™s a brilliant portrayal of the carelessness and weakness lurking within a middle-aged high flyer â€“ and it made Bang into a singular kind of star. Not many actors speak four languages fluently â€“ namely Danish, Swedish, German and English, which he speaks with an estuary-tinged accent that makes him sound a bit like David Bowie. Even fewer are touted by some journalists as possible Bonds, despite him being a grandad twice over.

Bang points out that in his wifeâ€™s family, everyone has children when theyâ€™re 20. â€œChildren have come into my life in a little bit of a weird way,â€ he says. â€œWhen I met my wife, aged 39, she had Bella who was eight and Sarah who was 19, and now Sarahâ€™s had two kids â€“ the youngest turned two a month ago and the older one just turned 13. I donâ€™t know how that happened but itâ€™s been a blessing. Itâ€™s probably been the best way of getting children into my life because for some reason I couldnâ€™t pull myself together and have some of my own.â€

The pandemic descended just as Bangâ€™s career was hitting full throttle â€“ he had three indie films out in 2020, each barely making it into the cinema. Now, however, he is back in business, as a villain in Stephen Merchantâ€™s The Outlaws, broadcast next month, in which he stars with Christopher Walken. â€œHe really makes a fool out of me, but he was lovely.â€ After that comes Bad Sisters, a series for Apple TV+ in which he plays Anne-Marie Duffâ€™s husband. As well as having a female showrunner, Sharon Horgan, and five female leads, all the directors on the show were women. â€œThe whole entertainment business is getting serious about diversity,â€ Bang says. â€œIâ€™m proud to be part of it.â€

Which brings us back to The Northman, whose whiteness, machismo and Norse mythological roots have seen it embraced by some extreme right-wingers. â€œI remember when the trailer came out around Christmas, there was this voiceover that says, â€˜You have to choose between kindness for your kin or hatred for your enemy.â€™ And I was like, â€˜Woah, wait a minute â€“ itâ€™s Donald Trump!â€™ If it is being used by white supremacist groups, I think thatâ€™s bloody horrible. It was not something I thought about when we were filming â€“ the script is based on the Danish story of Prince Amlet, the one that Shakespeare turned into perhaps the greatest play in the world.â€

Bang spent much of the time lurking in his trailer, either trying to avoid Covid or preparing for yet another of director Robert Eggersâ€™ many takes. There he indulged his other creative passion: music, which he releases under the name This Is Not America (and, sadly, not Claesâ€™ Bangers). Itâ€™s not half bad, particularly if you have a weakness for 80s electro pop. I tell Bang that Tale of a Broken Heart, on his new EP, reminds me of the Johnny Marr/Bernard Sumner supergroup Electronic. â€œOh my God!â€ he says. â€œThatâ€™s making me so proud. New Order, the Smiths, Pet Shop Boys â€“ thatâ€™s my DNA.â€

Related: Claes Bang: â€˜Could I do Bond? No, Iâ€™d be too oldâ€™

He finds music the perfect antidote to being ordered around by fussy directors. â€œIâ€™m my own boss â€“ I do the programming, the playing, the lyrics, the music. When you come home from a day of someone saying, â€˜Go stand over there and say these lines, do it in that light and blah blah blah,â€™ youâ€™re like, â€˜Shut the fuck up and let me go and do my own thing. Stop following me around!â€™â€

I suggest that Bang should play a few gigs, but he points out that his Spotify statistics arenâ€™t exactly giving Harry Styles sleepless nights. â€œIâ€™m not even sure, if I planned a gig, anyone would come. I probably have as many listeners per week as Billie Eillish has every 10 minutes.â€

  • Notes from a Saturday Afternoon at the End of the World by This Is Not America is out now. The Outlaws is on BBC1 in June and is streaming on Amazon Prime in Australia.

results.webTitle: When Harry met Harry! The man who put Harry Styles in a dress

fields.headline: When Harry met Harry! The man who put Harry Styles in a dress
fields.trailText: Stylist Harry Lambert is behind the singerâ€™s subversive, androgynous style and Emma Corrinâ€™s balloon bra, and has even convinced football clients to carry glittery pink handbags. He explains why fashion for men is changing
fields.body:
Walking down the narrow corridor towards stylist Harry Lambertâ€™s studio, I canâ€™t be the first person to wonder if Harry Styles â€“ Lambertâ€™s most famous client â€“ has trod the same blue carpet. Not that Lambert would tell me. Getting him to talk about Styles is like getting blood from a stone. â€œOK, look,â€ he says. â€œWhen it comes to questions about Harry, I just consider our relationship too private to go too deep. You have to remember I am there in the most intimate times with people I work with. Iâ€™m often the last person they see before they go on stage. Itâ€™s an intimate space! Iâ€™m aware that a lot of the attention I get is because of him, but I want to be very careful. But letâ€™s try. OK. Go.â€

Harry met Harry around the time of One Directionâ€™s 2014 album, Four. Rumours of a solo career were circulating, and Styles was going through his â€œJagger periodâ€, wearing black Saint Laurent suits, Chelsea boots and leonine hair tamed by bright bandanas â€“ fashion filtered through NME rather than GQ.

Lambert was mostly styling magazine shoots and fashion shows when they were introduced to each other. He presented a wardrobe (â€œplayful stuff, Gucci and JW Anderson, stuff like thatâ€), and Styles agreed to give it a whirl. What emerged is best described as 1970s man, resurrected â€“ flares, with a side of camp. Styles was always game, he says, â€œbut when it happened, it was still like: â€˜Fuck, this is wild.â€™â€

The fashion industry gobbled it up. From the sheer black blouse and single pearl earring at the 2019 Met Gala, to the tight crimson Arturo Obegero jumpsuit in the video to As It Was, Styles became mainstream popâ€™s most determined subverter of gender stereotypes.

Lambert has been central to this, a sort of Thomas Cromwell to Stylesâ€™s Henry VIII, but dissolving binaries instead of monasteries. Not that thatâ€™s how he sees it: â€œLook, when it comes to this [gender stuff], I wish I could be all: â€˜I wanted to change the world!â€™ But itâ€™s more that itâ€™s a byproduct of what weâ€™re doing,â€ he says. â€œIf you look at pop icons over the years, fashion is such an integral part of their image, like BjÃ¶rk in the swan dress, Britney in the schoolgirl outfit. Iâ€™m aware that what I do is having an impact, but is that top of the agenda for me? No.â€

Weâ€™re sitting on a bench in the communal garden behind his two-room studio in Hoxton, east London. In one room, platform shoes spill out of an Ikea Kallax unit. In the other, rails of clothes sit. Lambert, 35, is warm and chatty, with a gentle East Anglian accent and short bleached hair. Heâ€™s wearing wide-legged Marni trousers in chequerboard brown, large black pearls and a T-shirt lightly stained with breakfast.

Celebrity stylists are relatively new. In Hollywoodâ€™s golden age â€“ Lambertâ€™s favourite era â€“ actors were styled by costume designers from the studios. By the early 70s, the studio system was over, so stars dressed themselves, which didnâ€™t always go well (Google any Oscars ceremony in the 1980s).

It wasnâ€™t until the mid-00s and Rachel Zoe â€“ who turned her cadre (Paris Hilton, Lindsay Lohan) into avatars of her stick-thin self, and is rumoured to have commanded $10,000 a day â€“ that stylists became as famous as their clients.

Today, the red carpet is an economy unto itself, built on the (often false) idea that what celebrities wear is an extension of their personality rather than, say, a mutually beneficial marketing tool brokered between label, celebrity and stylist. No one knows how much money changes hands, but given that many celebrities require stylists as much off stage as on (the walking-to-the-car-holding-a-juice outfit, can be as considered as what is worn to the Grammys) the celebrity stylist has never been more powerful. Which explains why some of the big Hollywood ones â€“ Law Roach, say, who put Zendaya in a hot pink breastplate, or Karla Welch, who put Justin Bieber in extra-long sleeved T-shirts â€“ are household names, if you live in that sort of home.

Unusually for a stylist, Lambert has just four clients: Styles, Everton footballer Dominic Calvert-Lewin, and The Crown actors Emma Corrin and Josh Oâ€™Connor (each of whom has a body double who tries on outfits the day before). Lambert gets approached a lot, but usually says no. â€œI only style people who â€“ sorry to sound all LA â€“ I connect with, or who I can transform. I once styled Kylie [Minogue] â€“ but what do you even do with Kylie?â€

Itâ€™s reasonable to say that Oâ€™Connorâ€™s look is the most conventional. Standouts include a navy double-breasted sailor suit with ceramic buttons by SS Daley, worn to last yearâ€™s TV Baftas, â€œbut thereâ€™s always a little twist, or flourishâ€, says Lambert â€œIt can never be conventional â€“ I hate that.â€

Corrin, whom he met through a friend, came out as queer last year, and uses clothes to communicate this. â€œThereâ€™s a pressure on girls in acting to be sexy, to be a bombshell, to have [their] boobs out. Emma is sexy, but itâ€™s about playing with peopleâ€™s perceptions of what is beautiful,â€ says Lambert. I say the Loewe dress and balloon bra she wore to the Olivier awards in April certainly felt like an in-joke. â€œThe Oliviers are a bit stuffy, so we thought: â€˜Letâ€™s do something that most people arenâ€™t going to get,â€™â€ he says with a laugh. â€œItâ€™s a conversation, but in a dress. Even the Daily Mail loved it.â€

As with all stylistsâ€™ muses, there is an obligation to wear designers if they are linked with them â€“ Corrin was the face of Miu Miu, Styles of Gucci, and Oâ€™Connor of Loewe. But in using vintage pieces as well as pushing smaller designers such as Daley, Edward Crutchley and Harris Reed, whose gender-fluid designs have since ended up at the Met Gala, Lambert is attempting to redress the power balance.

Earlier this year, he turned down the chance to appear on the cover of The Hollywood Reporter. â€œI didnâ€™t get into this job to be on a [magazine] cover. Fashion is scary, fashion week is scary,â€ Lambert says. â€œThere are â€˜facesâ€™, like Anna Wintour, and then there are people like me.â€

But because of his job â€“ and because of social media â€“ he is a face of sorts. â€œSomeone took my picture on the bus and tagged me this week. So Iâ€™m famous to a particular group of people.â€ The Harrys have nicknames for each other (Lambert is Susan, and Styles is Sue) and the internet has fun with their relationship, with Reddit threads devoted to to unpacking what these names mean. Again, Lambert wonâ€™t comment, but it seems an efficient way to differentiate between two people called Harry.

Growing up in Norwich, Lambert was into clothes, not fashion. He cycled through trends familiar to a millennial (the skateboarding emo phase, the Abercrombie & Fitch ripped loose jeans phase) and, at school, drifted towards art. He studied photography at Rochester University and while he loved the narrative side, he tripped up on the technicalities, and instead spent his summers interning at various magazines.

He then moved to east London, just at the end of nu-rave. â€œI got into the industry right at the end, just after [the recession], when everyone had money, but also just before styling became a thing,â€ he says. He got work as a commercial stylist â€“ including a stint at fast fashion â€œfactoryâ€ Asos, and later Topman, but his Damascene moment was â€œbejewelling Little Bootsâ€™ roller skates on a shootâ€.

His most recent client is Calvert-Lewin, one of the few footballers who doesnâ€™t dress as if he has been vomited on by a bank. Last winterâ€™s Arena Homme+ cover, in which he wears a flared short suit and a glittery pink Prada handbag, was a blue-tick Lambert look â€“ high fashion with an androgynous twist. Is Lambert a football fan? â€œNo. I had to do half a season at Norwich City â€“ Delia Smithâ€™s team â€“ when I was a kid, but only to escort my little brother.â€

You only need to look at Little Richard, David Bowie or Prince to see that androgyny has been part of pop since the beginning. Yet in football, outward expressions of so-called femininity are few and far between. Is Lambert trying to drive a conversation about gender by introducing this fashion to the Premier League? Lambert laughs again. â€œI didnâ€™t bring the handbags to Dominic. He has three or four Chanel handbags of his own. But just because someone is a masculine straight guy in the football community, and has a handbag, it shouldnâ€™t be a big deal.â€ But it is a big deal, I say, in a good way. â€œOK, yeah, I understand how toxic the [football] industry can be, so to see a man with a Chanel handbag is â€¦ something. But everyone is trying to tap into that market,â€ he says of fashion and sport. â€œBack in the day, if you were into clothes you were gay. Now caring about how you look â€“ itâ€™s almost normal.â€

Itâ€™s unsurprising then that Gucci recently signed pomade-loving footballer Jack Grealish to front a future campaign. At the mention of his name, Lambert shifts around, then denies all knowledge of the signing. Iâ€™d put a tenner on him being involved.

â€œI think how men dress is changing,â€ he says. â€œThe Loewe aesthetic is going to be the next super-brand for youth in the way that Balenciaga and Vetements [two of the brands responsible for luxury logo streetwear] rewrote what was cool. You can see it happening.â€ To translate, Lambert means clothes that are pretty and surreal, logo-free knitwear and lots of colour. Like Stylesâ€™ famous rainbow cardigan â€“ effeminate and fun. â€œItâ€™s the vibe shift, yeah.â€

â€œWhen Iâ€™m gone,â€ Lambert says, â€œI just hope itâ€™s silly things such as putting Harry [Styles] in pearls and that men can wear necklaces and it not be a thing â€“ thatâ€™s the stuff I want to be remembered for. That and when people dress up as Harry for Halloween.â€ He claps his hands. â€œIt means that weâ€™ve done something that has had cultural impact. It means weâ€™ve got through.â€

results.webTitle: Microplastics in sewage: a toxic combination that is poisoning our land | George Monbiot

fields.headline: Microplastics in sewage: a toxic combination that is poisoning our land
fields.trailText: Policy failure and a lack of enforcement have left our waterways and farmland vulnerable to â€˜forever chemicalsâ€™, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
fields.body:
We have recently woken up to a disgusting issue. Rather than investing properly in new sewage treatment works, water companies in the UK â€“ since they were privatised in 1989 â€“ have handed Â£72 bn in dividends to their shareholders. Our sewerage system is antiquated and undersized, and routinely bypassed altogether, as companies allow raw human excrement to pour directly into our rivers. They have reduced some of them to stinking, almost lifeless drains.

This is what you get from years of policy failure and the near-collapse of monitoring and enforcement by successive governments. Untreated sewage not only loads our rivers with excessive nutrients, but itâ€™s also the major source of the microplastics that now pollute them. It contains a wide range of other toxins, including PFASs: the â€œforever chemicalsâ€ that were the subject of the movie Dark Waters. This may explain the recent apparent decline in otter populations: after recovering from the organochlorine pesticides used in the 20th century, they are now being hit by new pollutants.

Related: Microplastics found deep in lungs of living people for first time

But hereâ€™s a question scarcely anyone is asking: what happens when our sewerage system works as intended? What happens when the filth is filtered out and the water flowing out of sewage treatment plants is no longer hazardous to life? I stumbled across the answer while researching my book, Regenesis, and Iâ€™m still reeling from it. When the system works as it is meant to, it is likely to be just as harmful as it is when bypassed by unscrupulous water companies. Itâ€™s an astonishing and shocking story, but it has hardly been touched by the media.

We are often told that the microplastics entering the sewage system, which come from tyre crumb washing off the roads, the synthetic clothes we wear and many other sources, are a wicked problem, almost impossible to solve. But a modern, well-run sewage treatment works removes 99% of these fibres from wastewater. So far, so good. But â€“ and at this point you may wish to decide whether to laugh or cry â€“ having screened them out of the water supply, the treatment companies then release them back into the wild. In the UK, of the sewage sludge screened out by treatment works, 87% is sent to farms. The microplastics so carefully removed from wastewater by the treatment process are then spread across the land in the sewage sludge the water companies sell to farmers as fertiliser.

Then what happens to them? Some â€“ perhaps most â€“ wash off the soil and into the rivers: in other words, whether sewage is screened or not, the microplastics it contains end up in the same place. Others accumulate in the soil.

Itâ€™s hard to decide which is worse. Experiments show how microplastics cascade through soil food webs, poisoning some of the animals that inhabit it. When they decompose into nanoparticles, they can be absorbed by soil fungi and accumulated by plants. We currently have no idea what the consequences of eating these contaminated crops might be.

The testing of sewage sludge has not been updated since 1989, so there is no checking for plastic particles or most other synthetic chemicals. A study commissioned but then kept secret by the government found that the sewage sludge being spread on our farmland contains a remarkable cocktail of dangerous substances, including PFASs, benzo(a)pyrene (a group 1 carcinogen), dioxins, furans, PCBs and PAHs, all of which are persistent and potentially cumulative.

Where did they come from? Because our waste streams are not separated and poorly regulated, anywhere and everywhere. The major source of PFASs in sewage is probably the building trade. â€œForever chemicalsâ€ are found in paints, sealants and coatings, caulks, adhesives and roofing materials. Evidence sent to me by an industry insider suggests that regulators the world over turn a blind eye to liquid waste disposal on construction sites. Tools are washed and surfaces sprayed with water thatâ€™s then poured down the drain. Without regulation, contractors have no incentive to use technologies that ensure liquid waste is contained. Why go to this expense if your competitors donâ€™t have to?

Related: Raw sewage â€˜pumped into English bathing waters 25,000 times in 2021â€™

Could this story get any worse? Oh yes. Microplastics are sometimes spread deliberately on the soil by farmers, to make it more friable. Across Europe, thousands of tonnes of plastic are also added to fertilisers, to prevent them from caking; or to delay the release of the nutrients they contain. Fertiliser pellets are coated with plastic films â€“ polyurethane, polystyrene, PVC, polyacrylamide and other synthetic polymersÂ­â€“ some of which are known to be toxic and all of which disintegrate into microplastics. It is almost unbelievable that the deliberate contamination of agricultural soils with persistent and cumulative pollutants is both widespread and legal.

This practice, as well as the spreading of contaminated sewage sludge, urgently needs to be stopped, before large tracts of farmland become unusable, and the damage to ecosystems, from soil to sea, irreversible. Itâ€™s tragic that the nutrients in sewage sludge canâ€™t safely be used, but it seems to me that thereâ€™s no immediate solution, in our dysfunctional system, but to incinerate it. Only when toxic, accumulating chemicals are banned, waste streams separated and proper tests conducted will sewage be safe to spread.

Right now we are poisoning the land and, in all likelihood, poisoning ourselves. It could turn out to be one of the most deadly issues of all. And hardly anyone knows.

  • George Monbiot will discuss his book Regenesis at a Guardian Live event on Monday 30 May. Book tickets in-person or online here

  • George Monbiot is a Guardian columnist

results.webTitle: Unexpected influx of striped hawkmoths hits southern England

fields.headline: Unexpected influx of striped hawkmoths hits southern England
fields.trailText: Favourable winds that have swept in superstar of the moth world have also brought painted ladies
fields.body:
Hawkmoths are the plump-bodied superstars of the moth world, and the last two weeks have seen a notable invasion by one migratory species.

The striped hawkmoth is pale greeny-brown, with vivid pink underwings and pale stripes over its luxuriantly furred body and wings.

A handful are usually spotted each summer but this year up to a dozen are being found in a single (humane) moth light trap set by enthusiasts, particularly in south-west England. For many keen â€œmoth-ersâ€, these individuals are their first sightings.

The favourable winds that swept in this welcome visitor have also brought painted ladies, the powerful migratory species that will fly â€“ usually via several generations â€“ from sub-Saharan Africa to northern Europe every summer.

Both species can breed successfully in Britain â€“ moth fans will be scouring rosebay willowherb (and many other garden plants) for striped hawkmoth caterpillars in a few weekâ€™s time â€“ but are unlikely to survive winter.

For many years, the painted lady was assumed to have hit a cul-de-sac in Britain because its offspring were never spotted leaving at summerâ€™s end. Then radar revealed that the British-born ladies soar high into the air column to utilise winds to speed southwards to warmer climes where they can reproduce once again.

results.webTitle: NHS performs worldâ€™s first double hand transplant for scleroderma

fields.headline: NHS performs worldâ€™s first double hand transplant for scleroderma
fields.trailText: Roof tiler whose hands were left unusable by autoimmune disease says surgery gave him â€˜new lease of lifeâ€™
fields.body:
A roof tiler whose hands were left unusable by an autoimmune disease has told of his joy after NHS surgeons successfully performed the worldâ€™s first double hand transplant for the condition.

Steven Gallagher was forced to stop working after scleroderma, a condition that scars the skin and internal organs, caused his hands to close up into a fist position. After first developing an unusual rash about 13 years ago, the condition then affected his nose and mouth, his fingers began curling in and he suffered â€œhorrendousâ€ pain.

But after undergoing a 12-hour operation at Leeds teaching hospital NHS trust â€“ the first time anywhere in the world that hand transplantation has been used to replace hands terminally affected by scleroderma â€“ he can turn on the tap and fill a glass of water for the first time in years. Gallagher, 48, is now hoping to return to work.

â€œAfter the operation I woke up and it was quite surreal because before it I had my hands and then when I woke up from the operation I still had hands so in my head I never really lost any hands,â€ he said. â€œThese hands are amazing, everything has happened so quickly. From the moment I woke up from the operation I could move them.â€

Gallagher spent about four weeks in Leeds general infirmary after the operation in December 2021, and has regular visits to hospitals in Glasgow for physiotherapy and monitoring. His condition is improving more than five months on from the operation, and although he cannot do tasks requiring great dexterity such as doing up buttons, the father of three can do things like stroke his familyâ€™s dog.

â€œIt has given me a new lease of life,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™m still finding things hard just now but things are getting better every week with the physio and the occupational therapists, everything is just slowly getting better. The pain is the big thing. The pain before the operation was horrendous, I was on so much pain relief it was unbelievable, but now Iâ€™ve no pain at all.â€

When experts first suggested the idea of a double hand transplant, Gallagher, from Dreghorn in North Ayrshire, initially dismissed the idea. But he subsequently decided to go ahead despite the risks â€“ and is grateful to the person and family of the donor who made the transplant possible.

â€œMy hands started to close, it got to the point where it was basically two fists, my hands were unusable, I couldnâ€™t do a thing apart from lift things with two hands,â€ he recalled. â€œI could not grab anything, it was a struggle to get dressed and things like that.

â€œWhen Prof Hart in Glasgow mentioned to me about a double hand transplant, at the time I laughed and thought thatâ€™s space-age kind of things â€¦ My wife and I spoke about it and came to the agreement to go for it. I could end up losing my hands anyway, so it was just a case of letting them know I was going to go with it.â€

Prof Simon Kay, of Leeds teaching hospitals NHS trust, said the surgery was â€œa huge team effortâ€ with as many as 30 health professionals involved.

â€œHaving a hand transplant is very different from a kidney or other organ transplant, as hands are something we see every day and we use them in so many ways,â€ Kay said. â€œFor this reason, we and our expert clinical psychologists assess and prepare patients, in order to be sure that they will be able to cope psychologically with the permanent reminder of their transplant, and the risk the body may reject the transplanted hands.â€

results.webTitle: Ministry of Defence contractors â€˜drop standardsâ€™ to boost profits, MPs warn

fields.headline: Ministry of Defence contractors â€˜drop standardsâ€™ to boost profits, MPs warn
fields.trailText: Highly critical committee report says MoD should consider retaining firefighting and ancillary services in house
fields.body:
Outsourcing companies working for the Ministry of Defence â€œdrop standards and squeeze employeesâ€ to boost profits during the lifetime of their contracts, a committee of MPs has warned in a highly critical report.

The MoD should instead consider retaining firefighting and other ancillary services in house, the committee said â€“ and take into account the previous behaviour of companies chasing lucrative contracts.

â€œThe MoDâ€™s outsourcing practice is not exemplary,â€ the committee concludes. â€œContractors drop standards and squeeze employees to raise their profit margin, but the MoD is not always willing to step in,â€ the cross party committee concludes.

Particular criticism is reserved for Capita, a major outsourcing firm, whose handling of the Defence Fire and Rescue Service (DFRS) is analysed. The company took over responsibility for nearly half of the specialist firefighters in July 2019, after winning a 12 year contract priced at Â£525m.

The number of firefighters based at Faslane, the Trident nuclear submarine base in Scotland, had fallen significantly since privatisation, the MPs added. A total of 38 out of 524 had left on a voluntary basis as of last December, and further 150 had asked to be allowed to quit.

â€œWe find these figures surprising,â€ the committee concluded. â€œWhilst Capita argue that its job retention rate is â€˜goodâ€™, the number of voluntary exits suggests that there may be more than meets the eye.â€

Mark Francois, a Conservative MP, added that the government should change the law in the forthcoming procurement bill to allow ministers to consider â€œa bidderâ€™s past performanceâ€ when awarding contracts in future.

The former junior defence minister has been a persistent critic of Capita, and has called for the company to be stripped of its contract to supply army recruitment. â€œThe performance of certain sub-contractors is well known both within industry and the defence community,â€ Francois added.

Army recruitment has been handled jointly by Capita and the British army since 2012. But performance has been mixed: targets were missed in six years out of eight, the army remained below its 82,050 official requirement and the website was offline for weeks in the spring after an apparent leak of data belonging to 120 recruits.

The committee also complained that staff terms and conditions were sometimes eroded once a service had been privatised. Defence firefighters employed by Capita had 27 daysâ€™ holiday compared to 30 in the MoD.

Capita said its record of delivery on the DFRS contract was strong, and the company had met all of its targets. Recommendations over staffing levels â€œat any MoD site have to be endorsed by the MoD, and ultimately approved by the individual siteâ€™s military leadership team,â€ a spokesperson added.

A MoD spokesperson said outsourcing was used to deliver â€œmaximum valueâ€ for taxpayers. â€œOur contracts ensure that staff are paid fairly and contracted ancillary staff often have training and career prospects superior to an in-house service,â€ they added.

results.webTitle: MSC orders inquiry into shark finning on tuna vessels in the Pacific

fields.headline: MSC orders inquiry into shark finning on tuna vessels in the Pacific
fields.trailText: Campaigners report incidents of the cruel practice on several certified boats, amid allegations of a flawed auditing system
fields.body:
The Marine Stewardship Council, which certifies fisheries under its blue tick sustainability label, has ordered an independent investigation into allegations of shark finning on tuna vessels in certified Pacific fisheries.

Shark finning is the cruel practice of removing fins from live sharks. A report by the UK charity Shark Guardian with CNS Global Consulting, a sustainable development consultancy, has alleged it took place on board three vessels operating in the western central Pacific that were certified by the MSC, which runs the worldâ€™s largest fishery certification programme.

Official documents from independent observers who monitor fishery compliance, seen by the Guardian, said shark finning happened on board vessels in MSC-certified fisheries in 2019 and early 2020. They reported silky sharks and a black-tipped reef shark as having â€œDFRâ€ or â€œdiscarded fins retainedâ€, a reference to the practice of cutting fins off live animals and discarding their bodies overboard. Both species are classified as â€œnear threatenedâ€ with extinction by the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

A third of shark and ray species have been overfished to near extinction, a study found last year.

Despite documented evidence, little action was taken to prevent the boats from operating under the MSC banner, the charity said, nor was anyone prosecuted.

There is no suggestion the MSC was aware of the observer reports that alleged shark finning. However, the MSCâ€™s third-party certification boards â€“ known as conformity assessment bodies (Cabs) â€“ which audit fisheries and read observer reports, have a duty to remove certification if shark finning is detected, or if a vessel is convicted for it. This duty was strengthened in September 2020 to require â€œzero toleranceâ€ of shark finning, the MSC said.

Jean-Jacques Schwenzfeier, director of CNS Global Consulting, said: â€œThe observers told us their reports are constantly being ignored and shark finners are not being prosecuted.

â€œWe are not saying the MSC is a bad programme. The MSC is probably unaware this is happening. But the auditing system is flawed and needs improving.â€

A spokesperson for the MSC said it took the allegations â€œseriouslyâ€ and had asked Assurance Services International, which oversees Cabs, to investigate.

Related: European countries dominate half of Asian shark fin trade, report reveals

â€œShark finning is completely prohibited in MSC-certified fisheries and we take the allegations contained in the Shark Guardian report, relating to vessels fishing in the western central Pacific, seriously. On receiving notification of this report via the media, we immediately asked the independent oversight body, Assurance Services International, which oversees our third-party certification activities, to investigate the claims relating to shark finning and the other matters raised in the report.â€

Any vessel convicted of shark finning is banned from MSC certification for at least two years, it said.

The MSC has come under pressure from conservation groups to reform standards on shark finning, and is now proposing new standards. Earlier this month, 90 marine conservation experts, organisations and international researchers welcomed the MSCâ€™s move towards zero tolerance of shark finning by requiring all catch to have â€œfins naturally attached (FNA)â€ without exemptions.

results.webTitle: Refugees being sent to areas of UK with little or no legal aid, study finds

fields.headline: Refugees being sent to areas of UK with little or no legal aid, study finds
fields.trailText: People are missing out on immigration status they are entitled to because of shortfall, says reportâ€™s author
fields.body:
Refugees fleeing violence and persecution, including those who face being deported to Rwanda, risk being denied expert advice because many areas of the UK have little or no legal aid provision for people seeking asylum, a major report has found.

The study found that some towns and cities to which people seeking asylum are dispersed, including Plymouth, Stoke and Hull, had only one legal aid caseworker, while another, Swindon, had one provider with a legal aid contract but provided no provision because it could not recruit a caseworker.

The 257-page report, commissioned by Refugee Action, also found that there was no provision in most of North Yorkshire. A reception centre is being developed there in Linton-on-Ouse for people seeking asylum who are not sent to Rwanda under the governmentâ€™s New Plan for Immigration.

It concluded that every region in the UK bar London had a huge shortfall in access to free legal advice.

Tim Naor Hilton, the chief executive of Refugee Action, said: â€œItâ€™s hugely concerning that accessing justice is so difficult at a time when the government is tearing up its legal obligations to refugees.

â€œPeople who do not get advice are put at a huge disadvantage when their claim for asylum is being assessed.

â€œToo many errors are already made on asylum decisions. With refugees being sent to remote accommodation centres, 5,000 miles away to Rwanda, or home to face violence and persecution, itâ€™s vital they can get legal advice.â€

The charity says the lack of access is particularly concerning in light of the rise in the number of people waiting on an initial asylum claim, from 65,000 at the end of 2020 to 100,500 at the end of last year. Additionally, almost half of appeals against negative asylum decisions were successful last year.

Local authority areas including Cumbria, Durham, Gloucestershire, Somerset, Surrey, West Sussex, Norfolk, Suffolk, Essex, and Lincolnshire were found to have no provision at all, while there was a near-total lack of legal aid professionals along the south coast.

Unaccompanied asylum-seeking children were already being sent to local authorities in some of these â€œlegal aid desertsâ€, the report found.

Stoke-on-Trent â€“ a local authority with an agreement to take people seeking asylum â€“ was said to be facing â€œan especially severe shortage of legal aid and other provision, within a context of high demand from asylum dispersal and other migration and high levels of socio-economic deprivation, which affects both their ability to recruit and retain staff and their would-be clientsâ€™ ability to access servicesâ€.

While Scotland was found to have good provision for asylum legal aid, it was very limited for other types of immigration case â€“ which are generally excluded from legal aid in England and Wales â€“ and there was almost no provision outside Glasgow.

Dr Jo Wilding, a legal aid expert who authored the report after collecting data last year, said the deficit in legal aid â€œmeans that people are missing out on refugee status or immigration status that theyâ€™re entitled toâ€.

She made several recommendations to relieve demand on legal aid, including streamlining the asylum system and routes to settlement and abandoning hostile environment policies.

A government spokesperson said: â€œAll asylum seekers in the UK, including those being considered for relocation under our partnership with Rwanda, have access to legal aid and we spent Â£30m on this last year.

â€œProtecting the most vulnerable will always be our top priority and through our Nationality and Borders Act we will ensure a firm but fair system, so we can better support those in genuine need of asylum through safe and legal routes.â€

results.webTitle: Boris Johnson to try to oust Lady Scotland from Commonwealth role

fields.headline: Boris Johnson to try to oust Lady Scotland from Commonwealth role
fields.trailText: PM accused of abuse of position with public backing for Jamaican candidate before summit next month
fields.body:
Prince Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall are likely to witness an unseemly showdown at the Commonwealth conference in Rwanda next month when Boris Johnson tries to oust Patricia Scotland as secretary general of the Commonwealth.

The UK has been working behind the scenes for nearly two years to remove Lady Scotland, claiming she has not modernised the institution, and last week the prime minister publicly stated he was supporting a rival to Scotland.

Johnson said â€œthe UKâ€ supported the candidacy of the Jamaican minister of foreign affairs, Kamina Johnson Smith, for her â€œvast experience and support to unite our unique family of nations and seize opportunities aheadâ€.

Supporters of Scotland claim that Johnsonâ€™s backing of one candidate, at a time when the UK is supposed to be the neutral scrutiniser of the election process, is an abuse of his position and has compromised the UKâ€™s role.

The shadow foreign secretary, David Lammy, criticised Johnsonâ€™s intervention, saying: â€œThe chair of the Commonwealth is supposed to maintain neutrality and confidentiality. No chair has ever done this in the Commonwealth history. Itâ€™s unseemly and divisive.â€

Scotland, a Labour-appointed peer, would be expected to retain her role if a simple majority of the 54 Commonwealth states do not vote to remove her, and only otherwise should other candidates be considered for the role of administering the 54-member Commonwealth.

Scotlandâ€™s supporters say at present they are confident there is not a majority in favour of her dismissal, and claim resentment has grown at what could be regarded as a divisive approach.

Related: Caribbean leader warns against challenge to Commonwealth secretary general

One Commonwealth source said: â€œAgainst all the conventions of the Commonwealth, the UK has spent huge amounts of time and money trying to depose Scotland. What they do not seem to realise is that the rest of the Commonwealth can see what they are doing.â€

The election is due to take place at the Commonwealth summit in Kigali between 20 and 26 June.

Regardless of the outcome, Scotland is expected to stand down at the next Commonwealth conference, in two yearsâ€™ time, when her second four-year term will have expired. It is normal, but not a rule, that a secretary general is handed a second four-year term.

Johnsonâ€™s statement of support for Johnson Smith is likely to ensure most of the big Commonwealth states, such as Australia and Canada, come out in support of Jamaica so to appease the UK. The Caribbean states are now divided on who to back.

Scotland has done a lot in office to support the island states, and will be hoping for support from them, as well as from African countries that may feel it was their continentâ€™s turn to supply the next secretary general.

Johnson Smith in her campaign literature does not give a specific reason why Scotland should be removed, instead focusing on her own considerable experience as a commercial lawyer, trade negotiator and minister.

Scotland was born in Dominica and lived and worked in the UK before becoming attorney general in the Labour government led by Gordon Brown.

In 2021, Caricom, the 15-strong Caribbean umbrella body, took the unified position to support Scotlandâ€™s completion of a second term as secretary general, although it is known that some members opposed Scotland.

Antigua and Barbudaâ€™s PM Gaston Browne, a former Caricom chair, described Jamaicaâ€™s surprise bid as a â€œmonumental errorâ€, but Jamaica said it had the right to make its own sovereign decisions.

Scotlandâ€™s leadership has been under the microscope since it was revealed that she had circumvented the customary competitive tendering requirement by awarding a consultancy contract to a friendâ€™s company.

Scotlandâ€™s backers say audits have given her a clean bill of health and that her decision to award the contract complied with procurement procedures at the time.

results.webTitle: Country diary: In the dead of night, my garden comes alive

fields.headline: Country diary: In the dead of night, my garden comes alive
fields.trailText: Langstone, Havant: Unbeknownst to me, a whole soap opera was carrying on â€“ with six hedgehogs in the â€˜wild cornerâ€™
fields.body:
After two years of camera trapping in my garden, Iâ€™ve come to realise that thereâ€™s no such thing as a typical night. Even so, it still came as a surprise to play the first file on my most recent recording and see six hedgehogs congregating in the â€œwild cornerâ€ â€“ a 2m x 2m square of unmown, wildflower-rich grass, bordered by elder, sloe, bramble and honeysuckle.

Four were busy foraging for invertebrates, while one rotund male attempted to court a petite female, huffing and snorting as he circled her. Another suitor trundled over and the two boars squared up to each other, while the female scurried off into the undergrowth.

For almost five hours, the hedgehogs repeatedly triggered the camera as they fed, fought, and pursued potential mates. At 1.42am, two of the three individuals on screen simultaneously turned their attention towards the side gate, then scarpered in the opposite direction. A few seconds later, a lithe dog fox sauntered up to the bird table, flinching when he found himself faced with a ball of bristling spines. After a brief standoff, the hedgehog continued eating, unperturbed by the fox darting in and out to snatch titbits from his bowl.

After the fox departed, I noticed something had appeared on the lawn. Initially, I dismissed it as a fallen twig â€“ only, the twig moved. Maximising the screen, I could just make out four splayed limbs and a paddle-like tail swishing from side to side as the creature â€“ now identifiable as a smooth newt â€“ clambered through the long grass.

At 3.39am, a wood mouseâ€™s eyes glowed like tiny car headlights from behind a clump of teasels. Hopping out of the shadows, it dodged a perambulating hedgehog and slipped beneath the bird table in search of spilt seeds. Silently, a silver-rosetted Bengal cat leapt down from the fence and crouched low, every muscle tensed. It crept forward, laser-focused on its quarry. Pressing its paws into the ground and wiggling its hindquarters, it sprang towards the bird table, just as the recording cut off. I opened the next clip with trepidation, my finger hovering over the â€œplayâ€ button.

â€¢ Country Diary is on Twitter at @gdncountrydiary

results.webTitle: Major New Zealand salmon producer shuts farms as warming waters cause mass die-offs

fields.headline: Major New Zealand salmon producer shuts farms as warming waters cause mass die-offs
fields.trailText: Up to 42% of companyâ€™s fish have died in warm water areas this year, with CEO warning climate change is â€˜faster than people thinkâ€™
fields.body:
New Zealandâ€™s biggest king salmon farmer says it is shutting some of its farms after warming seas prompted mass die-offs of fish, warning that it is a â€œcanary in the coalmineâ€ for climate change.

New Zealand is the worldâ€™s largest producer of king, or â€œchinookâ€ salmon, a highly valued breed which fetches a premium on the world market. The countryâ€™s farms account for about 85% of global supply, New Zealand King Salmon chief executive Grant Rosewarne said.

Now, increasingly warm summer seas mean the fish at some sites are dying en masse before they can reach maturity, leaving farmers dumping thousands of tonnes of dead fish into local landfills.

â€œThere should be alarm bells,â€ Rosewarne said. â€œWhen I joined this company, I never heard of the term â€˜marine heatwaveâ€™â€¦. Recently, thereâ€™s been three of them.

â€œWe thought we had more time,â€ Rosewarne said. â€œClimate change is a slow process but faster than many people think â€“ certain industries are â€¦ canaries in the coalmine.â€

Related: Salmon farming harming marine life and costing billions in damage

â€œWe thought that climate change is a really slow effect, detected over decades â€“ and possibly weâ€™ve got, two decades before weâ€™re even impacted. Well, within one decade we were impacted.â€

Itâ€™s considered usual for a small percentage of farmed fish to die each year, but warming temperatures have significantly increased those deaths. In 2022, the King Salmon Companyâ€™s â€œpercentage mortality of biomassâ€ for the fish was up to 42% in warm water areas where the fish were not towed to cooler zones; compared to 17% in 2018. Even when the fish were towed out to cooler waters, many were dying: 37% in 2022, compared to just 10% in 2018.

Over the summer months, hotter water temperatures, heated by warm currents coming down from the coral sea, had pushed some of the farmed populations over the edge. â€œWe see [temperatures] elevated by a full degree â€“ I know that doesnâ€™t sound much to people, but a full degree is huge for our species,â€ he said. â€œIf you get to 18 degrees for two weeks, then you have a mass mortality event on your hands.â€

According to RNZ, trucks taking dead fish out of the area had dumped 1,269 tonnes of dead fish and waste in Blenheimâ€™s landfill over the summer â€“ 632 tonnes in February alone, seven times last year and up from the 194 tonnes dumped in February 2020.

Now, New Zealand King Salmon will â€œfallowâ€ three of its farms in the warmer Pelorus sound area, keeping just one open to run trials. The company is hoping to be allowed consents from the government for water space where it can farm the fish in cooler waters.

results.webTitle: Russian mercenaries accused over use of mines and booby traps in Libya

fields.headline: Russian mercenaries accused over use of mines and booby traps in Libya
fields.trailText: Exclusive: UN investigators say Wagner Group fighters did not mark minesâ€™ positions and may have rigged bomb to teddy bear
fields.body:
Russian mercenaries in Libya systematically broke international law by laying mines in civilian areas without any attempt to mark their location or remove the lethal devices, UN investigators have found.

According to a confidential UN report that will be made public in the coming weeks, fighters from the Wagner Group, a private military company that has been repeatedly linked to the Kremlin by western officials, also rigged booby traps to powerful explosive anti-tank weapons that were responsible for the death of two mine clearers working for an NGO.

Investigators suspect that a booby trap found in a civilian neighbourhood in Tripoli â€“ made of a mortar shell and plastic explosive attached to a teddy bear â€“ was also the work of Wagner fighters.

The conclusions of the report, by a specialist team that works for a UN committee charged with monitoring the sanctions regime and arms embargo on Libya, will reinforce growing concern in western capitals about the role played by Wagner across Africa.

Related: Russian mercenaries linked to civilian massacres in Mali

Last month the Guardian revealed that internal military memos in Mali linked Wagner to a series of massacres there. Wagner has also been accused of human rights abuses in Central African Republic, where in recent months its fighters have been battling rebels on behalf of the government.

Alleged Wagner group fighters have also been accused of murdering civilians during the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

Sergei Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, recently admitted that Wagner was present in Libya on a â€œcommercial basisâ€ but reiterated Moscowâ€™s official position that the company has nothing to do with the Russian state.

Experts believe there are about 2,000 Russian mercenaries in Libya, 1,000 fewer than at the peak of fighting two years ago.

The UN report seen by the Guardian covers 13 months from March 2021 to April 2022, though the accusation that Wagner indiscriminately used mines in civilian areas dates back to when the groupâ€™s fighters supported the advance on Tripoli launched by Gen Khalifa Haftar, a former Libyan army commander who controls much of the east of the country.

The attack stalled on the outskirts of the Libyan capital in early 2020, where Wagner fighters laid large numbers of powerful anti-personnel and anti-tank mines to defend their positions.

Under international law, Wagner should have marked the positions of mines, warned the local population and removed the mines when they withdrew after several weeks later. Failing to do so constitutes a war crime, according to the Geneva conventions.

The panel found that Wagner operatives took no such precautions when they laid 35 anti-personnel mines in civilian areas of the Ain Zara municipality. â€œThis failure to avoid, or at least to minimise, incidental effects of the deployed ordnance on the civilian population â€¦ rendered their method of warfare unlawful,â€ the report says.

Shortly after the withdrawal of Wagner from their positions in Ain Zara, a booby-trapped mine killed two civilian mine clearers. â€œThe device was unmarked and attached to a harmless object inside a civilian house,â€ the report says.

Investigators also found that Wagner operatives made no attempt to follow international law when they laid booby-trapped anti-tank mines along a road in southern Tripoli likely to be used by civilians after their withdrawal.

Some of the investigatorsâ€™ conclusions were based on a tablet left by Wagner when they withdrew. The device was obtained by journalists and examined by the UN team.

The tablet stored a 10-page document from January 2020, which included a list of the weapons and equipment required for various sub-units within Wagner in Libya and codenames of senior Wagner staff. These include a â€œdirector generalâ€ who the investigators identify as â€œhighly probably Yevgeny Prigozhinâ€, a businessman with close links to Vladimir Putin. Prigozhin has denied to the Guardian that he has any links with Wagner.

The report portrays an anarchic, divided country rife with human rights abuses by a multitude of different actors, 11 years after the Nato-backed overthrow of Muammar Gaddafi.

Libya has been divided since 2014 between the internationally recognised government in the west and Haftarâ€™s forces, a conflict exacerbated by a proxy war between regional and other powers. Haftar is supported by the United Arab Emirates and Russia, while the government is backed by Turkey.

Though there has been no sustained fighting for almost two years, the activities of dozens of armed groups, criminal networks and mercenaries continues to destabilise neighbouring countries.

â€œThe continuing presence of Chadian, Sudanese and Syrian fighters, and private military companies in the country is still a serious threat to the security of Libya and the region,â€ the report says.

The relative calm established since summer 2020 was due to an â€œexperimental ententeâ€ between Russia and Turkey, and has allowed Russia to use its military presence to consolidate economic interests and strategic use of Libya as a launchpad for efforts in the Sahel region farther south.

â€œIt was quite messy to start with but once you have that, both nations could see if a more peaceful Libya was more useful to them and the answer was yes â€¦ But the picture is not static and the calm is now more fragile,â€ said Jalel Harchaoui, a Paris-based independent expert specialising in Libya.

The arms embargo imposed by the UN security council on Libya is â€œtotally ineffectiveâ€ and â€œhas no deterrent effectâ€, the UN investigators believe.

The forthcoming report lists at least 175 Russian Federation military flights carrying nearly 10,000 tonnes of cargo between 1 May 2021 and 31 March 2022, which Moscow said comprised â€œhumanitarian assistance to Libya, including the supply of vaccines against Covid-19â€.

This response was met with scepticism from investigators. â€œUN agencies have neither observed, nor heard of, any large quantity of humanitarian aid from the Russian Federation being supplied to, or distributed in, eastern Libya. No humanitarian aid has been identified from satellite imagery or ground reports in the aircraft unloading areas,â€ the report says.

results.webTitle: Philippines election result is a win for dynasty politics

fields.headline: Philippines election result is a win for dynasty politics
fields.trailText: Alliance between Ferdinand Marcos Jr and Sara Duterte reinforces power of influential families
fields.body:
It was a deal â€“ rumoured to have been brokered at the exclusive island resort of Balesin â€“ that set the course of the Philippines election. The children of two of the countryâ€™s most powerful families agreed to join forces: dictatorâ€™s son Ferdinand Marcos Jr would run to be president in an alliance with Sara Duterte, the tough-talking daughter of the populist incumbent, Rodrigo Duterte.

Last week, they won a thumping victory. Marcos Jr secured 31 million votes, according to an unofficial count, thought to be the biggest mandate in decades. Sara Duterte, who ran to be vice-president, also won by a huge margin.

The pair were backed up by a host of powerful political names including the former president Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo, who reportedly brokered their alliance, and the family of former president Joseph Estrada. The heavyweights grouped together to oppose the rival candidate, Leni Robredo â€“ a reformist who wanted to pass an anti-dynasty law, and ultimately came second.

â€œWhen we look at the results in the numbers, that alliance worked,â€ said Prof Maria Ela L Atienza, who teaches political science at the University of the Philippines, pointing to how the candidates combined their respective support bases in the north and south of the country. â€œThey worked as a team and they were supported by all the traditional politicians.â€

Political parties are weak in the Philippines, and it is instead influential families who struggle for power, using patronage, vote-buying, intimidation and, at times, violence to keep relatives in office. The clout of families can rise and fall â€“ and rise again in the case of the Marcoses.

Marcos Jrâ€™s father, Ferdinand Marcos Sr, ruled for two decades, including a period of martial law, where he had absolute power, before he was ousted by a popular uprising in 1986.

Marcos Sr promised voters he would tackle the countryâ€™s dynasties, but instead merely replaced elites with cronies. He plundered up to $10bn (Â£8bn) and presided over rife rights abuses, where political opponents were tortured, arrested and disappeared.

Campaign alliances aside, the Marcoses, said Aries Arugay, a visiting fellow at the ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute, do no not pair up and rule as co-equals. â€œThe Marcoses rule by themselves.â€

Marcos Jrâ€™sâ€™ recent announcement that he will appoint Sara Duterte to lead the Department of Education â€“ and not defence, as was her preference â€“ has raised eyebrows.

In a statement, Duterte, a reserve officer, brushed off any suggestion she had been sidelined. â€œI expect that people who want to see the new administration fail will fabricate intrigues about my loyalty,â€ she said.

Rodrigo Duterte, who was blocked by the constitution from seeking a second term, did not endorse Marcos Jr, who he previously called a spoiled child and weak leader. Instead, he has openly expressed frustration that his daughter Sara, who was leading opinion surveys last year, did not go for the top job.

But for all his protests at his daughterâ€™s decision, Rodrigo Duterte himself fuelled the rise of the Marcoses, analysts say. He not only recommended a heroâ€™s burial for Marcos Sr in 2016 â€“ a highly controversial decision that contributed to the whitewashing of history â€“ but once described Marcos Jr as his preferred successor were he to stand down early.

Throughout Duterteâ€™s term, the Marcos family was building its base, with online disinformation campaigns flooding social media with false stories portraying Marcos Srâ€™s rule as a golden era.

The Dutertes â€œallowed this because the Marcoses were doing the work that the Duterte administration was too lazy to do or did not have the time to do, which is to pummel the oppositionâ€, Arugay said. Such glorification of martial law also benefited Duterteâ€™s authoritarian style of leadership.

â€œWhat Duterte and his administration failed to see is that it empowered the Marcoses even further in return,â€ he added.

The power of Philippine dynasties has only increased in the decades since the ousting of Marcos, distorting democracy and worsening inequality.

According to a 2019 study by Manilaâ€™s Ateneo School of Government, about 80% of governors belonged to â€œfat dynastiesâ€, meaning clans with two or more members in power at the same time â€“ and up from 57% in 2004. Political families also held 67% of seats in the House of Representatives, and 53% of mayoral posts.

â€œWithout dynasty regulation called for by our constitution, and given [the] little effort to curb vote-buying, and mixed record of anti-corruption in the past six years â€¦ then it is clear to see how dynastic politicians can further concentrate power,â€ said Dr Ronald Mendoza, who authored the study.

The pandemic and unemployment also increases peopleâ€™s vulnerability to patronage, a longstanding problem in the Philippines, said Mendoza.

Related: The return of a Marcos to power in the Philippines is a warning to the world | Nicole Curato

Local media reported that, in the days after the election, stores in some areas sold out of mobile phones, and restaurants were busier than usual, with shoppers openly saying they had received money from politicians running for congress and provincial posts.

The Commission on Elections told local media it had verified more than 100 cases of vote-buying, but did not believe such reports had affected the outcome of the vote.

Unless Marcos Jr, with a huge mandate, alters the constitution, he too will be limited to one six-year term.

Regardless, many more Marcoses are waiting in the wings. Marcos Jrâ€™s sister Imee is currently a senator, his cousin Martin Romualdez is poised to be the next house speaker, while his son Ferdinand Alexander, known as Sandro, was voted representative of Ilocos Norte, the family stronghold, last week.

Rodrigo Duterte will leave office on 30 June but has noted with satisfaction that, alongside Sara, his two sons are also in politics: one is a congressman and another has become mayor of Davao city, the familyâ€™s base.

results.webTitle: â€˜You shake at the smallest of noisesâ€™: Russian soldier tells of life as a PoW

fields.headline: â€˜You shake at the smallest of noisesâ€™: Russian soldier tells of life as a PoW
fields.trailText: Anton, released by Ukraine in a prisoner exchange, says he is only now registering the toll captivity took on mind and body
fields.body:
Still getting used to the feel of his gun and military fatigues, Anton suddenly found himself surrounded by Ukrainian forces as bullets flew by, with one striking his arm.

â€œIt was our first confrontation with the enemy; we hadnâ€™t even fired a shot. They ambushed us, and we couldnâ€™t fight back. We had to surrender,â€ said Anton, a 21-year-old Russian serviceman, in an interview with the Guardian.

Anton was taken captive by Ukrainian forces near Mykolaiv on 2 March with five other soldiers from his unit, as Russian forces were staging an offensive on the strategically important shipbuilding city near the Black Sea.

Anton, who asked not to be identified with his real name, would spend the next 45 days in Ukrainian captivity. He was eventually released in mid-April after Moscow arranged a prisoner exchange with Ukraine, and spoke to the Guardian from Russian territory.

Antonâ€™s story is a very rare account of a Russian PoW who has since been exchanged, as both Russia and Ukraine have released very little information about the fate of the hundreds of captive Russians.

Moscow does not publicise the names of its service people captured in Ukraine. However, during his captivity, Anton was interviewed as a Russian prisoner by a prominent Ukrainian vlogger. He was also named as a captured Russian soldier on websites close to the Ukrainian authorities.

I was sent to Ukraine completely unprepared

One of Antonâ€™s family members further confirmed to the Guardian that he was captured in Ukraine and then exchanged. The Guardian was not able to verify all the details of his story.

Anton, who comes from a small, remote city in Siberia, said he signed a contract to join the military last December, shortly after graduating from vocational school.

In hindsight, he said, he should â€œhave done everythingâ€ to avoid the army.

Antonâ€™s unit was first transferred during the last days of December to the Russian-annexed Crimean peninsula, where he was told he was taking part in a â€œone-weekâ€ training course.

By that point, he claimed he had received practically no military training that would adequately prepare him for a full-scale war.

As weeks went by in Crimea, Anton said some members of his unit started to worry they would be sent to war, a prospect he still considered to be completely â€œabsurdâ€.

â€œMany of the young guys couldnâ€™t even imagine that we would go to war. They told us at the very last moment about this, the night before the invasion,â€ he said.

â€œUltimately, it is really not fair how the Russian authorities treated me. I was sent to Ukraine completely unprepared.â€

Antonâ€™s account, which depicts a military unit that was kept in the dark about the invasion, echoes a number of other Russian soldiers who have similarly said that they did know they were going to war until they crossed into Ukraine. Military experts have argued that the decision to not tell a large number of its troops about the invasion is one explanation for Moscowâ€™s halting military campaign.

On 25 February, the day after Russian troops entered Ukraine, Antonâ€™s unit was ordered to cross into the country from Crimea.

He said they were driven in armoured vehicles to the outskirts of Mykolaiv, which was under heavy attack from Russian forces in the early days of the war.

As they continued on foot, part of the unit split from the main group and was ambushed by Ukrainian forces on 2 March, less than a week after entering the country. Anton said he was hit by a Ukrainian bullet while being captured, fracturing a bone in his hand.

We were constantly told that Russia is finished, that we belonged to the bottom of society. Theyâ€™d threaten to starve us

Soon after, Ukrainian forces put a bag on his head as he was transferred to a prison cell, the location of which he said he still does not know.

At first, life in captivity was dominated by fear. â€œYou shake at the smallest of noises. Every day you hope that this wonâ€™t be your last and you will not be killed,â€ Anton recalled.

He said that he was not physically assaulted during his time in captivity but alleged that Ukrainian guards would mentally torment him and other Russian soldiers.

â€œWe were constantly told that Russia is finished, that we belonged to the bottom of society. They would threaten to starve us.â€

Anton added that while some guards looked like â€œthey wanted to hurt youâ€, the majority remained calm and â€œwould not let their animal instinct set inâ€.

Ukraineâ€™s deputy prime minister Iryna Vereshchuk, who is in charge of negotiating prisoner exchanges, did not immediately respond to requests for comment. Under the Geneva conventions, the detention of PoWs after capture should not be seen as a form of punishment but as a means to prevent further participation in a conflict.

But it was the daily boredom that soon emerged as the biggest challenge, Anton said.

â€œIf we were lucky, we would be given something random to read. Sometimes they let us watch Ukrainian propaganda on television.

â€œMost days we would just stare at the walls in front of us,â€ he said, adding that he was moved three times during his captivity.

At one point, he was asked to record an interview about his capture with a prominent Ukrainian vlogger.

Ukrainian officials have given journalists and vloggers access to interview their Russian PoWs. Such videos have been watched by hundreds of thousands of people on YouTube, but they have also faced criticism for violating the Geneva conventions.

â€œIn such a situation, as a prisoner, you understand there isnâ€™t really a choice to say no. You agree despite them saying that you could refuse,â€ Anton said.

Related: Alleged Wagner Group fighters accused of murdering civilians in Ukraine

Eventually, in early April, Anton was told that he was going to be exchanged for a Ukrainian soldier.

While Russia and Ukraine have engaged in several prisoner swaps, both countries have released almost no details on the mechanisms behind the exchanges. On 4 April, Ukraine said that it held about 600 Russian military prisoners of war. Russia does not release exact figures, but in late March its human rights ombudswoman said there were more than 500 Ukrainian PoWs in Russia.

That number has since grown significantly after at least 1,000 Ukrainian fighters, including members of the Azov battalion, were transferred to Russian-held territory when the Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol was taken by Russian forces last week. Ukraine has said that the Azovstal fighters would be involved in a prisoner swap, but some Russian officials have said they could be tried or even executed.

According to Anton, he was part of a one-for-one swap involving 17 other Russian soldiers, which took place near the Ukrainian city of Melitopol.

As soon as he was back in Russia, he was intensely questioned by the security services about his time in Ukraine.

â€œThey wanted to know if they could still trust me. It was standard procedure,â€ he said.

But it was only days after he was discharged from a Russian hospital that he felt the full toll that his time in captivity had inflicted on his mind and body.

â€œDuring my captivity, I blocked most of my emotions. I just tried not to think about my life,â€ he said.

â€œBut now, I have terrible dreams, I can barely sleep. I have gained a lot of weight,â€ he said.

Anton said the authorities had given him about Â£2,000 as compensation for his injuries. According to Russian military law, service people do not receive any special compensation for being held as a PoW, and Anton was expected to return to service once he had recovered from the injuries.

But after his experience in Ukraine, Anton is now looking for ways to quit the military for good.

â€œI just want to go back home, man, that is it. All I want is to go home.â€

results.webTitle: What deals is China pursuing in the Pacific and why is everyone so worried?

fields.headline: What deals is China pursuing in the Pacific and why is everyone so worried?
fields.trailText: Chinaâ€™s foreign minister is embarking on a grand tour of Pacific nations amid western concerns about Beijingâ€™s ambitions for the region
fields.body:
Why is everyone talking about China in the Pacific all of a sudden?

Chinaâ€™s ambitions in the Pacific first attracted renewed attention back in March, when news leaked of a draft security agreement that would grant Chinese military and police significant access to Solomon Islands. The news surprised Australia and New Zealand, the Solomonâ€™s traditional security partners, as well as other Pacific nations and the US. This week â€“ as Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi embarked on a 10-day visit to the Pacific taking in eight countries â€“ news broke that Beijing was seeking to secure a sweeping economic security deal with 10 countries that would mean a dramatic expansion of its influence in the region.

Related: Five things we learned about Chinaâ€™s ambitions for the Pacific from the leaked deal | Anna Powles

Why are Australia, New Zealand and the US concerned?

All three countries have voiced concerns that an increased Chinese security presence in the Pacific would destabilise the region, with the biggest fear regarding the Solomons deal being that China could eventually establish a military base on the islands, just 2,000km from Australiaâ€™s east coast. Beijing and Honiara have denied such a plan.

Chinaâ€™s reported interest in establishing a similar deal with Kiribati, meanwhile, has been of concern due to its fishing resources and geostrategic location in the central Pacific. Kiribati and Solomon Islands both had diplomatic relations with Taiwan until 2019 when they switched to recognise China.

News of Wangâ€™s visit and the potential multilateral security and economic deal will have set fresh alarm bells ringing in Washington, Canberra and Wellington.

â€œWhen you consider the extent of Chinaâ€™s global interests and the relatively small size of the Pacific countries, that tells you immediately that Beijing has ambitious long-term plans in the region,â€ Richard McGregor, a senior fellow at Australiaâ€™s Lowy Institute, says.

What are they doing about it?

In her first days in office, Australiaâ€™s new foreign minister, Penny Wong, has made it clear that the Pacific will be one of Canberraâ€™s priorities after years of friction between the Pacific and the previous Liberal-National coalition government. She recorded a video address to regional leaders soon after her inauguration pledging to make climate a priority and that Australia would be a â€œgenerous, respectful and reliableâ€ partner. On Thursday she set off on her own competing visit to the Pacific, with a meeting with Fijiâ€™s prime minister, Frank Bainimarama, and a speech at the Pacific Islands Forum in Suva on the agenda.

The US sent a high-level delegation to Solomon Islands last month to express its concerns about the China deal, with ambassador Daniel Kritenbrink, assistant secretary of state for east Asian and Pacific affairs, later refusing to rule out military action should China establish a military base in the Solomon Islands.

New Zealand has taken a softer approach, with prime minister Jacinda Ardern this week saying it was â€œnot for us to speak on behalf of other Pacific nationsâ€ but that Wellington stood â€œready to respondâ€ to security needs in the region.

What deals has China signed in the Pacific and whatâ€™s in the pipeline?

The Solomons deal marks Beijingâ€™s first known bilateral security agreement in the Pacific. It is widely expected that China will sign further agreements with Solomon Islands during Wangâ€™s visit and will be looking to sign agreements with other Pacific nations during the tour as well.

Teburoro Tito, Kiribatiâ€™s ambassador to the US and the UN, told the Guardian this week that China had agreed in principle to finance the refurbishment of a world war two runway on Kanton island, but denied reports that a broader security deal was in the works.

There are concerns that Kiribati could sign a deal with China, giving it special fishing rights in the Phoenix Islands Protected Area (PIPA), which was one of the worldâ€™s largest marine protected areas, until the Kiribati government announced last year it would open up the PIPA to commercial fishing.

Vanuatu has just signed a contract with China for the construction of a new runway extension at Pekoa airport on the island of Santo, to allow access for larger aircraft, making it accessible for the delivery of humanitarian aid.

So have Australia, New Zealand and the US dropped the ball?

The Pacific islands have long accused Australia of failing to take their concerns on climate â€“ which they view as an existential threat â€“ seriously. Canberraâ€™s leaders have also been caught mocking the Pacific over its concerns. In 2015, then prime minister Tony Abbott and his immigration minister, Peter Dutton, were caught joking about rising sea levels in the region. After a 2019 meeting of the Pacific Islands Forum, several leaders accused then prime minister Scott Morrison of dismissive and insulting behaviour, with Bainimarama telling the Guardian his condescending attitude was pushing the Pacific towards China.

New Zealand has a more positive relationship, and 60% of its foreign aid goes to the region. However its influence has declined in recent years, with Dr Anna Powles, senior lecturer at the centre for defence and security studies at Massey University, putting this down to â€œassumptions that Australia and New Zealand didnâ€™t need to put considerable effort into the region to maintain their perceived primacyâ€.

The US has also been accused of disinterest and focusing on undermining China rather than responding to what Pacific leaders want.

What do the deals mean for the Pacific?

There are fears that deals mean not just a loss of sovereignty for island nations but also that they would make them the centre of unwanted geostrategic competition. Some of the second world warâ€™s bloodiest battles took place in the Pacific. In Solomon Islands there are also fears that Chinese military or police could be brought in to quell protests.

In a letter to 21 Pacific leaders seen by Reuters, David Panuelo, the president of the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM), which will be holding a virtual meeting with Wang, said his country would argue that the proposed multilateral deal should be rejected, because he feared it could spark a new â€œcold warâ€ between China and the west.

results.webTitle: Australian households face steep power bill increases as generation costs soar

fields.headline: Australian households face steep power bill increases as generation costs soar
fields.trailText: Customers in NSW could see power bill increases of up to 18%, South Australia almost 20% and parts of Queensland could see rises of 12%
fields.body:
Households in Queensland, New South Wales and elsewhere will face double-digit increases in their power bills from July after the regulator lifted its standard electricity price after generation costs soared by close to half.

The Australian Energy Regulator, which was ordered to delay the release of its default market offer (DMO) from 1 May until Thursday by the outgoing Morrison government, said residential customers in south-east Queensland will see increases of 11.3%-12.6%, or about double the expected inflation rate.

Similarly in NSW, residential customers will see increases 8.5%-18.3%, or much higher than the inflation rate. South Australia, the other state covered by the DMO, will see prices rise as much as almost 20%, while Victoria released its own reset for 2022-23 on Tuesday, lifting the price by 5%.

Related: Coalition delayed news that electricity prices are set to rise until after federal election

The DMO was set up in 2019 to give consumers who donâ€™t shop around a â€œprice safety netâ€. The offer serves as a price cap for residential and small business customers for how much energy retailers can charge electricity consumers on default plans, known in the market as standing offer contracts.

Rising gas and coal prices globally have contributed to a spike in wholesale power prices to record levels. Repairs or outages to as much as a third of the coal-fired power fleet have also contributed to the recent jump.

The incoming energy minister, Chris Bowen, said the sharp increase in the standard market price was the result of â€œnine years of delay and denialâ€ by the Coalition government that would now be left with households and businesses to pay.

â€œThe Liberal legacy is higher power pricesâ€ for the residents of Queensland, NSW and South Australia covered by the so-called default market offer, he said. â€œNine years of policy chaos means we donâ€™t have enough renewables in the systemâ€ nor enough transmission to link them up â€œthe cheapest form of energyâ€ to the grid.

Bowen also took aim at his predecessor, energy minister Angus Taylor, for acting to delay the release of the higher DMO. As reported by Guardian Australia earlier this week, Taylor ordered the regulator to delay the new offer from 1 May until today, after the election.

â€œAngus Taylor knew this report was coming out,â€ Bowen said. â€œThey sat on this report. They approved its delay until after the election â€¦ they put power prices up and were dishonest about it.â€

A spokesperson for Taylor earlier this week denied the delay was for political reasons. During the campaign, Coalition ministers and the prime minister Scott Morrison claimed power prices had fallen by as much as 10%, a figure also included in the March budget.

The spokesperson on Thursday said Bowenâ€™s comments were â€œfactually incorrectâ€.

â€œWe did not see the final Dmo prices until they were made public this morning so your claims of â€˜hidingâ€™ them are complete rubbish,â€ he said. â€œThey were a decision of [the] AER.â€

Related: Penny Wong tells Pacific nations â€˜we have heard youâ€™ as Australia and China battle for influence

The AER said that since the last DMO, wholesale costs for retailers have risen by 49.5% in Queensland, 41.4% in NSW and by 11.8% in South Australia. These increases were â€œdue to reductions in thermal generation resulting from unplanned outages and higher coal and gas prices, slowing of investment in new capacity, and increasingly â€˜peakyâ€™ demand (sharp highs and lows) driving up the cost of wholesale electricity contracts for retailersâ€.

The rise in generation costs had preceded Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine in February, and the resulting increase in global prices for gas, coal and other energy supplies had compounded Australiaâ€™s increases. Extreme weather in NSW and Queensland had also affected coal supplies and electricity demand, as had further unplanned outages at multiple generators, the regulator said.
