Asic launched the federal court lawsuit in October 2020, accusing Youpla of engaging in misleading and deceptive conduct towards potential customers.

The companyâ€™s marketing material was misleading and deceptive because it said the group was run by Aboriginal people, approved by the Aboriginal community, better than other funeral insurance products on sale and told plan holders they would get a lump sum payout when they would actually only get reimbursed for funeral expenses.

Youpla denied the allegations and the case was moving towards a trial, but progress stalled after the group collapsed into administration on 11 March.

results.webTitle: Queensland to roll out simultaneous flu and Covid testing in line with NSW hospitals

fields.headline: Queensland to roll out simultaneous flu and Covid testing in line with NSW hospitals
fields.trailText: Exclusive: Move comes two days after state announced free flu vaccines for the next month as cases rise
fields.body:
Sick people will soon be tested for Covid and the flu simultaneously at state-run fever clinics and hospitals across Queensland, as authorities scramble to get a hold on rising cases.

Simultaneous testing for Covid, influenza and other respiratory illnesses such as respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is also now in place in hospitals across New South Wales.

Queensland Health confirmed its plan to roll out simultaneous testing to the Guardian on Wednesday, two days after it announced flu vaccines would be free for the next month in a move NSW and Victoria flagged they would follow.

Private pathology providers in every state and territory are also understood to be testing for viruses other than Covid, including influenza, when taking samples. But this was not available at every facility, and depended on the reason for someone attending, their symptoms and the government rebates available.

Related: All Australians should be offered free flu vaccines to prevent â€˜disasterâ€™, experts say

The Guardian can also reveal the federal Department of Health has discussed potential changes to the Medicare rebate system to allow for simultaneous testing, as Covid and influenza tests currently attract separate rebates.

â€œThe department has had discussions with the pathology sector in relation to future changes to testing that would support a range of respiratory targets being tested for at the same time as Covid-19,â€ the department said in a statement.

â€œAny changes to MBS (Medicare Benefits Schedule) rebates for respiratory tests are a matter for the incoming government.â€

The federal government provides financial assistance to the states and territories for the additional costs incurred in their Covid responses, including 50% of testing costs.

At the end of March, the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) released recommendations for all state, territory and private testing sites to â€œsupport the targeted testing of multiple respiratory pathogens simultaneouslyâ€.

â€œThe prevalence of influenza in the community will inform decisions on the appropriate timeframe for this to commence,â€ the AHPPC said in its winter preparedness plan.

Queensland Health said it supported the AHPPC plan and was working to introduce simultaneous testing as soon as possible.

â€œQueensland Health fully supports the AHPPC statement on winter season preparedness which includes expanded and targeted testing for COVID-19 and influenza over winter,â€ a spokesperson said.

â€œQueensland Health is working toward routine combined testing for COVID-19 and other respiratory viruses such as influenza.â€

In NSW, simultaneous testing has been included since the start of the flu season, which arrived early this year amid persistently high Covid cases and staff furloughing due to illness.

Dr Karen Price, president of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, supported the move.

â€œGiven that weâ€™re still in a global pandemic, weâ€™ve got Covid at near-record numbers, and weâ€™ve got capacity issues in the hospital and health system more broadly, it may make good public health sense to start understanding whatâ€™s going on and where itâ€™s going on,â€ she said.

Price said most people would recover from flu with rest at home but if they were seriously unwell and not getting better they should contact their GP or a respiratory clinic for further assistance.

â€œWe see the whole person so weâ€™re not just seeing influenza, weâ€™re seeing influenza in a diabetic or weâ€™re seeing influenza in someone whoâ€™s highly anxious,â€ she said.

â€œIf you get symptoms, stay home. If youâ€™re concerned about it escalating, then seek perhaps a telehealth appointment from your GP to understand whether or not you need to come in and be seen.â€

South Australia is also looking at implementing simultaneous testing and officials are working through affordability and accessibility issues, and the split in testing between public and private health facilities.

Related: High-risk people eligible for second Covid booster vaccine under new Australian guidelines

The stateâ€™s chief public health officer, Prof Nicola Spurrier, said SA Health was â€œstill discussing all of those issuesâ€.

â€œThere are ways of doing the flu and Covid together but weâ€™ve got to make sure that weâ€™ve got the balance right in our state,â€ she said on Monday.

Announcing plans for free flu vaccinations, the NSW health minister, Brad Hazzard, said this yearâ€™s flu season could be the worst in years.

Over the week ending last Sunday, 1,125 people presented to NSW hospitals with flu-like illnesses, while cases of the virus in Queensland jumped 132% in the space of a week.

results.webTitle: â€˜I didnâ€™t know I had it in meâ€™: soul singer Miiesha steps into the spotlight

fields.headline: â€˜I didnâ€™t know I had it in meâ€™: soul singer Miiesha steps into the spotlight
fields.trailText: The Indigenous musician was discovered as a teenager in the tiny community of Woorabinda. She talks about losing her beloved grandmother, finding poetry in pain and a transformative trip to the desert
fields.body:
In the year after Miiesha Young won the 2020 Aria award for best soul/R&B release for her debut album, Nyaaringu, Australiaâ€™s most promising neo-soul singer resolved to give it all up.

Related: Country detour brings out the Whitlamsâ€™ Black Stump ballads

â€œIt was a very, very dark time in my life,â€ she explains on the phone from Brisbane, where the 23-year-old Anangu and Torres Strait Islander woman is searching for a place to rent between promotional duties for her new dual EP, Smoke & Mirrors. â€œI just wanted to give everything up â€“ I wanted to throw it all away. I didnâ€™t know who I was without my grandmother.â€

Miiesha had lost her â€œrockâ€ â€“ â€œthe person who gave me that nurturing and love growing upâ€ â€“ at the end of 2019. That year also saw the first shoots of a music career that the â€œyoung Black woman from the missionâ€ in Woorabinda, Queensland, had never dared dream possible. Her first two singles, Black Privilege and Drowning, were picked up by Triple Jâ€™s Unearthed, then her performance at Brisbaneâ€™s Bigsound festival clinched her a record deal with EMI. â€œFor [my nan] to witness that was very important for me because I didnâ€™t know I had it in me â€“ but she always knew,â€ she says.

The subsequent album, Nyaaringu (meaning â€œwhat happenedâ€ in Pitjantjatjara), was a chance for Miiesha to celebrate the â€œstrength and beautyâ€ of her grandmother, who was a member of the stolen generations. Woven through the album are spoken-word interludes of her grandmother imparting wisdom, which Miiesha recorded when she was 19.

Musically, Nyaaringu is the kind of slinky, glitchy R&B that has seen Miiesha compared to the likes of Solange, FKA twigs and Ella Mai, her sultry, breathy vocals sitting incongruously alongside charged lyrics such as: â€œSurvival ainâ€™t that beautiful / Iâ€™ve just made it look this good for you,â€ and a 2015 soundbite of Tony Abbott dismissing remote communities as â€œlifestyle choicesâ€. Nyaaringu was released in May 2020, just as George Floydâ€™s murder ignited the US; the albumâ€™s examination of racism and celebration of Indigenous identity chimed with the global rise of the Black Lives Matter movement.

An Aria and National Indigenous Music award followed. But behind the scenes, the wheels were coming off for Miiesha. Covid lockdowns derailed her tour plans. She left Melbourne, where she had been based, to ride out the pandemic in Rockhampton, two hours north-east of her home town, a tiny Aboriginal community with a population less than 1,000 that had shut its doors to keep out the virus.

Into the stasis crept insecurities about her talent, as did the reality of life without her grandmother, who had acted as a buffer for her â€œrollercoasterâ€ relationship with her mother. Any hopes Miiesha had of her mother filling the maternal void soon vanished. â€œI was like, â€˜Mum, you need to be there for me,â€™â€ she recalls. â€œI couldnâ€™t understand her pain because I was clouded, because I had lost somebody so important to me that all my emotions kind of balled up inside me. I was very self-destructive â€¦ It is that intergenerational trauma, and I had to understand that itâ€™s like a chain.â€

In times of turmoil, Miiesha had always turned to writing poetry â€“ the starting point for her songs â€“ but even that proved too painful. When she was finally able to process her emotions, they came rushing out in the swirl of songs on Smoke, the first part of her EP that was released in November. Its singles â€“ the Nima-winning Damaged, the funky Queensland Music award-winning Made for Silence and the sublime Price I Paid â€“ wrestle with love and forgiveness amid a â€œbrokenâ€ mother-daughter relationship. â€œ[Mum has] heard the songs, and she gets frustrated, she gets angry, she gets sad about it,â€ Miiesha says. â€œShe rings me up crying about it but I believe thatâ€™s healing for her too.â€

Mirrors, by contrast, is â€œthe calm after the stormâ€. â€œSmoke & Mirrors represent two chapters of my life and the growth between those chapters,â€ Miiesha explains. â€œI donâ€™t feel so much hate or resentment because I understand where my pain is coming from.â€

Miiesha describes Mirrorsâ€™ opening track, Everything, as a â€œfight songâ€ with a singular message: â€œJust donâ€™t give up.â€

â€œI had to see for myself that I am worth something, that I do have it in me to keep going. I donâ€™t need somebody there with me the whole time. I had to find the light myself without somebody handing me the candle.â€

I didnâ€™t realise how beautiful and how old and how deep my blood runs

In Everything, she sings: â€œMy mind floods like / Iâ€™ve been drowning this whole time / Too late to learn to swim.â€ Water and emotional undercurrents appear in much of Miieshaâ€™s music, having spent much of her childhood in Woorabinda, where the parched Mimosa Creek would only run when it flooded. The communityâ€™s history as a relocated, government-controlled Aboriginal reserve, made up of 52 different clans sent there from across Queensland, New South Wales and the Northern Territory, meant Miiesha â€œfelt lost growing upâ€, disconnected from her ancestral country and culture.

She was first exposed to music through her mumâ€™s love of gospel and 90s R&B. She recalls feeling awestruck, aged five, after hearing a singer at her church in Rockhampton, and vowed to â€œsing like her one dayâ€. When she was 13, Stephen Collins, a 22-year-old youth worker from Sydney, visited Woorabinda for a month with a laptop and microphone to set up a sustainable music program. Miieshaâ€™s grandmother signed her up and a song she penned earned her an invite to perform at a Naidoc event in Sydney.

Collins ended up staying in Woorabinda for six years, becoming like a brother to Miiesha. When she turned 18, he encouraged her to join him in NSW for a two-week recording stint. A songwriting partnership flourished, leading to three years bouncing between Sydney, Melbourne and Collinsâ€™ family farm near Goulburn.

In 2018 Miiesha had an experience that would prove transformative: accompanying her grandmother on a two-week trip to Amata, a red-dirt desert community on her grandfatherâ€™s country in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara lands.

â€œAll the brothers went hunting and the women prepared food,â€ she says. â€œIt was a beautiful experience. I just felt at home.â€ At night she slept in a tent beside her grandmother and siblings: â€œIt was dead quiet and it felt like I could hear the stars.â€

Related: Flume finally finds happiness: â€˜I didnâ€™t want to tour any more. I hated my jobâ€™

The trip was â€œreally importantâ€ for her, she says. â€œGrowing up in a mission, I didnâ€™t really feel a connection to who I am. I donâ€™t think anyone [in Woorabinda] does, because we were all just put in one spot and we had our culture taken away from us. I didnâ€™t know I had this empty space in my heart and I didnâ€™t know what was missing.

â€œSeeing my grandmother go back to this familiar place, seeing these old girls that she hadnâ€™t seen for 20-plus years, watching them huddle together and cry, and watching my grandmother speak Pitjantjatjara â€¦ I didnâ€™t realise how beautiful and how old and how deep my blood runs.â€

Miiesha hopes to use her platform to â€œopen doorsâ€ for other young artists in Woorabinda, a community she says is brimming with creativity.

â€œI never wanted the spotlight because I didnâ€™t want to have to be brave; I didnâ€™t want to have to be strong,â€ she says. â€œI thought I was the worst person to be a role model. And now Iâ€™ve come to accept that this is who I am, this is what Iâ€™ve been given, and I have to bring these people up because I think itâ€™s so important. I saw the bigger picture, you know?â€

  • Smoke & Mirrors is out on 3 June. Miiesha plays the Sydney Opera House that day, Brisbane on 10 June and Melbourne on 11 June

results.webTitle: No action taken against Victorian mental health services despite more than 12,000 complaints

fields.headline: No action taken against Victorian mental health services despite more than 12,000 complaints
fields.trailText: Exclusive: reports from stateâ€™s mental health regulator show some services donâ€™t hand over complaint outcome data
fields.body:
After receiving more than 12,000 complaints about Victorian mental health services, the stateâ€™s regulator has not taken compliance action against a single mental healthcare provider in seven years.

This is despite the royal commission into the Victorian mental health sector last year finding systemic breaches of the law and human rights across the system.

Annual reports from Victoriaâ€™s mental health complaints commissioner (MHCC) showed that in the seven years since it was first established in July 2014, it received 14,160 inquiries, of which 12,470 were complaints. Yet no compliance notices were issued, despite the MHCC having regulatory powers to compel providers to improve.

Related: Calls for people with mental impairment to get more protections in Victoriaâ€™s justice system

The MHCC is an independent body that resolves complaints about Victoriaâ€™s public mental health services and makes recommendations for improvements.

The MHCCâ€™s service provider complaint reports, obtained under freedom of information, show that some mental health services do not hand over data on the outcomes of complaints, in breach of the stateâ€™s Mental Health Act (2014).

Simon Katterl, a human rights and mental health consultant who obtained the reports, said it was â€œsimply unbelievableâ€ that more than 12,000 complaints did not warrant a compliance notice.

â€œWeâ€™ve have had a regulator in place for eight years during a human rights crisis but we have no evidence they have acted during that crisis,â€ he said.

â€œYou can tell that by the lack of transparency in the regulator and the lack of use of their powers.â€

Katterl said while complaints data alone could not always give a clear picture of what is occurring in a service â€“ forensic mental health services, for example, have higher numbers of complaints due to the complexity of their care â€“ it was nonetheless data the public had a right to access.

â€œThe public deserves this information so they can make better informed decisions about the care they receive,â€ he said. â€œThey deserve transparency.â€

An MHCC spokesperson said it regularly worked through â€œa range of processesâ€ with services to address issues and improvements identified in the complaints and investigations process.

â€œServices have cooperated with our processes and to date a compliance notice has not been required to achieve this outcome,â€ the spokesperson said.

The stateâ€™s peak mental health organisation said it had â€œreal concernsâ€ about the MHCCâ€™s lack of enforcement.

The Victorian Mental Illness Awareness Councilâ€™s chief executive, Craig Wallace, said an â€œunwillingness to rock the boat with service providersâ€ was most likely behind the lack of action by the regulator against noncompliant providers who did not provide full data about complaint outcomes.

Related: â€˜People donâ€™t choose to become addictsâ€™: the push to end Victoriaâ€™s war on drugs

The chief executive of Mind Australia â€“ a community-based mental health provider, Gill Callister, said it was vital people with mental health concerns, their families and carers had access to â€œinformation about the performance and approachâ€ of the mental health services they access.

â€œFor a lot of people, a lack of transparency reinforces the view that theyâ€™re sitting at the bottom of the pile in terms of priority even when seeking information about their own care,â€ she said.

The royal commission recommended the creation of a new mental health and wellbeing commission to monitor the governmentâ€™s delivery of the inquiryâ€™s reform. The scathing report found the over-burdened system was crisis-driven and not designed to support people living with psychological distress or mental illness.

In one case, a mental health service had 60 complaints for every 1,000 patients made to the MHCC in 2018-19, and 57 complaints for every 1,000 patients made the following year.

  • Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

â€œTreatment was the most common issue raised in complaints,â€ one of the reports said. â€œResponsiveness of staff was frequently raised â€¦ and included inadequate consideration of the views of consumers, family and carers, as well as lack of care and attention.â€

â€œSuboptimal treatment [quality of treatment] was also commonly raised, particularly with the MHCC, with the most commonly raised suboptimal treatment issue for MHCC complaints being disagreement with treatment order.â€

A government spokesperson said the new commission would include people with lived experience who will have increased scope to investigate complaints.

â€œThe current MHCC uses a range of resolution tactics to resolve issues raised through complaints â€“ including formal conciliation which makes sure complainants can continue to engage with the mental health system in the long-term,â€ the spokesperson said.

results.webTitle: France has â€˜huge hopesâ€™ of rebuilding relationship with Australia after Coalitionâ€™s â€˜deceitfulâ€™ behaviour

fields.headline: France has â€˜huge hopesâ€™ of rebuilding relationship with Australia after Coalitionâ€™s â€˜deceitfulâ€™ behaviour
fields.trailText: Exclusive: Ambassador Jean-Pierre ThÃ©bault says Australian governmentâ€™s stronger climate stance a â€˜gamechangerâ€™ opening doors to more cooperation internationally
fields.body:
Franceâ€™s ambassador to Australia has declared the former Morrison government was widely seen as â€œrefusing to take responsibilityâ€ to act on the climate crisis, suggesting the Albanese governmentâ€™s new policy will help repair trust.

Jean-Pierre ThÃ©bault also told Guardian Australia there had never been a problem between the people of France and Australia, but the breakdown was linked to the â€œdeceitful attitudeâ€ taken by â€œa certain administrationâ€.

Eight months on from the Aukus-fuelled rift, ThÃ©bault said he now had â€œhuge hopesâ€ for rebuilding the relationship between the two countries.

The Albanese governmentâ€™s stronger 2030 emissions target has also been welcomed by senior European diplomats, who believe it could help smooth the way towards a long-awaited free trade agreement between the European Union and Australia.

Related: Franceâ€™s outgoing foreign minister welcomes defeat of Scott Morrison

The EU ambassador to Australia, Michael Pulch, said it might now be possible to agree on â€œa more ambitious sustainable trade chapterâ€ â€“ and that â€œcertainly will helpâ€ the process of ratifying the deal through the European parliament.

Both ambassadors spoke to Guardian Australia after they attended an Indo-Pacific forum at the Australian National University in Canberra on Wednesday â€“ an event designed to showcase the EUâ€™s interest in closer cooperation in the region.

ThÃ©bault said the new Australian governmentâ€™s position on climate change â€“ including a 43% cut in emissions by 2030 against 2005 levels â€“ was â€œtruly a gamechangerâ€, and took aim at the previous governmentâ€™s refusal to increase the target.

â€œIt is something on which Australia was widely seen, not only by EU but also by Pacific countries, as not fulfilling its potential and refusing to take responsibility,â€ said the French ambassador, who was recalled to Paris at the height of the tensions last year.

â€œToday, we have a complete change of footing, which has been widely applauded.â€

ThÃ©bault said France welcomed the new stance, which opened avenues for pragmatic cooperation â€œnot only bilaterally, also internationally, and especially in this region, that we both have a strong interest forâ€.

He said he hoped for â€œa substantial, very positive, constructive reconnection [and] relaunchâ€.

â€œIâ€™ve received a lot of messages from Australians â€“ the quiet Australians â€“ who have been loudly saying we hope, especially on climate change, on these common threats, that we can act together,â€ ThÃ©bault said, using a phrase coined by Scott Morrison.

â€œWe will work on this, but also many other aspects â€“ but this remains to be discussed among the leaders and among the responsible persons to make it possible and to make it stronger than ever.â€

Franceâ€™s outgoing foreign affairs minister, Jean-Yves Le Drian, made some undiplomatic remarks on Sunday, saying Morrisonâ€™s defeat in the election â€œsuits me very wellâ€ after the cancellation of the French submarine deal showed â€œbrutality and cynicismâ€.

ThÃ©bault said Le Drian had been speaking â€œon the basis of his experienceâ€, noting that the long-serving foreign minister had also been the defence minister before that.

â€œHe also was personally very involved in the building of this confident relationship [with Australia], which does probably explain the bluntness of his assessment, but he wasnâ€™t the only one to express dissatisfaction with the way things were being handled,â€ ThÃ©bault said.

â€œIt was a deceitful attitude then but, you know, it was not only the French who felt that. It has been the Europeans and it has been very large sectors of the Australian public opinion.â€

Morrison and his ministers have always maintained that France would have been upset by the cancellation of the deal, regardless of when it was told, and the pursuit of nuclear-powered submarines was justified by the worsening strategic outlook in the Indo-Pacific.

Labor is committed to the Aukus deal with the US and the UK and agrees with the strategic case for nuclear-propelled submarines, so there is no prospect of a return to the French project.

The incoming government will likely have to sign off on the financial settlement with Franceâ€™s Naval Group in coming months, given the negotiations were not concluded by the time of the election.

Related: Australia to stand with Pacific islands on climate crisis and â€˜respectâ€™ region, Penny Wong says

Progress on an EU-Australia free trade agreement slowed down after the diplomatic rift with France, although a postponed round of negotiations went ahead in February.

Pulch, who heads the EU delegation in Canberra, said the next round of negotiations was likely to be held by October and the new climate policy was â€œa very good signalâ€.

â€œIn the European parliament, there is generally a view that every agreement that we sign â€“ whether itâ€™s political, economic or trade â€“ should be a net-plus when it comes to implementation of the Paris Agreement,â€ Pulch said in an interview.

The EU released its strategy for cooperation in the Indo-Pacific in September but it was overshadowed by the Aukus fallout.

Pulch said the EU was committed to the strategy, which was â€œmore important than everâ€ after Russia invaded Ukraine.

Amid intensifying competition with China for influence, Pulch said Australia and the EU could help Pacific island countries with infrastructure and â€œoffer an alternative to Chinese investmentâ€.

â€œAustralia matters to us,â€ he said.

Earlier, the EUâ€™s special envoy for the Indo-Pacific, Gabriele Visentin, described Australia as a â€œregional powerâ€ and crucial to the strategy.

Visentin said this engagement â€œgoes beyond governments, beyond political partiesâ€.

â€œOur strategy is - allow me to say - a love letter to the region,â€ Visentin said in conversation with the head of the ANUâ€™s national security college, Prof Rory Medcalf.

â€œIt says that we want to do more.â€

Visentin said the strategy was focused on cooperation not confrontation â€œso we donâ€™t ask our partners to take sidesâ€.

results.webTitle: â€˜As we head into winter, itâ€™s an important considerationâ€™: whatâ€™s the deal with vitamin D?

fields.headline: â€˜As we head into winter, itâ€™s an important considerationâ€™: whatâ€™s the deal with vitamin D?
fields.trailText: People who live in Australiaâ€™s southern states are at greater risk of being low in the hormone that packs a crucial health punch
fields.body:
As winter sets in and Australians living in the southern states don scarves, beanies and puffer jackets, many are bracing for a season of colds and flu. Being a season that also tends to bring less sun exposure, winter is associated with lower vitamin D levels, which our bodies derive mainly from the sun. And while this is known to impact bone health, there is growing evidence that vitamin Dâ€™s functions could be more extensive, with deficiencies linked to greater risk from respiratory infections.

â€œWhen our vitamin D levels are extremely low, they can cause muscle aches and pains of the body and can impact the immune response to infections,â€ says Vicki Kotsirilos, associate professor at Western Sydney University. â€œSo as we head into winter, itâ€™s an important consideration.â€

What is vitamin D?

Despite its common name, the fat-soluble vitamin D is now regarded as a hormone. It is made by the body through a series of steps. When exposed to ultraviolet B (UVB) rays from the sun, cholesterol in the skin is converted to cholecalciferol (D3) and ergocalciferol (D2), which travel in the bloodstream to the liver where they are metabolised to form calcidiol. These then head to the kidneys and are converted to the active hormone, calcitriol.

Related: Does vitamin D combat Covid?

Around 90% of our vitamin D intake comes from the sun. â€œVitamin D deficiency is a sunlight deficiency,â€ says Ian Brighthope, professor of nutritional and environmental medicine and director of the National Institute of Integrative Medicine.

We can derive smaller amounts from the diet as vitamin D3 or D2. Food sources include fatty fish such as salmon and tuna, eggs, mushrooms, beef liver and full-cream milk. Supplements are also a source of vitamin D3.

Vitamin D and the immune system

Vitamin D helps bones take up calcium and other important minerals and has long been known to help prevent rickets in children and bone problems such as osteoporosis in adults. But it became apparent that vitamin Dâ€™s impact went well beyond bone health after vitamin D receptors were discovered in most cells in the body â€“ including immune cells â€“ signalling other functions.

â€œVitamin D has a very broad spectrum of activity,â€ says Brighthope. â€œProbably, its most important activity is on the immune system, because we now know that people who have high levels of vitamin D in their system are less likely to get acute, severe respiratory infections and end up in hospital and dying in intensive care.â€

We were meant to live in daylight. We werenâ€™t meant to live in caves

Ian Brighthope

There is general agreement on the importance of sun exposure, but Professor Prue Hart, principal research fellow at the Telethon Kids Institute, suggests the benefits are not due to vitamin D but rather other molecules produced by the skin. Hart says although blood levels of vitamin D levels are associated with immunity, clinical supplementation trials have not shown any benefit.

While some studies have shown no benefit, a 2017 meta-analysis of 25 randomised controlled trials with more than 11,000 participants reported that vitamin D supplements helped ward off acute respiratory infection.

As these different studies suggest, nothing is simple, because several factors could be at play with respiratory infections. Vitamin D supplements are most likely to benefit someone with a deficiency.

â€œVitamin D is only one member of an orchestra of nutrients and it doesnâ€™t work very well if you abuse your kidneys and your liver with alcohol or eat high levels of salt, fat and sugar in particular,â€ says Brighthope. â€œAll of these things suppress your immunity.â€ Vitamin D supplements may not always work in people with comorbidities such as heart disease, cancer, stroke, diabetes and metabolic syndrome, he adds.

Brighthope says a medical practitioner with postgraduate nutrition qualifications is best equipped to address these complexities.

How do you know if youâ€™re deficient?

Rickets or osteoporosis could be an alarm bell for vitamin D deficiency, as could muscle aches and pains as Kotsirilos noted. Other than that, itâ€™s hard to tell.

Related: Slip, slop, what? Why putting on sunscreen suddenly seems complicated

â€œVitamin D deficiency doesnâ€™t carry with it too many symptoms,â€ says Brighthope. People may notice neuropsychiatric or neurophysiological changes, he notes. â€œFor example, it can be tiredness, poor sleep, poor appetite, depression or depression mixed with anxiety.â€ But these could all be attributed to other factors as well.

Therefore, a blood test is the best way to measure vitamin D status.

Who is at risk?

People who live in the lower latitudes of Victoria, the ACT, New South Wales, South Australia and Tasmania are generally at greater risk of deficiency than those in the northern regions.

â€œThere are also what we call subpopulations within those groups that have a high risk of vitamin D deficiency,â€ says Kotsirilos. â€œFor example, people who are more house bound, community-dwelling, older and/or disabled people, dark-skinned people and people who are overdressed and avoid the sun or work indoors.â€ Sunscreen can also block UVB rays.

How do I boost my vitamin D levels?

Getting outdoors is the best way to get vitamin D levels up. â€œThe easiest way is safe sun exposure,â€ says Kotsirilos. But with our modern lifestyles this can be tricky.

â€œWe were meant to live in daylight,â€ says Brighthope. â€œWe werenâ€™t meant to live in caves, but Iâ€™m sure you are sitting in your cave right now, like I am. So you should really be out there foraging for nuts, seeds, berries and perhaps doing a little bit of fishing.â€ Physical activity is also thought to help the body produce vitamin D.

Failing that, supplementation can help to lift low vitamin D levels. Recommended intakes vary considerably, and it is best to consult a medical practitioner about appropriate supplement dosage and monitoring.

What about skin cancer risk?

Australians have a relatively high incidence of skin cancer, usually from excessive UV exposure, so common sense should prevail when going out in the sun.

â€œGoing out in the full midday sun in summer is crazy, and going into ultraviolet tanks for tanning is crazy,â€ says Brighthope. Basically, Hart says we should avoid getting sunburnt â€“ but this is not generally as big an issue in winter.

â€œOver summer itâ€™s important to cover up and be safe between the hours of say 11am to 5pm,â€ says Kotsirilos. Balancing this with vitamin D requirements, sun protection is recommended if the UV index is above 3.

Brighthope suggests exposing your skin to moderate amounts of sunlight for 20 minutes a day, or for up to 30-60 minutes before 11am and after 3pm. â€œProviding youâ€™re not fair-skinned,â€ he adds. For very pale people, Kotsirilos proposes 15 minutes of exposure per day. â€œItâ€™s a matter of knowing thyself and everything in moderation.â€

results.webTitle: New Coalition MP was founding member of club promoting climate science denial

fields.headline: New Coalition MP was founding member of club promoting climate science denial
fields.trailText: LNP member for Flynn, Colin Boyce, signed international statement rejecting climate crisis and criticised science in state parliament
fields.body:
The new federal MP for the Queensland seat of Flynn was a founding member of a club formed to promote climate science denial, and was a signatory to an international statement claiming â€œthere is no climate emergencyâ€.

Colin Boyce did not respond to questions as to whether he is still a member of the Saltbush Club, a group which published commentary during the election campaign that said the climate crisis is â€œa fraudâ€.

He would not say whether he still supported the â€œworld climate declarationâ€, which he signed in 2019 alongside figures such as Ian Plimer. At the time he was the only Australian MP â€“ state or federal â€“ to publicly support the document, which repeats long-debunked talking points on climate change that are contradicted by scientific institutions and academies around the world.

Related: The Noosa yacht club member who led the hemp party to its best result yet in Queensland

Boyce, a one-time boilermaker who resigned as a Queensland MP to run for the federal parliament, shot to prominence during the election campaign when he said the Coalitionâ€™s net zero pledge was â€œflexibleâ€ and left â€œwiggle roomâ€.

A search of Queensland Hansard showed that in his four and a half years in state parliament Boyce repeatedly criticised and rejected climate science.

In a 2019 speech, Boyce claimed that pollution-prevention measures in the Great Barrier Reef catchment were â€œbased on flawed, manipulated science that is driven by a socialist political agendaâ€.

During the same speech he said: â€œI believe in climate change. It is a normal, cyclic event that has been happening for millions of years and will continue to happen.â€

â€œClimate alarmists make outrageous claims that we will all die from sea level rise, temperature rise and climate events and are being called out. Their doomsday predictions, including the demise of the Great Barrier Reef, have not eventuated.â€

In a 2018 speech, he read into Hansard an article by Viv Forbes, a Queensland-based coalmining millionaire and one of the key figures of the Saltbush Club. The article claimed that burning fossil fuels created â€œplant foodâ€ and that â€œwe should celebrate, not fear, the â€˜modern warm eraâ€™â€.

  • Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

In 2021, after an explosion at the Callide coal-fired power station in Boyceâ€™s electorate, he argued for the construction of a new coal plant. He said the argument against building new coal plants was â€œdriven by the mind-numbing, eco-Marxist millennials and upper middle-class â€˜wokesâ€™ who have been indoctrinated with some quasi-religious belief that coal is bad and carbon dioxide is poisoning the planetâ€.

Boyce has previously paid for Facebook ads that call renewable energy â€œa fantasyâ€.

Related: Australian Greens hail â€˜best result everâ€™ with dramatic gains in lower house and Senate

On Tuesday, Labor ministers in the Queensland parliament used question time to lampoon Boyce, who will become Queenslandâ€™s newest federal LNP MP after an election where the Coalition lost heartland seats to the Greens and climate-conscious independents.

â€œOnce again, the climate change deniers, the science sceptics and the anti-vaxxers in the Queensland LNP helped wreck the federal coalition and destroy the â€¦ federal Liberal party on the way,â€ the treasurer, Cameron Dick, told parliament.

â€œThey ensured that Josh Frydenberg lost his seat. And who did Australia get in return? Colin Boyce.â€

Boyce enters the federal parliament as the decimated ranks of Liberal moderates attempt to bring the party back to the centre. One expessed concern that Boyce, who will sit with the Nationals, has the potential to further damage the Coalitionâ€™s ability to appeal to lost voters.

A Queensland LNP state MP said â€œwe used to hold our breathâ€ when Boyce stood up to speak.

â€œHeâ€™s Canberraâ€™s problem now,â€ they said.

results.webTitle: West Hamâ€™s contract talks with Tomas Soucek reach impasse over pay rise

fields.headline: West Hamâ€™s contract talks with Tomas Soucek reach impasse over pay rise
fields.trailText: West Hamâ€™s talks with Tomas Soucek over a new contract have reached an impasse
fields.body:
West Hamâ€™s talks with Tomas Soucek over a new contract have reached an impasse. The Czech Republic midfielder has two years left on his deal, with an option for an extra year, and negotiations with West Ham over a pay rise have stalled.

Soucek has been a key figure since joining from Slavia Prague in January 2020 but the 27-year-old struggled to find his best form this season and David Moyes is thinking about strengthening his midfield.

Related: Chelsea target KoundÃ© and Gvardiol after government clears takeover

Moyes is tracking Leeds Unitedâ€™s Kalvin Phillips and Southamptonâ€™s James Ward-Prowse as he considers how to refresh his team. Soucek has looked tired in recent months and his partnership with Declan Rice has not been quite as effective.

However Soucekâ€™s weariness owes much to West Hamâ€™s lack of cover in midfield. Alex Kral failed to impress after joining on loan from Spartak Moscow last summer and Mark Noble has not played much in his final season. That increased the load on Soucek, whose physicality and goalscoring threat have made him one of West Hamâ€™s most important players. There is hope on both sides that the contract situation can be resolved despite suggestions that West Ham will consider suitable bids.

West Ham remain in talks with Rennes over signing of Nayef Aguerd. Moyes wants to buy a left-sided centre-back and Aguerd is regarded as one of the best defenders in Ligue 1.

results.webTitle: New era for Philippines as Ferdinand Marcos Jr proclaimed president

fields.headline: New era for Philippines as Ferdinand Marcos Jr proclaimed president
fields.trailText: Dictatorâ€™s son will take office on 30 June, marking the dynastyâ€™s return to the seat of power
fields.body:
Ferdinand Marcos Jr was flanked by his family, including matriarch Imelda Marcos, as he stood at the rostrum in the Philippines Congress to be proclaimed president-elect, marking the dynastyâ€™s return to the seat of power.

Marcos Jr won almost 59% of votes in an election earlier this month, more than double that of his closest rival. His landslide victory followed a highly divisive campaign that was dominated by disinformation that sought to glorify the regime of his dictator father, Ferdinand Marcos Sr, who plundered as much as $10bn while in office, and presided over rife human rights abuses.

Marcos Jr has not acknowledged or apologised for abuses that were perpetrated under his father. In comments made after the proclamation, he said he was humbled by the election result, stating: â€œI promise you, that we may not be perfect, but we will always strive to perfection.â€

Imelda, 92, who is appealing against a 2018 criminal conviction on seven corruption charges, was helped on to the platform to stand beside her son as his hands were raised by the senate president and speaker. Marcos was also accompanied by his wife, Liza Araneta-Marcos, his sisters Imee and Irene Marcos and son Joseph Simon Marcos.

Imee Marcos, who is a senator, told CNN Philippines that she believed her family now had the opportunity to show what it â€œstill can do for the countryâ€.

She said: â€œWhatâ€™s most important to us is of course our name, the family name that has become so controversial, and so difficult at times to bear. The legacy of my father is what we hope will be clarified at last.â€

Imee Marcos told media that Imeldaâ€™s health had improved rapidly following her sonâ€™s election victory. â€œShe is suddenly able to hear, walk, and her ailments. All her ailments suddenly went away. She is suddenly agile. She looks 29 years old, not 92,â€ she said.

Imelda, who has previously said it was her sonâ€™s destiny to become president, was granted bail to appeal corruption charges due to her old age and health.

The familyâ€™s return to power has horrified both survivors of Marcos Srâ€™s brutal regime, and those who fear the family will again use its power to enrich itself and crack down on opponents. Prior to the proclamation, protesters gathered at the Commission of Human Rights to denounce the election result. Police responded with water cannon to prevent the groups from marching to Congress.

Marcos Jr faces ongoing legal challenges to his presidency, with campaigners arguing that he should have been barred from the presidential race due to a past conviction for failing to file his income tax returns. Two cases have reached the supreme court.

Were the supreme court to rule against Marcos, it is possible that Sara Duterte, who ran in tandem with Marcos to be vice-president, could take the highest office.

Related: The return of a Marcos to power in the Philippines is a warning to the world | Nicole Curato

Sara Duterte, daughter of the outgoing president Rodrigo Duterte, was proclaimed vice-president-elect on Wednesday. She was not accompanied by any family members as she took to the rostrum. Her father had previously questioned her decision not to run for the presidency.

Marcos Jr received more than 31m votes, out of more than 55m cast, while Sara Duterte won more than 32m.

After the session, Marcos Jr asked for people to pray for him. â€œWish me well. I want to do well because when a president does well, the country does well. And I want to do well for this country,â€ he said. His term will begin on 30 June.

results.webTitle: Burnley close to appointing Vincent Kompany as manager

fields.headline: Burnley close to appointing Vincent Kompany as manager
fields.trailText: Burnley are close to appointing the former Manchester City captain Vincent Kompany as their manager after relegation to the Championship
fields.body:
Burnley are close to appointing Vincent Kompany as their manager. The former Manchester City captain left his job as Anderlechtâ€™s head coach on Wednesday and is poised to accept the challenge of trying to lead Burnley out of the Championship.

Kompany had been in charge of Anderlecht since August 2020, although he started the previous season as player-manager before choosing to concentrate on playing. The club finished third this season and a parting of ways suits both parties.

Taking over at Burnley would return Kompany and his family to the north-west of England. His wife is from nearby Manchester, where their three children were also born. Kompany played for City from 2008-19.

Burnley were relegated last week and face the likely loss of several players and the need to reconfigure finances to be sustainable. Mike Jackson oversaw the final matches of the season after Sean Dyche was sacked but an upturn in form was not enough to prevent the club from finishing 18th.

Burnley last played in the second tier in 2016, when they won the title, having finished second to win promotion two years earlier.

results.webTitle: Republicans offer thoughts and prayers â€“ but not gun control to stop the killings

fields.headline: Republicans offer thoughts and prayers â€“ but not gun control to stop the killings
fields.trailText: Response in Congress to Texas school shooting that left 21 people dead comes from all-too-familiar Republican playbook
fields.body:
As the cycle of American gun violence took its latest turn on Tuesday, with at least 19 children and two teachers brutally murdered at an elementary school in the small town of Uvalde, Texas, the response from the Republican right came from an all too familiar playbook.

Related: Texas school shooting: all victims were in the same classroom, official says â€“ latest updates

Thoughts and prayers, obfuscation and inaction.

Shortly after the shooting, Republican Senate minority leader Mitch McConnell, who for well over a decade has led his party in vehemently blocking a raft of federal gun control measures, decried the â€œdisgusting violenceâ€ in Uvalde and said: â€œThe entire country is praying for the children, families, teachers, and staff and the first responders on the scene.â€

But prayers aside, there remains little to no hope of commonsense gun control measures making their way into federal law, despite support from the majority of American voters.

Within hours of the bloodshed on Tuesday, many of the national Republican Partyâ€™s most outspoken voices on gun ownership recited talking points now rote in the aftermath of mass shootings.

Texas senator Ted Cruz, who also sent prayers to the community in Uvalde, castigated Democrats and members of the media during a brief interview with CNN. â€œInevitably when thereâ€™s a murder of this kind you see politicians try to politicize it,â€ he said. â€œYou see Democrats and a lot of folks in the media whose immediate solution is to try to restrict the constitutional rights of law-abiding citizens. That doesnâ€™t work. Itâ€™s not effective. It doesnâ€™t prevent crime.â€

His remarks were almost identical in the aftermath of the Parkland school shooting in Florida back in 2018, which claimed the lives of 17 students and teachers. Despite a grassroots protest movement, in which hundreds of thousands of school children descended on Washington in a March for Our Lives, no federal legislation was passed. Jury selection in the death penalty trial of the Parkland shooter continues this week, a further marker of the trauma these mass shootings leave behind.

Meanwhile, Cruz is set to speak at the National Rifle Association leadership summit on Friday, in Houston, just 280 miles from Uvalde, alongside Donald Trump and Texas governor Greg Abbott.

Other senior Texas Republicans, who have presided over a series of measures aimed at loosening restrictions on firearm ownership in the state, reiterated calls to arm teachers, despite the fact the shooter engaged a number of armed officers as he successfully stormed the school building.

â€œWe canâ€™t stop bad people from doing bad things,â€ Texas attorney general Ken Paxton told Fox News on Tuesday. â€œWe can potentially arm and prepare and train teachers and other administrators to respond quickly. That, in my opinion, is the best answer.â€

Among other US Republican senators, perceived as more open to bipartisan agreement, the sentiment remained largely the same. North Carolina senator Thom Tillis told reporters on Tuesday he had not seen any indication in initial reports that suggested the shooterâ€™s record â€œâ€‹â€‹was in any way affected by Congressâ€™s actions or inactionâ€.

Tillis continued to express skepticism over so-called â€œred flag lawsâ€ adopted by a handful of US states in the wake of Parkland, which aim to allow authorities to restrict gun ownership from individuals deemed a threat to public safety. In 2019 bipartisan efforts in the US Senate to support such laws failed and on Tuesday Tillis reiterated his concern that such laws were â€œoverreachâ€.

While Democrats, who control the House of Representatives, passed two House gun control bills last year, which aimed to expand and strengthen background checks, there remains little to no hope of their passage through the split US Senate where 60 votes are required to pass legislation. On Tuesday, the conservative Democrat Joe Manchin also reiterated he did not support calls from within the party to reform senate filibuster rules, which could allow the passage of legislation with a simple majority.

There was no sign either that a new generation of Republican senators might offer any hope for bipartisan gun reform measures. At a victory party on Tuesday night in Georgia, the newly nominated, Trump-endorsed Senate candidate Herschel Walker evaded questions over the massacre.

Asked if he supported any new gun control measures in the aftermath, Walker responded: â€œWhat I like to â€¦ what I like to do, is see it and everything and stuff,â€ before being ushered away.

Supporters at the event reportedly booed as president Joe Bidenâ€™s address to the nation was broadcast, during which he asked: â€œWhen in Godâ€™s name are we going to stand up to the gun lobby? When in Godâ€™s name are we going to do what has to be done? Why are we willing to live with this carnage?â€

The president was far from alone in expressing indignation on the legislative paralysis in Congress.

During an impassioned speech on the senate floor on Tuesday, Connecticut Democrat Chris Murphy invoked the memory of the Sandy Hook massacre almost 10 years ago in his home state as he urged his colleagues to engage with reform efforts.

â€œWhat are we doing?â€ Murphy said. â€œWhy do you spend all this time running for the United States Senate? Why do you go through all the hassle of getting this job, of putting yourself in a position of authority, if your answer is that as this slaughter increases, as our kids run for their lives, we do nothing?â€

results.webTitle: Tory MPsâ€™ staff tell Boris Johnson abuse is treated as â€˜mere gossipâ€™ in parliament

fields.headline: Tory MPsâ€™ staff tell Boris Johnson abuse is treated as â€˜mere gossipâ€™ in parliament
fields.trailText: Exclusive: Letter urges PM and party to do more to tackle sexual abuse, harassment and bullying
fields.body:
Serious sexual abuse, harassment and bullying accusations made against MPs are treated as â€œmere gossipâ€, dozens of Conservative staffers have said, as they urged Boris Johnson and party HQ to do more to tackle the problem.

The group of staff working for Tory MPs said â€œbehaviour committed by a few individuals but tolerated by others has stained the reputationâ€ of parliament.

Their intervention follows a string of incidents â€“ including a Tory MP being arrested on suspicion of rape, a second being jailed for sexually assaulting a child and another being investigated over sexual harassment claims.

In a letter seen by the Guardian, the staffers warned: â€œA culture of gossip and rumour has enabled the toleration and acceptance of abuse for too long. This has to change.â€

They said that â€œpersistent stories of abuse and denigration of standards in parliamentâ€ had left them â€œashamedâ€ and that improvements to the system of reporting harassment were not enough.

â€œMaking abuse easier to report does nothing to change the root cause: a culture of indifference and fear,â€ they wrote.

â€œIn any other workplace, things would never have been allowed to get this bad. It is shocking that those most involved in the governance of our country have overseen such a denigration of standards.

â€œWe understand that the power to make change often lies outside of parliament, with the government and political parties themselves.

â€œHowever, all it takes for evil to prosper is for good people to stand by and do nothing. Change must come from the top â€“ MPs must call out their colleaguesâ€™ behaviour and end this constant cycle of scandal that tarnishes all of us.â€

The letter, organised by two staffers and sent to the prime minister, the Conservative party chair Oliver Dowden, and the Commons Speaker, Lindsay Hoyle, added that â€œsexual abuse, harassment and bullying have started to become synonymous with politicsâ€ and â€œmajor allegations of illegal behaviour are treated as mere gossipâ€.

The group called on the party to â€œuphold the commonsense decency of the British people and stand up to behaviour that is so clearly wrongâ€ and called for changes.

They urged Conservative Central Headquarters (CCHQ) to incorporate an assessment of how potential candidates say they would treat staff and run their office professionally into the selection process.

And the whipsâ€™ office was asked to ensure that those under investigation should have the whip suspended.

The whipsâ€™ office â€“ in charge of party discipline â€“ refused to withdraw the whip from the MP arrested on suspicion of rape earlier this month, and another MP arrested for the same reason in 2020.

Several sources suggested figures in the whipsâ€™ office and party HQ had been exerting pressure on people asked to sign the letter and urging them not to â€“ though this was disputed.

A spokesperson for the chief whip said: â€œThe whipsâ€™ office values the work that all parliamentary staffers do and will always work to ensure they are looked after in parliament.â€

One who signed the letter told the Guardian: â€œBeing an MP should be the greatest honour of your life. Itâ€™s not an excuse to use your power and privilege to try to turn the mother of parliaments into a knocking shop.â€

Other staffers dismissed the letter, saying it was too scornful of the government and so was unlikely to lead to the desired changes.

The organisers are understood to have been granted a meeting with the chief whip on Thursday.

A Conservative party spokesperson said they took all complaints seriously and that staff could â€œraise complaints or speak to our HR team at any point if they want adviceâ€. They added that all candidates must subscribe to the partyâ€™s code of conduct, constitution and equal opportunities policy.

A government spokesperson said there was â€œabsolutely no place for bullying, harassment or sexual misconduct in parliamentâ€ and that â€œwe take all claims of this nature incredibly seriously and would encourage anyone with allegations to come forward to the relevant authoritiesâ€.

They added: â€œTackling these issues is rightly a matter for parliament and the prime minister is fully committed to working with the parliamentary authorities, Speakerâ€™s office, and on a cross-party basis, to improve the culture in parliament.â€

results.webTitle: Boris Johnsonâ€™s Partygate remorse lasts all of 30 seconds | John Crace

fields.headline: Boris Johnsonâ€™s Partygate remorse lasts all of 30 seconds
fields.trailText: Wine stains, puke and brawling at No 10 â€“ none of the details in Sue Grayâ€™s report are enough to flush out a PM devoid of shame
fields.body:
Well, there we had it. It had been heavily briefed that Boris Johnson would be the model of remorse for his statement to the Commons on the Sue Gray report. But that Boris lasted barely 30 seconds and what we got thereafter was the classic narcissistâ€™s non-apology. A tawdry torrent of self-pity. A man more sinned against than sinner. A good man cast adrift in a world he barely understood.

The Convict began by saying he was grateful to Gray. I bet he was. There was little doubt she had pulled her punches. She was a career civil servant, after all, who had spent a lifetime covering up other peopleâ€™s messes. Yes, there were some telling details in her report â€“ the wine stains, the puke, the brawling, the dodging out of sight of CCTV cameras at 4am, the altered invitations â€“ all of which suggested that everyone knew they were acting against the law. But there was no smoking gun. Or not one that could flush out a prime minister devoid of shame.

â€œI donâ€™t say this to absolve myself,â€ Johnson said repeatedly. Except he did. And time and again he found himself worthy of total absolution. The fixed-penalty notice he had received? That was for something that was never a party. But he accepted his martyrdom. Not. He would go to his grave believing he had done nothing wrong. Not least because as the police hadnâ€™t busted him for any further crimes, then he couldnâ€™t have committed any.

Nor did people understand quite how large No 10 was, so it was impossible to keep tabs on everyone. Which was weird because other prime ministers have complained how small the building is. And he had just been showing good leadership by turning up to the illegal leaving parties. It had never occurred to him that some of the parties might go on for hours. The Convict had always wondered why there was so much noise and the cleaners were complaining about having to clear up so many empties.

Johnson ended by saying the bad old days were over. The entire senior management team had changed â€“ it hadnâ€™t occurred to him that he might be in any way responsible for the chaos and law-breaking in No 10 â€“ and from now on he was going to be extra nice to the little people. He might even speak to them.

â€œWe are humbled,â€ he said with a dismissive, regal wave of his arm. Except he wasnâ€™t at all. You need empathy and a state of grace to feel humbled. He didnâ€™t even feel humiliated. Which any normal person would have been.

There was no hint of repentance or sincere apology. Just delusional ramblings. A man far more dangerous than a serial liar. An amoral sociopath capable of believing any falsehood to be true if it fits his solipsistic worldview. Nothing will shake his belief that he never lied to parliament or anyone else. The truth is just a matter of perception.

Keir Starmer tried to prise open the gaping cracks in the Convictâ€™s logic. Thatâ€™s how the light gets in. The report was a monument to hubris. Even though it appeared to have been heavily edited in parts, it still had enough in it for any reasonable person to expect the prime minister to go.

Did Johnson never wonder why everyone was permanently pissed and it was impossible to find anyone doing any real work after 4pm? How come he never looked at tables weighed down with booze and wondered what the fuck was going on? And the idea of the governmentâ€™s ethics adviser bringing her own karaoke machine into work was straight out of The Thick of It.

By now, though, the Convict could no longer maintain even the facade of giving a shit. He tugged at his toddler haircut and smirked. Couldnâ€™t Starmer just let go of his â€œsanctimonious obsessionâ€? He was fed up with everyone droning on about party this and party that. No one was going to take him down. Top of the world, Ma. And Sue â€“ Johnson lapsed into the familiar â€“ had investigated the party in the Downing Street flat exhaustively. As in not at all. Labour clearly believed she had been nobbled. But Johnson just wanted everyone to move on. To a place where no one could eat or pay their fuel bills.

The Tory response was muted. There were a few of the usual quarterwits â€“ step forward Peter Bone, Michael Fabricant and Craig Mackinlay â€“ to say the prime minister was a paragon of virtue and that no one could expect anyone to have obeyed the rules as they were all so complicated â€“ but only Tobias Ellwood called out the Convict as a liar who was destroying the image of the Tory party.

â€œWe will lose the next election,â€ he said, as several of his own side heckled him. They are as truth-averse as their leader. The rest of the Tory backbenchers made their excuses and left. Anything to escape the scene of the crime. Within 40 minutes of the statement starting, the benches were less than a quarter full. Though the stony-faced cabinet had to stay and take their punishment beating. The question is what happens next. Do the Tories feel lucky enough to put their letters in to the 1922 Committee? Or do they stick with the man who will drag them ever further into the dirt?

A couple of hours later, the Convict was giving a press conference in Downing Street. If anything, he was now even more deconstructed. Just phoning it in and openly laughing in journalistsâ€™ faces as he brazenly made no attempt to answer their questions. As if he believed he had got away scot-free on a technicality. His answer to allegations of lying to parliament and the country was yet more lies. It was somehow a fitting symmetry. He canâ€™t help himself.

The closest he got to coming unstuck was when the Guardianâ€™s Jessica Elgot asked him if he was not bothered that his press officers had openly lied to the media about parties they themselves had been at. It was like this. His media team were like him. They genuinely believed their own lies. The vomit in their waste bins was work vomit.

â€œMy job is to serve the country,â€ Johnson said. In which case, why doesnâ€™t he do us all a favour and bugger off. â€œIâ€™ve got to love you and leave you.â€ Something heâ€™s said to every wife and lover. He looked at his watch. Past four. Past wine oâ€™clock. Time for a drink. There was going to be one hell of a party in the Downing Street flat tonight.

results.webTitle: French Open 2022: Raducanu beaten, Zverev wins, Djokovic through on day four â€“ as it happened!

fields.headline: French Open 2022: Raducanu beaten, Zverev wins, Djokovic through on day four â€“ as it happened!
fields.trailText: Emma Raducanu lost in three sets to Aliaksandra Sasnovich, Alex Zverev came from two sets down to beat Sebastian Baez and Novak Djokovic won easily against Alex Molcan
fields.body:
6.07pm BST

Righto people, my watch is over. To do a quick around the courts before I depart, itâ€™s Bencic 5-2 Andreescu, Korda 1-0 Gasquet (with a break), Dimitrov 6-0 4-3 Coric and Munar 6-2 7-6(3) 2-6 2-6 2-5 Schwartzman. Otherwise, join us again tomorrow!

6.04pm BST

Itâ€™s so nervous out there now, Alcaraz amping up the crowd before ceding match point ... then Ramos-Vinolas tamely nets! And have a look! Alcaraz climbs into the next point, and facing a defensive lob, he lets it bounce then, from the backhand corner, clobbers a flat smash cross-court for break-back point! Then Ramos-Vinolas nets a backhand, and weâ€™re back on serve in set four! Ramos-Vinolas 1-6 7-6(7) 7-5 5-5 Alcaraz

6.00pm BST

A monstrous forehand gets Alcaraz 15-30, but then he nets from mid-court looking to be too precise with loads of margin for error. Ramos-Vinolas, though, canâ€™t capitalise, going long to cede a break-back point ... but a long return takes us to deuce.

5.54pm BST

Alcaraz is in trouble again, serving at 4-4 30-40 ... and he goes long with his first effort. This is a colossal chance for Ramos-Vinolas, who plays his way into the next rally, then runs around his backhand to absolutely leather a forehand winner down the line! He will now serve for the match!

5.48pm BST

On Chatrier, Bencic and Andreescu are away; Bencic leads 2-1 with a break.

5.46pm BST

And Schwartzman, a semi-finalist in 2020, is 3-0 up on Munar in their decider.

5.46pm BST

Weâ€™re still on serve on Mathieu, where itâ€™s now4-3 to Alcaraz in set four, but still 2-1 Rmos-Vinolas overall.

5.37pm BST

Novak Djokovic [1] beats Alex Molcan 6-2 6-3 7-6(4)!

He meets Bedene next, which will be more of a test, I think.

Updated at 5.50pm BST

5.31pm BST

Djokovic and Molcan are now playing a breaker in set three â€“ Djokovic leads by two sets to one; Schwartzman has just forced a decider against Munar, having won sets three and four 6-3; and Dimitrov leads Coric 5-0.

5.29pm BST

But have a look! Ramos-Vinolas flicks a lob from under the net, not just over it but down the line, and that snatches back the break immediately!

Updated at 6.27pm BST

5.25pm BST

Alcaraz is very, very serious, and he breaks Ramos-Vinolas at the first time of asking â€“ though, in fairness, he didnâ€™t actually have to do all the much to get it. Anyroad, he leads 2-0 in the fourth, trailing 1-2.

5.22pm BST

Next on Chatrier: Bencic [14] v Andreescu.

5.19pm BST

Zverev tells Mats that he told Baez, this is the worst heâ€™ll ever feel on a tennis court, and he knows that feeling himself having been two sets up and two points away from the US Open. But he couldnâ€™t bring it home, losing in the fifth. Whatâ€™s also interesting is that when asked why, match point down, he served down the middle, he says that he finds the forehand is the side on which people tend to get tight, and though he couldâ€™ve looked silly, it worked out for him.

5.17pm BST

Well! Ramos-Vinolas serves out for the third set! He leads Alcaraz 1-6 7-6(7) 7-5!

5.15pm BST

Alexander Zverev [3] beats Sebatian Baez 2-6 4-6 6-1 6-2 7-5!

What a match! What a performance from Baez! But itâ€™s Zverev through to meet either Nakashima or Griekspoor next; currently, the former leads 7-6(6) 6-4 1-2.

Updated at 6.18pm BST

5.13pm BST

Zverev gets to 30-15, Baez nets, and from 2-0 down and then match point down, the number three seed has match point....

5.12pm BST

Sklhhhsqpp! Alcaraz hands Ramos-Vinolas a break point, looks set to save it when a drop means all his opponent can do is dig it out ... but he dumps the simple put-away! Ramos-Vinolas will no serve for the third set!

Updated at 6.26pm BST

5.08pm BST

Eeesh, Zverev sends Baez scurrying to hither and yon, a slice to the forehand corner setting up the put-away for break point. What foes Baez have left? Ach, he finds a fine forehand, but then going for the backhand winner cross-court, he goes fractionally, wife, and Zverev will now serve for the match at 6-5 in the fifth!

5.06pm BST

â€œThere are some matches I watch, I feel proud that I was a player â€“ when you see guys dig this deep,â€ says Mac, when Zverev levels at 5-5. Itâ€™s a lovely sentiment, though Iâ€™m not sure pride and Zverev go together.

Related: Lessons to be learned from ATP handling of Alexander Zverev abuse allegations | Tumaini Carayol

Anyway, itâ€™s been an unbelievable match, and weâ€™re in great shape on Mathieu too, where Alcaraz and Ramos-Vinolas are 1-1 and 5-5.

5.03pm BST

Zverev, though, finds a colossal serve, good enough to save match point. But heâ€™s not out of the woods yet, not by a long chalk.

5.02pm BST

A glorious drop from Baez gets him 30-all and heâ€™s two tantalising points away from an incredible win. Heâ€™s been so brave in this final set, unloading the suitcase at everything. So he goes again, hauls Zverev to the net, and eventually whacks the ball at him hard enough so that the volley in response goes long!

4.56pm BST

Baez holds again and now leads 5-4 in the decider!

4.54pm BST

Alcaraz, champion that he is, breaks Ramos-vinolas back immediately; Djokovic now leads Molcan by two sets and a break; and Schwartzman has won the third against Munar to trail 2-1. But the most serious action is still on Chtrier, where a final-set breaker looks likely at 4-4. Itâ€™s extremely tense now...

4.47pm BST

Ach, Zverev nails two devastating backhands down the line to break back at the first time of asking, and now trails 3-4 in the fifth.

4.45pm BST

Sloane Stephens beats Sorana CÃ®rstea [26] 3-6 6-2 6-0!

Thatâ€™s a bazzing win for the 2018 finalist, and she meets Osorio or Parry next.

Updated at 6.21pm BST

4.44pm BST

Aaarrgghhhh! Baez earns a break point and have an absolute look! He flings his entire being into a forehand to the backhand corner, and though Zverev gets it back, the ball floats long! This is unbelievable behaviour, it really is â€“ to go up two sets, be yanked back 1 and 2 by one of the worldâ€™s best ... only to rebound like this? Amazing. Zverev 2-6 4-6 6-1 6-2 2-4 Baez

Updated at 4.47pm BST

4.39pm BST

Alcaraz is under pressure! The Madrid champ is broken early in set three and is struggling from the back against Ramos-Vinolasâ€™ loopy lefty style. Djokovic, meanwhile, has taken the second set from Molcan and leads 6-2 6-3.

Updated at 4.40pm BST

4.32pm BST
